sn.q: That which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance.

sn.def: A disagreement or difference between two parts of the same legal proceeding, which, to be effectual, ought to agree, -- as between the writ and the declaration, or between the allegation and the proof.
The expected value of the square of the deviation from the mean of a randomly distributed variable; the second moment about the mean. This is also the square of the standard deviation.

entry.ety: L. varians, p. pr. of variare to change: cf. F. variant. See Vary

sn.def: Varying in form, character, or the like; variable; different; diverse.
Changeable; changing; fickle.
sn.q: He is so variant, he abit [abides] nowhere.

entry.ety: Cf. F. variante
entry.def: Something which differs in form from another thing, though really the same; as, a variant from a type in natural history; a variant of a story or a word.

entry.ety: L. variatus, p. p. of variare. See Vary
entry.def: To alter; to make different; to vary.

entry.cs: Annual variation Astron the yearly change in the right ascension or declination of a star, produced by the combined effects of the precession of the equinoxes and the proper motion of the star. Calculus of variations. See under Calculus. Variation compass. See under Compass. Variation of the moon Astron an inequality of the moon's motion, depending on the angular distance of the moon from the sun. It is greater at the octants, and zero at the quadratures. Variation of the needle Geog. & Naut the angle included between the true and magnetic meridians of a place; the deviation of the direction of a magnetic needle from the true north and south line; -- called also declination of the needle.
entry.ety: OE. variatioun, F. variation, L. variatio. See Vary

sn.def: The act of varying; a partial change in the form, position, state, or qualities of a thing; modification; alteration; mutation; diversity; deviation; as, a variation of color in different lights; a variation in size; variation of language.
sn.q: The essences of things are conceived not capable of any such variation.

sn.def: Extent to which a thing varies; amount of departure from a position or state; amount or rate of change.
Change of termination of words, as in declension, conjugation, derivation, etc.

Repetition of a theme or melody with fanciful embellishments or modifications, in time, tune, or harmony, or sometimes change of key; the presentation of a musical thought in new and varied aspects, yet so that the essential features of the original shall still preserve their identity.
One of the different arrangements which can be made of any number of quantities taking a certain number of them together.
sn.syn: Change; vicissitude; variety; deviation.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of LL. variola smallpox
entry.def: Chicken pox.
See Varix.

entry.ety: Varix + -form
entry.def: Resembling a varix.

entry.ety: Varix a dilated vein + Gr. � tumor: cf. F. varicocèle
entry.def: A varicose enlargement of the veins of the spermatic cord; also, a like enlargement of the veins of the scrotum.

entry.ety: L. varicosus, from varix -icis, a dilated vein; cf. varus bent, stretched, crooked

sn.def: Irregularly swollen or enlarged; affected with, or containing, varices, or varicosities; of or pertaining to varices, or varicosities; as, a varicose nerve fiber; a varicose vein; varicose ulcers.
Intended for the treatment of varicose veins; -- said of elastic stockings, bandages, and the like.

entry.ety: NL. See Varix, and -osis
entry.def: The formation of varices; varicosity.

sn.def: The quality or state of being varicose.
An enlargement or swelling in a vessel, fiber, or the like; a varix; as, the varicosities of nerve fibers.

entry.ety: See Varix; -tomy
entry.def: Excision of a varicosity.
Varicose.
Changed; altered; various; diversified; as, a varied experience; varied interests; varied scenery.
entry.q: The varied fields of science, ever new.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Variegated; p. pr. & vb. n. Variegating
entry.ety: L. variegatus, p. p. of variegare to variegate; varius various + agere to move, make. See Various, and Agent
entry.def: To diversify in external appearance; to mark with different colors; to dapple; to streak; as, to variegate a floor with marble of different colors.
entry.q: The shells are filled with a white spar, which variegates and adds to the beauty of the stone.

entry.def: Having marks or patches of different colors; as, variegated leaves, or flowers.
entry.q: Ladies like variegated tulips show.

entry.def: The act of variegating or diversifying, or the state of being diversified, by different colors; diversity of colors.

entry.ety: From Vary
entry.def: A wanderer; one who strays in search of variety.
entry.q: Pious variers from the church.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a variety; characterizing a variety; constituting a variety, in distinction from an individual or species.
entry.q: Perplexed in determining what differences to consider as specific, and what as varietal.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A variety; -- used in giving scientific names, and often abbreviated to var.

entries.entry:
Va*ri"e*ty ☞ Varieties usually differ from species in that any two, however unlike, will generally propagate indefinitely (unless they are in their nature unfertile, as some varieties of rose and other cultivated plants); in being a result of climate, food, or other extrinsic conditions or influences, but generally by a sudden, rather than a gradual, development; and in tending in many cases to lose their distinctive peculiarities when the individuals are left to a state of nature, and especially if restored to the conditions that are natural to typical individuals of the species. Many varieties of domesticated animals and of cultivated plants have been directly produced by man. ☞ These may be viewed as variations from the typical species in its most perfect and purest form, or, as is more commonly the case, all the forms, including the latter, may rank as Varieties. Thus, the sapphire is a blue variety, and the ruby a red variety, of corundum; again, calcite has many Varieties differing in form and structure, as Iceland spar, dogtooth spar, satin spar, and also others characterized by the presence of small quantities of magnesia, iron, manganese, etc. Still again, there are varieties of granite differing in structure, as graphic granite, porphyritic granite, and other varieties differing in composition, as albitic granite, hornblendic, or syenitic, granite, etc.
Geographical variety Biol a variety of any species which is coincident with a geographical region, and is usually dependent upon, or caused by, peculiarities of climate. Variety hybrid Biol a cross between two individuals of different varieties of the same species; a mongrel.
Variety Diversity. A man has a variety of employments when he does many things which are not a mere repetition of the same act; he has a diversity of employments when the several acts performed are unlike each other, that is, diverse. In most cases, where there is variety there will be more or less of diversity, but not always. One who sells railroad tickets performs a great variety of acts in a day, while there is but little diversity in his employment. n.; pl.Varieties #. L. varietas: cf. F. variété. See Various
The quality or state of being various; intermixture or succession of different things; diversity; multifariousness.
Variety is nothing else but a continued novelty. The variety of colors depends upon the composition of light. For earth hath this variety from heaven. There is a variety in the tempers of good men.
That which is various. Specifically:
A number or collection of different things; a varied assortment; as, a variety of cottons and silks. He . . . wants more time to do that variety of good which his soul thirsts after.
Something varying or differing from others of the same general kind; one of a number of things that are akin; a sort; as, varieties of wood, land, rocks, etc.
Biol An individual, or group of individuals, of a species differing from the rest in some one or more of the characteristics typical of the species, and capable either of perpetuating itself for a period, or of being perpetuated by artificial means; hence, a subdivision, or peculiar form, of a species.
In inorganic nature, one of those forms in which a species may occur, which differ in minor characteristics of structure, color, purity of composition, etc.
Theaters Such entertainment as in given in variety shows; the production of, or performance in, variety shows. Cant Diversity; difference; kind. All sorts are here that all the earth yields!Variety without end. But see in all corporeal nature's scene, What changes, what diversities, have been!

Variety show. A stage entertainment, live or televised, of successive separate performances, usually songs, dances, acrobatic feats, dramatic sketches, exhibitions of trained animals, or any specialties. When performed live in a theater, it was often called a vaudeville show, but when television became a dominant form of entertainment live vaudeville performances almost completely ceased.
Variety store. a retail store selling a wide variety of items, especially of low price, as in a five and ten.

entry.ety: L. varius various + -form
entry.def: Having different shapes or forms.
Formed with different shapes; having various forms; variform.

entry.ety: L. varius various + -fy
entry.def: To make different; to vary; to variegate.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. varius various. See Various
entry.def: The smallpox.
Variolous.
Inoculation with smallpox.

entry.ety: Cf. F. variole smallpox. See Variola

sn.def: A foveola.
A spherule of a variolite.

entry.def: Variolous.

entry.ety: L. varius various + -lite: cf. F. variolite
entry.def: A kind of diorite or diabase containing imbedded whitish spherules, which give the rock a spotted appearance.

entry.ety: From Variola

sn.def: Thickly marked with small, round specks; spotted.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, variolite.

entry.ety: Variola + -oid: cf. F. varioloïde
entry.def: Resembling smallpox; pertaining to the disease called varioloid.

entry.note: ☞ It is almost always a milder disease than smallpox, and this circumstance, with its shorter duration, exhibits the salutary effects of previous vaccination or inoculation.
entry.ety: Cf. F. varioloïde. See Varioloid a.
entry.def: The smallpox as modified by previous inoculation or vaccination.

entry.ety: LL. variolosus, fr. variola the smallpox: cf. F. varioleux
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the smallpox; having pits, or sunken impressions, like those of the smallpox; variolar; variolic.

entry.ety: L. varius various + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for comparing magnetic forces, esp. in the earth's magnetic field.

entry.ety: L., abbrev. fr. cum notis variorum with notes of various persons
entry.def: Containing notes by different persons; -- applied to a publication; as, a variorum edition of a book.

entry.ety: L. varius. Cf. Vair

sn.def: Different; diverse; several; manifold; as, men of various names; various occupations; various colors.
sn.q: So many and so various laws are given.
A wit as various, gay, grave, sage, or wild.

sn.def: Changeable; uncertain; inconstant; variable.
sn.q: A man so various, that he seemed to be Not one, but all mankind's epitome.
The names of mixed modes . . . are very various.

sn.def: Variegated; diversified; not monotonous.
sn.q: A happy rural seat of various view.

entry.def: In various or different ways.

entry.ety: So called from Variscia in Germany
entry.def: An apple-green mineral occurring in reniform masses. It is a hydrous phosphate of alumina.

entry.ety: Cf. F. varice varix. Cf. Varix
entry.def: An imperfection on the inside of the hind leg in horses, different from a curb, but at the same height, and often growing to an unsightly size.

entries.entry:
Va"rix Va"rix ☞ Varices are owing to local retardation of the venous circulation, and in some cases to relaxation of the parietes of the veins. They are very common in the superficial veins of the lower limbs. ☞ The varices usually indicate stages of growth, each one showing a former position of the outer lip of the aperture. vā"rĭks n.; pl.Varices văr"ĭ*sēz. L
Med A uneven, permanent dilatation of a vein.
Zoöl One of the prominent ridges or ribs extending across each of the whorls of certain univalve shells.

entry.ety: D. varken a pig
entry.def: The bush hog, or boshvark.

entry.ety: OF. varlet vaslet vallet, servant, young man, young noble, dim. of vassal. See Vassal, and cf. Valet

sn.def: A servant, especially to a knight; an attendant; a valet; a footman.
Hence, a low fellow; a scoundrel; a rascal; as, an impudent varlet .
sn.q: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou !

sn.def: In a pack of playing cards, the court card now called the knave, or jack.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. valeterie the young unmarried nobles
entry.def: The rabble; the crowd; the mob.
entry.q: Shall they hoist me up, And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome.

entry.note: ☞ According to the sorts of solvents employed, the ordinary kinds of varnish are divided into three classes: spirit turpentine, and oil varnishes.

cs.cd: a tree or shrub from the juice or resin of which varnish is made, as some species of the genus Rhus, especially Rhus vernicifera of Japan. The black varnish of Burmah is obtained from the Melanorrhœa usitatissima, a tall East Indian tree of the Cashew family. See Copal, and Mastic.

entry.ety: OE. vernish, F. vernis, LL. vernicium; akin to F. vernir to varnish, fr. (assumed) LL. vitrinire to glaze, from LL. vitrinus glassy, fr. L. vitrum glass. See Vitreous

sn.def: A viscid liquid, consisting of a solution of resinous matter in an oil or a volatile liquid, laid on work with a brush, or otherwise. When applied the varnish soon dries, either by evaporation or chemical action, and the resinous part forms thus a smooth, hard surface, with a beautiful gloss, capable of resisting, to a greater or less degree, the influences of air and moisture.
That which resembles varnish, either naturally or artificially; a glossy appearance.
sn.q: The varnish of the holly and ivy.

sn.def: An artificial covering to give a fair appearance to any act or conduct; outside show; gloss.
sn.q: And set a double varnish on the fame The Frenchman gave you.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Varnished; p. pr. & vb. n. Varnishing
entry.ety: Cf. F. vernir vernisser. See Varnish n.

sn.def: To lay varnish on; to cover with a liquid which produces, when dry, a hard, glossy surface; as, to varnish a table; to varnish a painting.
To cover or conceal with something that gives a fair appearance; to give a fair coloring to by words; to gloss over; to palliate; as, to varnish guilt.
sn.q: Beauty dothvarnishage.
Close ambition, varnished o'er with zeal.
Cato's voice was ne'er employed To clear the guilty and to varnish crimes.

sn.def: One who varnishes; one whose occupation is to varnish.
One who disguises or palliates; one who gives a fair external appearance.

entry.def: The act of laying on varnish; also, materials for varnish.

sn.def: Colloquial contraction of University.

the team with the best players of a school or club, being the main representative of the organization in competitive play between schools or organizations. In schools, contrasted with junior varsity. Also used attributively, as, the varsity football team.

entry.ety: F., prop. fem. of varsovien pertaining to Warsaw, fr. Varsovie Warsaw, Pol. Warszawa
entry.def: A kind of Polish dance.
Music for such a dance or having its slow triple time characteristic strong accent beginning every second measure.

entry.ety: Armen., a doctor, master, preceptor
entry.def: A doctor or teacher in the Armenian church. Members of this order of ecclesiastics frequently have charge of dioceses, with episcopal functions.

entry.ety: Skr. Varuṇa
entry.def: The god of the waters; the Indian Neptune. He is regarded as regent of the west, and lord of punishment, and is represented as riding on a sea monster, holding in his hand a snaky cord or noose with which to bind offenders, under water.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L., bent, grown inwards
entry.def: A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes.

entry.ety: F. vervelle
entry.def: In falconry, one of the rings secured to the ends of the jesses.

entry.note: ☞ In heraldry, when the jesses attached to the legs of hawks hang loose, or have pendent ends with rings at the tips, the blazon is a hawk or a hawk's leg jessed and varveled.
entry.def: Having varvels, or rings.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Varied; p. pr. & vb. n. Varying
entry.ety: OE. varien, F. varier, L. variare, fr. varius various. See Various, and cf. Variate

sn.def: To change the aspect of; to alter in form, appearance, substance, position, or the like; to make different by a partial change; to modify; as, to vary the properties, proportions, or nature of a thing; to vary a posture or an attitude; to vary one's dress or opinions.
sn.q: Shall we vary our device at will, Even as new occasion appears?

sn.def: To change to something else; to transmute; to exchange; to alternate.
sn.q: Gods, that never change their state,Vary oft their love and hate.
We are to vary the customs according to the time and country where the scene of action lies.

sn.def: To make of different kinds; to make different from one another; to diversify; to variegate.
sn.q: God hath varied their inclinations.
God hath hereVaried his bounty so with new delights.

sn.def: To embellish; to change fancifully; to present under new aspects, as of form, key, measure, etc. See Variation, 4.
To alter, or be altered, in any manner; to suffer a partial change; to become different; to be modified; as, colors vary in different lights.
sn.q: That each from other differs, first confess; Next, that he varies from himself no less.

sn.def: To differ, or be different; to be unlike or diverse; as, the laws of France vary from those of England.
To alter or change in succession; to alternate; as, one mathematical quantity varies inversely as another.
sn.q: While fear and anger, with alternate grace, Pant in her breast, and vary in her face.

sn.def: To deviate; to depart; to swerve; -- followed by from; as, to vary from the law, or from reason.
To disagree; to be at variance or in dissension; as, men vary in opinion.
sn.q: The rich jewel which we vary for.

entry.def: Alteration; change.

cs.cd: any hare or rabbit which becomes white in winter, especially the common hare of the Northern United States and Canada.

entry.def: a. & n. from Vary.

entries.entry:
Vas Vas
‖Vas deferens; pl.Vasa deferentia. L. vas vessel + deferens carrying down Anat The excretory duct of a testicle; a spermatic duct.
n.; pl.Vasa #. L., a vessel. See Vase
Anat A vessel; a duct.

cs.cd: plants composed in part of vascular tissue, as all flowering plants and the higher cryptogamous plants, or those of the class Pteridophyta. Cf. Cellular plants, under Cellular.
the body of associated ducts and woody fiber; the fibrovascular part of plants.
vegetable tissue composed partly of ducts, or sap tubes.

a system of vessels in annelids, nemerteans, and many other invertebrates, containing a circulating fluid analogous to blood, but not of the same composition. In annelids the fluid which they contain is usually red, but in some it is green, in others yellow, or whitish.

entry.ety: L. vasculum a small vessel, dim. of vas vessel: cf. F. vasculaire. See Vase, and cf. Vessel

sd.def: Consisting of, or containing, vessels as an essential part of a structure; full of vessels; specifically Bot, pertaining to, or containing, special ducts, or tubes, for the circulation of sap.
Operating by means of, or made up of an arrangement of, vessels; as, the vascular system in animals, including the arteries, veins, capillaries, lacteals, etc.
Of or pertaining to the vessels of animal and vegetable bodies; as, the vascular functions.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the higher division of plants, that is, the phænogamous plants, all of which are vascular, in distinction from the cryptogams, which to a large extent are cellular only.

entries.entry: Vas`cu*lar"i*ty văs`k�*lăr"ĭ*t� n.; pl.Vascularities văs`k�*lăr"ĭ*tĭz. Biol The quality or state of being vascular.

entry.def: The process of becoming vascular, or the condition of being vascular; as, the vascularization of cartilege.
One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed, differing from cellulose in respect to its solubility in certain media.

entries.entry:
Vas"cu*lum Vas"cu*lum n.; pl.Vascula #. L., a small vessel
Bot Same as Ascidium n., 1.
A tin box, commonly cylindrical or flattened, used in collecting plants.

entry.note: ☞ Until the time of Walker (1791), vase was made to rhyme with base case, etc., and it is still commonly so pronounced in the United States. Walker made it to rhyme with phrase maze, etc. Of modern English practice, Mr. A. J. Ellis1874) says: “Vase has four pronunciations in English: v�z, which I most commonly say, is going out of use, väz I hear most frequently, vāz very rarely, and vās I only know from Cull's marking. On the analogy of case, however, it should be the regular sound.” The Merriam-Webster's 10th Colletgiate Dictionary says: “U. S. oftenest vās; Canada usu. and U. S. also vāz; Canada also & U. S. sometimes väz.” One wit has noted that “a väz is a vāz that costs more than $100.”, suggesting that the former is considered a higher-class pronunciation.
entry.ety: F. vase; cf. Sp. & It. vaso; fr. L. vas vasum. Cf. Vascular Vessel

sn.def: A vessel adapted for various domestic purposes, and anciently for sacrificial uses; especially, a vessel of antique or elegant pattern used for ornament; as, a porcelain vase; a gold vase; a Grecian vase. See Illust. of Portland vase, under Portland.
sn.q: No chargers then were wrought in burnished gold, Nor silver vases took the forming mold.

sd.def: A vessel similar to that described in the first definition above, or the representation of one in a solid block of stone, or the like, used for an ornament, as on a terrace or in a garden. See Illust. of Niche.
The body, or naked ground, of the Corinthian and Composite capital; -- called also tambour, and drum.

sn.def: The calyx of a plant.

entries.entry: Vase clock. Art A clock whose decorative case has the general form of a vase, esp. one in which there is no ordinary dial, but in which a part of a vase revolves while a single stationary indicator serves as a hand.

entry.ety: Vas + -ecmoty
entry.def: Resection or excision of the vas deferens.

entry.ety: Said by the manufacturer to be derived from G. wasser water + Gr. 'e`laion olive oil
entry.def: A yellowish translucent substance, almost odorless and tasteless, obtained as a residue in the purification of crude petroleum, and consisting essentially of a mixture of several of the higher members of the paraffin series. It is used as an unguent, and for various purposes in the arts. See the Note under Petrolatum.
Formed like a vase, or like a common flowerpot.

cs.cd: tissue containing vessels, or ducts.

entry.ety: L. vas a vessel + -form
entry.def: Having the form of a vessel, or duct.
Causing constriction of the blood vessels; as, the vasoconstrictor nerves, stimulation of which causes constriction of the blood vessels to which they go. These nerves are also called vasohypertonic.
A substance which causes constriction of the blood vessels. Such substances are used in medicine to raise abnormally low blood pressure.

entry.ety: L. vas a vessel + E. dentine
entry.def: A modified form of dentine, which is permeated by blood capillaries; vascular dentine.

entry.ety: L. vas a vessel + dilator
entry.def: Causing dilation or relaxation of the blood vessels; as, the vasodilator nerves, stimulation of which causes dilation of the blood vessels to which they go. These nerves are also called vaso-inhibitory, and vasohypotonic nerves, since their stimulation causes relaxation and rest.

entry.ety: L. vas a vessel + dilator
entry.def: A substance which causes dilation of blood vessels.

entry.ety: L. vas a vessel + formative
entry.def: Concerned in the development and formation of blood vessels and blood corpuscles; as, the vasoformative cells.

entry.ety: See Hyper-, and Tonic
entry.def: See Vasoconstrictor.

entry.ety: See Hypo-, and Tonic
entry.def: See Vasodilator.
See Vasodilator.

cs.cd: the chief dominating or general center which supplies all the unstriped muscles of the arterial system with motor nerves, situated in a part of the medulla oblongata; a center of reflex action by the working of which afferent impulses are changed into efferent, -- vasomotor impulses leading either to dilation or constriction of the blood vessels.

entry.ety: L. vas a vessel + motor that which moves fr. movere to move
entry.def: Causing movement in the walls of vessels; as, the vasomotor mechanisms; the vasomotor nerves, a system of nerves distributed over the muscular coats of the blood vessels.

cs.cd: the vassal of a vassal; an arriere vassal.

entry.ety: F., fr. LL. vassallus vassus; of Celtic origin; cf. W. & Corn. gwas a youth, page, servant, Arm. gwaz a man, a male. Cf. Valet Varlet Vavasor

sn.def: The grantee of a fief, feud, or fee; one who holds land of a superior, and who vows fidelity and homage to him; a feudatory; a feudal tenant.
A subject; a dependent; a servant; a bondman; a slave.
sn.q: Thevassalsof his anger.

entry.def: Resembling a vassal; slavish; servile.
entry.q: The sun and every vassal star.

entry.def: To treat as a vassal; to subject to control; to enslave.

entry.ety: OE. vassalage, F. vasselage, LL. vassallaticum

sn.def: The state of being a vassal, or feudatory.
Political servitude; dependence; subjection; slavery; as, the Greeks were held in vassalage by the Turks.
A territory held in vassalage.
sn.q: The Countship of Foix, with six territorialvassalages.

sn.def: Vassals, collectively; vassalry.
Valorous service, such as that performed by a vassal; valor; prowess; courage.

entry.def: A female vassal.
The body of vassals.

entry.ety: L. vastus empty, waste, enormous, immense: cf. F. vaste. See Waste, and cf. Devastate

sn.def: Waste; desert; desolate; lonely.
sn.q: The empty, vast, and wandering air.

sn.def: Of great extent; very spacious or large; also, huge in bulk; immense; enormous; as, the vast ocean; vast mountains; the vast empire of Russia.
sn.q: Through the vast and boundless deep.

sn.def: Very great in numbers, quantity, or amount; as, a vast army; a vast sum of money.
Very great in force; mighty; as, vast labor.
Very great in importance; as, a subject of vast concern.
sn.syn: Enormous; huge; immense; mighty.

entry.def: A waste region; boundless space; immensity.
entry.q: The wateryvast.
Michael bid sound The archangel trumpet. Through the vast of heaven It sounded.

entry.ety: L. vastatio, fr. vastare to lay waste, fr. vastus empty, waste
entry.def: A laying waste; waste; depopulation; devastation.
See Wastel.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. vastité, L. vastitas
entry.def: Vastness; immensity.
entry.q: All the world'svastidity.

entry.ety: L. vastitudo

sn.def: Vastness; immense extent.
Destruction; vastation.

entry.ety: L. vastitas
entry.def: Vastness.
entry.q: The huge vastity of the world.

entry.def: To a vast extent or degree; very greatly; immensely.
The quality or state of being vast.

entry.ety: From Vast
entry.def: Vast; immense.
entry.q: I can call spirits from the vasty deep.

entry.ety: L., a vase. See Vase
entry.def: A genus including several species of large marine gastropods having massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on the columella.

entry.note: ☞ The old Dutch grain vat averaged 0.762 Winchester bushel. The old London coal vat contained 9 bushels. The solid-measurement vat of Amsterdam contains 40 cubic feet; the wine vat, 241.57 imperial gallons, and the vat for olive oil, 225.45 imperial gallons.
entry.ety: A dialectic form for fat, OE. fat, AS. fæt; akin to D. vat, OS. fat, G. fass, OHG. faz, Icel. & Sw. fat, Dan. fad, Lith. půdas a pot, and probably to G. fassen to seize, to contain, OHG. fazzōn, D. vatten. Cf. Fat a vat

sn.def: A large vessel, cistern, or tub, especially one used for holding liquors in an immature state, chemical preparations for dyeing, or for tanning, or for tanning leather, or the like.
sn.q: Let him produce his vats and tubs, in opposition to heaps of arms and standards.

sn.def: A measure for liquids, and also a dry measure; especially, a liquid measure in Belgium and Holland, corresponding to the hectoliter of the metric system, which contains 22.01 imperial gallons, or 26.4 standard gallons in the United States.

sd.def: A wooden tub for washing ores and mineral substances in.
A square, hollow place on the back of a calcining furnace, where tin ore is laid to dry.

sn.def: A vessel for holding holy water.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vatted; p. pr. & vb. n. Vatting
entry.def: To put or transfer into a vat.

entries.entry: Vat"ful n.; pl.Vatfuls. As much as a vat will hold; enough to fill a vat.

entry.ety: L. vates a prophet
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a prophet; prophetical.

entry.note: ☞ The word is often used to indicate the papal authority.

cs.cd: the anathemas, or denunciations, of the pope.

entry.ety: L. Vaticanus mons, or collis Vaticanus, the Vatican hill, in Rome, on the western bank of the Tiber: cf. F. Vatican, It. Vaticano
entry.def: A magnificent assemblage of buildings at Rome, near the church of St. Peter, including the pope's palace, a museum, a library, a famous chapel, etc.

entries.entry: Vat"i*can Coun"cil. R. C. Ch The council held under Pope Pius IX. in Vatican at Rome, in 1870, which promulgated the dogma of papal infallibility.

entry.def: The doctrine of papal supremacy; extreme views in support of the authority of the pope; ultramontanism; -- a term used only by persons who are not Roman Catholics.
One who strongly adheres to the papal authority; an ultramontanist.

entry.ety: L. vates a prophet + caedere to kill
entry.def: The murder, or the murderer, of a prophet.
entry.q: The caitiffvaticide.

entry.ety: See Vaticinate
entry.def: Of or pertaining to prophecy; prophetic.

entry.ety: L. vaticinatus, p. p. of vaticinari to prophesy, fr. vaticinus prophetical, fr. vates a prophet
entry.def: To prophesy; to foretell; to practice prediction; to utter prophecies.

entry.ety: L. vaticinatio
entry.def: Prediction; prophecy.
entry.q: It is not a false utterance; it is a true, though an impetuous, vaticination.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who vaticinates; a prophet.

entry.ety: L. vaticinium
entry.def: A prediction; a vaticination.

entry.ety: F., fr. Vau-de-vire, a village in Normandy, where Olivier Basselin, at the end of the 14th century, composed such songs

sn.def: A kind of song of a lively character, frequently embodying a satire on some person or event, sung to a familiar air in couplets with a refrain; a street song; a topical song.
A theatrical piece, usually a comedy, the dialogue of which is intermingled with light or satirical songs, set to familiar airs.
sn.q: The early vaudeville, which is the forerunner of the opera bouffe, was light, graceful, and piquant.

sn.def: a variety show when performed live in a theater (see above); as, to play in vaudeville; a vaudeville actor.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: An inhabitant, or the inhabitants, of the Swiss canton of Vaud.
A modern name of the Waldenses.

entry.def: See Voodoo.

entry.note: ☞ The l in this word was formerly often suppressed in pronunciation.
entry.cs:
Barrel vault Cradle vault Cylindrical vaultorWagon vault
Arch a kind of vault having two parallel abutments, and the same section or profile at all points. It may be rampant, as over a staircase (see Rampant vault, under Rampant), or curved in plan, as around the apse of a church. Coved vault. Arch See under 1st Cove v. t.
Groined vault Arch a vault having groins, that is, one in which different cylindrical surfaces intersect one another, as distinguished from a barrel, or wagon vault. Rampant vault. Arch See under Rampant. Ribbed vault Arch a vault differing from others in having solid ribs which bear the weight of the vaulted surface. True Gothic vaults are of this character. Vault light a partly glazed plate inserted in a pavement or ceiling to admit light to a vault below.
entry.ety: OE. voute, OF. voute volte, F. voûte, LL. volta, for voluta volutio, fr. L. volvere volutum, to roll, to turn about. See Voluble, and cf. Vault a leap, Volt a turn, Volute

sn.def: An arched structure of masonry, forming a ceiling or canopy.
sn.q: The long-drawn aisle and fretted vault.

sn.def: An arched apartment; especially, a subterranean room, used for storing articles, for a prison, for interment, or the like; a cell; a cellar.
sn.q: Charnelvaults.
The silent vaults of death.
To banish rats that haunt our vault.

sn.def: The canopy of heaven; the sky.
sn.q: That heaven's vault should crack.

entry.sn:
F. volte, It. volta, originally, a turn, and the same word as volta an arch. See the Etymology above A leap or bound. Specifically: Man The bound or leap of a horse; a curvet.
A leap by aid of the hands, or of a pole, springboard, or the like.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vaulted; p. pr. & vb. n. Vaulting
entry.ety: OE. vouten, OF. volter vouter, F. voûter. See Vault an arch

sn.def: To form with a vault, or to cover with a vault; to give the shape of an arch to; to arch; as, to vault a roof; to vault a passage to a court.
sn.q: The shady arch that vaulted the broad green alley.

sn.def: To leap over; esp., to leap over by aid of the hands or a pole; as, to vault a fence.
sn.q: I will vault credit, and affect high pleasures.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. volter, F. voltiger, It. voltare to turn. See Vault n., 4

sn.def: To leap; to bound; to jump; to spring.
sn.q: Vaulting ambition, which o'erleaps itself.
Leaning on his lance, he vaulted on a tree.
Lucan vaulted upon Pegasus with all the heat and intrepidity of youth.

sn.def: To exhibit feats of tumbling or leaping; to tumble.

entry.def: Vaulted work; also, a vaulted place; an arched cellar.

sn.def: Arched; concave; as, a vaulted roof.
Covered with an arch, or vault.
Arched like the roof of the mouth, as the upper lip of many ringent flowers.

entry.def: One who vaults; a leaper; a tumbler.

sn.def: The act of constructing vaults; a vaulted construction.
Act of one who vaults or leaps.

entry.def: Arched; concave.

entry.ety: See Advance
entry.def: To advance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vaunted; p. pr. & vb. n. Vaunting
entry.ety: F. vanter, LL. vanitare, fr. L. vanus vain. See Vain
entry.def: To boast; to make a vain display of one's own worth, attainments, decorations, or the like; to talk ostentatiously; to brag.
entry.q: Pride, which prompts a man to vaunt and overvalue what he is, does incline him to disvalue what he has.

entry.def: To boast of; to make a vain display of; to display with ostentation. In the latter sense, the term usually used is flaunt.
entry.q: Charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up.
My vanquisher, spoiled of his vaunted spoil.

entry.def: A vain display of what one is, or has, or has done; ostentation from vanity; a boast; a brag.
entry.q: The spirits beneath, whom I seduced With other promises and other vaunts.

entry.ety: F. avant before, fore. See Avant Vanguard
entry.def: The first part.

entry.ety: See Avant Advance
entry.def: To put forward; to display.
entry.q: Vauntedspear.
And what so else his person most may vaunt.

entry.def: See Van-courier.
One who vaunts; a boaster.
Given to vaunting or boasting; vainly ostentatious; boastful; vainglorious.
In a vaunting manner.

entry.ety: F. avant-mur. See Vanguard, and Mure

entry.ety: So called after the French chemist Vauquelin, who died in 1829: cf. F. vauquelinite
entry.def: Chromate of copper and lead, of various shades of green.

entry.def: The vassal or tenant of a baron; one who held under a baron, and who also had tenants under him; one in dignity next to a baron; a title of dignity next to a baron.

entry.def: The quality or tenure of the fee held by a vavasor; also, the lands held by a vavasor.

entry.ety: For vanward, equivalent to vanguard. See Vanguard Ward guard

entries.entry: Va"za par`rot. Zoöl Any one of several species of parrots of the genus Coracopsis, native of Madagascar; -- called also vasa parrot.

entry.def: a videocasette recorder.
The thirteenth, or intercalary, month of the Jewish ecclesiastical calendar, which is added about every third year.

entry.ety: OE. veel, OF. veel, F. veau, L. vitellus, dim. of vitulus a calf; akin to E. wether. See Wether, and cf. Vellum Vituline
entry.def: The flesh of a calf when killed and used for food.

entry.ety: L. vectio, from vehere vectum, to carry
entry.def: Vectitation.

entry.ety: L. vectitatus borne about, fr. vectare, v. intens. fr. vehere vectum, to carry
entry.def: The act of carrying, or state of being carried.

entry.note: ☞ In a triangle, either side is the vector sum of the other two sides taken in proper order; the process finding the vector sum of two or more vectors is vector additionsee under Addition).
entry.ety: L., a bearer, carrier. fr. vehere vectum, to carry

sn.def: Same as Radius vector.
A directed quantity, as a straight line, a force, or a velocity. Vectors are said to be equal when their directions are the same and their magnitudes equal. Cf. Scalar.

entry.ety: L. vectura, from vehere vectum, to carry. Cf. Vettura Voiture
entry.def: The act of carrying; conveyance; carriage.

entry.note: ☞ The language of the Vedas is usually called Vedic Sanskrit, as distinguished from the later and more settled form called classical Sanskrit.
entry.ety: Skr. vēda, properly, knowledge, from vid to know. See Wit
entry.def: The ancient sacred literature of the Hindus; also, one of the four collections, called Rig-Veda Yajur-Veda Sama-Veda, and Atharva-Veda, constituting the most ancient portions of that literature.

entry.ety: Skr. Vēdanta
entry.def: A system of philosophy among the Hindus, founded on scattered texts of the Vedas, and thence termed the “Anta,” or end or substance.
Of or pertaining to the Vedas.
One versed in the doctrines of the Vedantas.

entries.entry:
Ved"dahs vĕd"dȧz n. pl.EthnolA primitive people of Ceylon.
Weddars

entry.ety: F. vedette, It. vedetta, for velettainfluenced by vedere to see, L. videre), from It. veglia watch, L. vigilia. See Vigil
entry.def: A sentinel, usually on horseback, stationed on the outpost of an army, to watch an enemy and give notice of danger; a vidette.
Of or pertaining to the Vedas or one of the Vedas.

entry.ety: Russ., pail
entry.def: A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U. S. standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons.

cs.cd: to vary the course or direction; -- said of the wind, which veers aft and hauls forward. The wind is also said to veer when it shifts with the sun.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Veered; p. pr. & vb. n. Veering
entry.ety: F. virercf. Sp. virar birar), LL. virare; perhaps fr. L. vibrare to brandish, vibrate (cf. Vibrate); or cf. L. viriae armlets, bracelets, viriola a little bracelet (cf. Ferrule). Cf. Environ
entry.def: To change direction; to turn; to shift; as, wind veers to the west or north.
entry.q: Hisveeringgait.
And as he leads, the following navy veers.
an ordinary community which is hostile or friendly as passion or as interest may veer about.

cs.cd: to pull tight and slacken alternately.
to let out; to slacken and let run; to pay out; as, to veer away the cable; to veer out a rope.

entry.def: To direct to a different course; to turn; to wear; as, to veer, or wear, a vessel.
Changeable; shifting; as, winds veerable to southwest.
Shifting.

An American thrush (Turdus fuscescens) common in the Northern United States and Canada. It is light tawny brown above. The breast is pale buff, thickly spotted with brown. Called also Wilson's thrush.
entry.q: Sometimes I hear the veery's clarion.

entry.ety: Ar. wāgi', properly, falling: cf. F. Wéga
entry.def: A brilliant star of the first magnitude, the brightest of those constituting the constellation Lyra.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: An open tract of ground; a plain, esp. one which is moist and fertile, as those used for tobacco fields.
A vegetarian who does not eat any animal products, not even fish, eggs, or milk.
The quality or state of being vegetable.

entry.cs: Vegetable alkali Chem an alkaloid. Vegetable brimstone. Bot See Vegetable sulphur, below. Vegetable butter Bot a name of several kinds of concrete vegetable oil; as that produced by the Indian butter tree, the African shea tree, and the Pentadesma butyracea, a tree of the order Guttiferæ, also African. Still another kind is pressed from the seeds of cocoa (Theobroma). Vegetable flannel a textile material, manufactured in Germany from pine-needle wool, a down or fiber obtained from the leaves of the Pinus sylvestris. Vegetable ivory. See Ivory nut, under Ivory. Vegetable jelly. See Pectin. Vegetable kingdom. Nat. Hist See the last Phrase, below. Vegetable leather. Bot A shrubby West Indian spurge (Euphorbia punicea), with leathery foliage and crimson bracts. See Vegetable leather, under Leather. Vegetable marrow Bot an egg-shaped gourd, commonly eight to ten inches long. It is noted for the very tender quality of its flesh, and is a favorite culinary vegetable in England. It has been said to be of Persian origin, but is now thought to have been derived from a form of the American pumpkin. Vegetable oyster Bot the oyster plant. See under Oyster. Vegetable parchment papyrine. Vegetable sheep Bot a white woolly plant (Raoulia eximia) of New Zealand, which grows in the form of large fleecy cushions on the mountains. Vegetable silk a cottonlike, fibrous material obtained from the coating of the seeds of a Brazilian tree (Chorisia speciosa). It is used for various purposes, as for stuffing cushions, and the like, but is incapable of being spun on account of a want of cohesion among the fibers. Vegetable sponge. See 1st Loof. Vegetable sulphur the fine and highly inflammable spores of the club moss (Lycopodium clavatum); witch meal. Vegetable tallow a substance resembling tallow, obtained from various plants; as, Chinese vegetable tallow, obtained from the seeds of the tallow tree. Indian vegetable tallow is a name sometimes given to piney tallow. Vegetable wax a waxy excretion on the leaves or fruits of certain plants, as the bayberry.

Vegetable kingdom Nat. Hist that primary division of living things which includes all plants. The classes of the vegetable kingdom have been grouped differently by various botanists. The following is one of the best of the many arrangements of the principal subdivisions.
I. Phænogamia called also Phanerogamia). Plants having distinct flowers and true seeds.1. Dicotyledonscalled also Exogens). -- Seeds with two or more cotyledons. Stems with the pith, woody fiber, and bark concentrically arranged. Divided into two subclasses: Angiosperms, having the woody fiber interspersed with dotted or annular ducts, and the seeds contained in a true ovary; Gymnosperms, having few or no ducts in the woody fiber, and the seeds naked. 2. Monocotyledonscalled also Endogens). -- Seeds with single cotyledon. Stems with slender bundles of woody fiber not concentrically arranged, and with no true bark.} II. Cryptogamia . Plants without true flowers, and reproduced by minute spores of various kinds, or by simple cell division.1. Acrogens. -- Plants usually with distinct stems and leaves, existing in two alternate conditions, one of which is nonsexual and sporophoric, the other sexual and oöphoric. Divided into Vascular Acrogens, or Pteridophyta, having the sporophoric plant conspicuous and consisting partly of vascular tissue, as in Ferns, Lycopods, and Equiseta, and Cellular Acrogens, or Bryophyta, having the sexual plant most conspicuous, but destitute of vascular tissue, as in Mosses and Scale Mosses. 2. Thallogens. -- Plants without distinct stem and leaves, consisting of a simple or branched mass of cellular tissue, or reduced to a single cell. Reproduction effected variously. Divided into Algæ, which contain chlorophyll or its equivalent, and which live upon air and water, and Fungi, which contain no chlorophyll, and live on organic matter. (Lichens are now believed to be fungi parasitic on included algæ
entry.note: ☞ Many botanists divide the Phænogamia primarily into Gymnosperms and Angiosperms, and the latter into Dicotyledons and Monocotyledons. Others consider Pteridophyta and Bryophyta to be separate classes. Thallogens are variously divided by different writers, and the places for diatoms, slime molds, and stoneworts are altogether uncertain. For definitions, see these names in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: F. végétable growing, capable of growing, formerly also, as a noun, a vegetable, from L. vegetabilis enlivening, from vegetare to enliven, invigorate, quicken, vegetus enlivened, vigorous, active, vegere to quicken, arouse, to be lively, akin to vigere to be lively, to thrive, vigil watchful, awake, and probably to E. wake, v. See Vigil Wake v.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to plants; having the nature of, or produced by, plants; as, a vegetable nature; vegetable growths, juices, etc.
sn.q: Blooming ambrosial fruit Of vegetable gold.

sn.def: Consisting of, or comprising, plants; as, the vegetable kingdom.

entry.note: ☞ Vegetables and fruits are sometimes loosely distinguished by the usual need of cooking the former for the use of man, while the latter may be eaten raw; but the distinction often fails, as in the case of quinces, barberries, and other fruits, and lettuce, celery, and other vegetables. Tomatoes if cooked are vegetables, if eaten raw are fruits.

sn.def: A plant. See Plant.
A plant used or cultivated for food for man or domestic animals, as the cabbage, turnip, potato, bean, dandelion, etc.; also, the edible part of such a plant, as prepared for market or the table.

A person who has permanently lost consciousness, due to damage to the brain, but remains alive; sometimes continued life requires support by machinery such as breathing tubes. Such a person is said to be in a vegetative state.

entry.ety: F. végétal. See Vegetable

sn.def: Of or pertaining to vegetables, or the vegetable kingdom; of the nature of a vegetable; vegetable.
sn.q: All creatures vegetal, sensible, and rational.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, that class of vital phenomena, such as digestion, absorption, assimilation, secretion, excretion, circulation, generation, etc., which are common to plants and animals, in distinction from sensation and volition, which are peculiar to animals.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A vegetable.

sn.def: The quality or state of being vegetal, or vegetable.
The quality or state of being vegetal, or exhibiting those physiological phenomena which are common to plants and animals. See Vegetal a., 2.

entry.def: One who holds that vegetables and fruits are the only proper food for man. Strict vegetarians eat no meat, eggs, or milk, and are sometimes referred tro as vegans.
Of or pertaining to vegetarianism; as, a vegetarian diet.
The theory or practice of living upon vegetables and fruits.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vegetated; p. pr. & vb. n. Vegetating
entry.ety: L. vegetatus, p. p. of vegetare to enliven. See Vegetable

sn.def: To grow, as plants, by nutriment imbibed by means of roots and leaves; to start into growth; to sprout; to germinate.
sn.q: See dying vegetables life sustain, See life dissolving vegetate again.

sn.def: Fig.: To lead a life too low for an animate creature; to do nothing but eat and grow.
sn.q: Persons who . . . would have vegetated stupidly in the places where fortune had fixed them.

sn.def: To grow exuberantly; to produce fleshy or warty outgrowths; as, a vegetating papule.

cs.cd: a crystalline growth of an arborescent form.

entry.ety: Cf. F. végétation, L. vegetatio an enlivening. See Vegetable

sn.def: The act or process of vegetating, or growing as a plant does; vegetable growth.
The sum of vegetable life; vegetables or plants in general; as, luxuriant vegetation .
An exuberant morbid outgrowth upon any part, especially upon the valves of the heart.

entry.ety: Cf. F. végétatif

sn.def: Growing, or having the power of growing, as plants; capable of vegetating.
Having the power to produce growth in plants; as, the vegetative properties of soil.
Having relation to growth or nutrition; partaking of simple growth and enlargement of the systems of nutrition, apart from the sensorial or distinctively animal functions; vegetal.

entry.ety: L. vegetus. See Vegetable
entry.def: Lively; active; sprightly; vigorous.
entry.q: Even her body was made airy and vegete.

entry.def: Vegetal state or characteristic.

entry.ety: See Vegetate, and Vegetative
entry.def: Having the nature of a plant; vegetable; as, vegetive life.
A vegetable.
entry.q: The blest infusions That dwell in vegetives, in metals, stones.

entry.def: Partaking of the nature both of vegetable and animal matter; -- a term sometimes applied to vegetable albumen and gluten, from their resemblance to similar animal products.

entry.ety: L. vegetus. See Vegete
entry.def: Vigorous; lively; active; vegete.

entry.ety: L. vehementia: cf. F. véhémence

sn.def: The quality or state of being vehement; impetuous force; impetuosity; violence; fury; as, the vehemence of the wind; to speak with vehemence .
Violent ardor; great heat; animated fervor; as, the vehemence of love, anger, or other passions.
sn.q: I . . . tremble at his vehemence of temper.

entry.def: Vehemence.
entry.q: The vehemency of your affection.

entry.ety: L. vehemens, the first part of which is perhaps akin to vehere to carry, and the second mens mind: cf. F. véhément. Cf. Vehicle, and Mental

sn.def: Acting with great force; furious; violent; impetuous; forcible; mighty; as, a vehement wind; a vehement torrent; a vehement fire or heat.

Vehementdesire.
sn.syn: Furious; violent; raging; impetuous; passionate; ardent; eager; hot; fervid; burning.

entry.def: In a vehement manner.

entry.note: ☞ Water is used in fresco and in water-color painting, the colors being consolidated with gum arabic; size is used in distemper painting. In oil painting, the fixed oils of linseed, nut, and poppy, are used; in encaustic, wax is the vehicle.
entry.ety: L. vehiculum, fr. vehere to carry; akin to E. way wain. See Way n., and cf. Convex Inveigh Veil Vex

sn.def: That in or on which any person or thing is, or may be, carried, as a coach, carriage, wagon, cart, car, sleigh, bicycle, etc.; a means of conveyance; specifically, a means of conveyance upon land.
That which is used as the instrument of conveyance or communication; as, matter is the vehicle of energy.

sn.def: A substance in which medicine is taken.
Any liquid with which a pigment is applied, including whatever gum, wax, or glutinous or adhesive substance is combined with it.

Vehicular.

Vehicular.

entry.ety: G. vehm fehm fehme, a secret tribunal of punishment, MHG. veime veme: cf. F. vehmique

cs.cd: to receive or be covered with, a veil, as a nun, in token of retirement from the world; to become a nun.

She, as a veil down to the slender waist, Her unadornéd golden tresses wore.

sn.def: A cover; a disguise; a mask; a pretense.
sn.q: I will] pluck the borrowed veil of modesty from the so seeming Mistress Page.

sd.def: The calyptra of mosses.

sn.def: A covering for a person or thing; as, a nun's veil; a paten veil; an altar veil.
Same as Velum, 3.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Veiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Veiling

sn.def: To throw a veil over; to cover with a veil.

sn.def: One of the vessels which carry blood, either venous or arterial, to the heart. See Artery, 2.

One of the ribs or nervures of the wings of insects. See Venation.

A narrow mass of rock intersecting other rocks, and filling inclined or vertical fissures not corresponding with the stratification; a lode; a dike; -- often limited, in the language of miners, to a mineral vein or lode, that is, to a vein which contains useful minerals or ores.
A fissure, cleft, or cavity, as in the earth or other substance.
sn.q: Down to theveinsof earth.
Let the glass of the prisms be free from veins.

sn.def: A streak or wave of different color, appearing in wood, and in marble and other stones; variegation.
A train of associations, thoughts, emotions, or the like; a current; a course; as, reasoning in the same vein .
sn.q: He can open a vein of true and noble thinking.

sn.def: Peculiar temper or temperament; tendency or turn of mind; a particular disposition or cast of genius; humor; strain; quality; also, manner of speech or action; as, a rich vein of humor; a satirical vein .
sn.q: Certain discoursing wits which are of the same veins.
Invoke the Muses, and improve my vein.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Veined; p. pr. & vb. n. Veining

Pertaining to veins; venous.

sn.def: Full of veins; streaked; variegated; as, veined marble.
sn.q: Veinedfollies.

sn.def: Having fibrovascular threads extending throughout the lamina; as, a veined leaf.

entry.def: Having no veins; as, a veinless leaf.
A small vein.
Marked with veins; veined; veiny.
entry.q: The excellent old gentleman's nails are long and leaden, and his hands lean and veinous.

entries.entry: Vein quartz. Quartz occurring as gangue in a vein.

entry.def: The valueless nonmetalliferous mineral or rock material which surrounds the ores in a vein, as quartz, calcite, barite, fluor spar, etc.; gangue; matrix; -- called also veinstuff.

entry.ety: From Vein: cf. F. veiné
entry.def: Full of veins; veinous; veined; as, veiny marble.

Having the place of articulation on the soft palate; guttural; as, the velar consonants, such as k and hard g.

entries.entry: Ve*la"ri*um Ve*la"ri*um n.; pl.Velaria #. L., a covering Zoöl The marginal membrane of certain medusæ belonging to the Discophora.

entry.def: Having a veil; veiled.

entry.ety: D. veld. Cf. Field n.

entries.entry: Veldt sore. Med An infective sore mostly on the hands and feet, often contracted in walking on the veldt and apparently due to a specific microörganism.

entry.note: ☞ These creatures are brilliantly colored and float at the surface of the sea. They have an oblong, disklike body, supported by a thin chitinous plate, from which rises a thin diagonal crest which acts as a sail. The feeding and reproductive zooids hang down from the under side of the disk.

entry.ety: Cf. Vell n.
entry.def: To cut the turf from, as for burning.

entry.ety: F. velléitécf. It. velleità), fr. L. velle to will, to be willing

entry.def: To twitch; to cause to twitch convulsively.
entry.q: Convulsions, arising from something vellicating a nerve in its extremity, are not very dangerous.

entry.def: To move spasmodically; to twitch; as, a nerve vellicates .

entry.ety: L. vellicatio

sn.def: The act of twitching, or of causing to twitch.
A local twitching, or convulsive motion, of a muscular fiber, especially of the face.

entry.def: Having the power of vellicating, plucking, or twitching; causing vellication.

entry.ety: Sp

Resembling vellum.

entry.ety: L. velox -ocis, swift + pes pedis, a foot. See Velocity, and Foot
entry.def: A light road carriage propelled by the feet of the rider. Originally it was propelled by striking the tips of the toes on the roadway, but commonly now by the action of the feet on a pedal or pedals connected with the axle of one or more of the wheels, and causing their revolution. They are made in many forms, with two, three, or four wheels. See Bicycle, and Tricycle.
One who rides on a velocipede; a cyclist.

entries.entry:
Ve*loc"i*ty ☞ In such phrases, velocity is more generally used than celerity. We apply celerity to animals; as, a horse or an ostrich runs with celerity; but bodies moving in the air or in ethereal space move with greater or less velocity, not celerity. This usage is arbitrary, and perhaps not universal.
Angular velocity. See under Angular. Initial velocity the velocity of a moving body at starting; especially, the velocity of a projectile as it leaves the mouth of a firearm from which it is discharged. Relative velocity the velocity with which a body approaches or recedes from another body, whether both are moving or only one. Uniform velocity velocity in which the same number of units of space are described in each successive unit of time. Variable velocity velocity in which the space described varies from instant to instant, either increasing or decreasing; -- in the former case called accelerated velocity, in the latter, retarded velocity; the acceleration or retardation itself being also either uniform or variable. Virtual velocity. See under Virtual.
☞ In variable velocity, the velocity, strictly, at any given instant, is the rate of motion at that instant, and is expressed by the units of space, which, if the velocity at that instant were continued uniform during a unit of time, would be described in the unit of time; thus, the velocity of a falling body at a given instant is the number of feet which, if the motion which the body has at that instant were continued uniformly for one second, it would pass through in the second. The scientific sense of velocity differs from the popular sense in being applied to all rates of motion, however slow, while the latter implies more or less rapidity or quickness of motion. n.; pl.Velocities #. L. velocitas, from velox -ocis, swift, quick; perhaps akin to volare to fly (see Volatile): cf. F. vélocité
Quickness of motion; swiftness; speed; celerity; rapidity; as, the velocity of wind; the velocity of a planet or comet in its orbit or course; the velocity of a cannon ball; the velocity of light.
Mech Rate of motion; the relation of motion to time, measured by the number of units of space passed over by a moving body or point in a unit of time, usually the number of feet passed over in a second. See the Note under Speed. Swiftness; celerity; rapidity; fleetness; speed.

entry.ety: F. See Velure
entry.def: One of many textile fabrics having a pile like that of velvet.

entries.entry: ‖Ve*lou`té" n.orSauce velouté . F. velouté, lit., velvety Cookery A white sauce or stock made by boiling down ham, veal, beef, fowl, bouillon, etc., then adding soup stock, seasoning, vegetables, and thickening, and again boiling and straining.

entry.ety: See Fieldfare
entry.def: The fieldfare.

entries.entry:
Ve"lum Ve"lum n.; pl.Vela #. L., an awning, a veil. See Veil
Anat A curtain or covering; -- applied to various membranous partitions, especially to the soft palate. See under Palate.
Bot
See Veil n., 3 .
A thin membrane surrounding the sporocarps of quillworts Isoetes).
Zoöl A veil-like organ or part. Especially: The circular membrane that partially incloses the space beneath the umbrella of hydroid medusæ.
A delicate funnel-like membrane around the flagellum of certain Infusoria. See Illust.a of Protozoa.

entry.ety: F. velours, OF. velous, from L. villosus hairy. See Velvet

sn.def: Velvet.
sn.q: A woman's crupper ofvelure.

sn.def: A substance resembling velvet.

entry.ety: NL. See Velvet
entry.def: Any one of several species of marine gastropods belonging to Velutina and allied genera.

entry.ety: It. velluto velvet. See Velvet
entry.def: Having the surface covered with a fine and dense silky pubescence; velvety; as, a velutinous leaf.
The veltfare.
A kind of velvet having cotton back.

entry.cs: Cotton velvet an imitation of velvet, made of cotton. Velvet cork the best kind of cork bark, supple, elastic, and not woody or porous. Velvet crab Zoöl a European crab (Portunus puber). When adult the black carapace is covered with a velvety pile. Called also lady crab, and velvet fiddler. Velvet dock Bot the common mullein. Velvet duck. Zoöl A large European sea duck, or scoter (Oidemia fusca). The adult male is glossy, velvety black, with a white speculum on each wing, and a white patch behind each eye. The American whitewinged scoter. See Scoter. Velvet flower Bot love-lies-bleeding. See under Love. Velvet grass Bot a tall grass (Holcus lanatus) with velvety stem and leaves; -- called also soft grass. Velvet runner Zoöl the water rail; -- so called from its quiet, stealthy manner of running. Prov. Eng Velvet scoter. Zoöl Same as Velvet duck, above. Velvet sponge. Zoöl See under Sponge. in velvet having a coating of velvet{2} over the antlers; in the annual stage where the antlers are still growing; -- of deer.
entry.ety: OE. velouette veluet velwet; cf. OF. velluau, LL. velluetum vellutum, It. velluto, Sp. velludo; all fr. (assumed) LL. villutus shaggy, fr L. villus shaggy hair; akin to vellus a fleece, and E. wool. See Wool, and cf. Villous

sn.def: A silk fabric, having a short, close nap of erect threads. Inferior qualities are made with a silk pile on a cotton or linen back, or with other soft fibers such as nylon, acetate, or rayon.
The soft and highly vascular deciduous skin which envelops and nourishes the antlers of deer during their rapid growth.
Something likened to velvet{1} in being soft or luxurious; as, a lawn of velvet .

entry.def: Made of velvet; soft and delicate, like velvet; velvety.
entry.q: The cowslip'svelvethead.

entry.def: To pain velvet.
To make like, or cover with, velvet.
The goosander.

entry.ety: Cf. F. velvantine. See Velvet
entry.def: A kind of cloth, usually cotton, made in imitation of velvet; cotton velvet.
The fine shag or nap of velvet; a piece of velvet; velvet goods.
A name given to several plants which have soft, velvety leaves, as the Abutilon Avicennæ, the Cissampelos Pareira, and the Lavatera arborea, and even the common mullein.
Made of velvet, or like velvet; soft; smooth; delicate.

entries.entry:
Ve"na Ve"na
Vena cava; pl.Venæ cavæ. L., literally, hollow vein Anat Any one of the great systemic veins connected directly with the heart. Vena contracta. L., literally, contracted vein Hydraulics The contracted portion of a liquid jet at and near the orifice from which it issues. Vena portæ; pl.VenÆ portæ. L., literally, vein of the entrance Anat The portal vein of the liver. See under Portal.
n.; pl.Venæ #. L. See Vein
A vein.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. venado a deer, stag
entry.def: The pudu.

entry.ety: L. vena a vein
entry.def: Of or pertaining to veins; venous; as, venal blood.

entry.usage: Venal Mercenary. One is mercenary who is either actually a hireling (as, mercenary soldiers, a mercenary judge, etc.), or is governed by a sordid love of gain; hence, we speak of mercenary motives, a mercenary marriage, etc. Venal goes further, and supposes either an actual purchase, or a readiness to be purchased, which places a person or thing wholly in the power of the purchaser; as, a venal press. Brissot played ingeniously on the latter word in his celebrated saying, “ My pen is venal that it may not be mercenary,” meaning that he wrote books, and sold them to the publishers, in order to avoid the necessity of being the hireling of any political party.
entry.ety: L. venalis, from venus sale; akin to Gr. 'w^nos price, Skr. vasna: cf. F. vénal
entry.def: Capable of being bought or obtained for money or other valuable consideration; made matter of trade or barter; held for sale; salable; mercenary; purchasable; hireling; as, venal services.
entry.q: Paid court tovenalbeauties.
The venal cry and prepared vote of a passive senate.
Thus needy wits a vile revenue made, And verse became a mercenary trade.
This verse be thine, my friend, nor thou refuse This, from no venal or ungrateful muse.

entry.ety: L. venalitas: cf. F. vénalité
entry.def: The quality or state of being venal, or purchasable; mercenariness; prostitution of talents, offices, or services, for money or reward; as, the venality of a corrupt court; the venality of an official.
entry.q: Complaints of Roman venality became louder.

entry.def: In a venal manner.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. venans, p. pr. of venari to hunt
entry.def: The hunting spiders, which run after, or leap upon, their prey.

entry.ety: LL. venarius, fr. L. venari, p. p. venatus, to hunt
entry.def: Of or, pertaining to hunting.

entry.ety: L. venaticus, fr. venatus hunting, fr. venari, p. p. venatus, to hunt
entry.def: Of or pertaining to hunting; used in hunting.
entry.q: Venaticalpleasure.

entry.def: See Vinatico.

entry.ety: L. vena a vein
entry.def: The arrangement or system of veins, as in the wing of an insect, or in the leaves of a plant. See Illust. in Appendix.

entry.ety: L. venatio, fr. venari, p. p. venatus, to hunt. See Venison
entry.def: The act or art of hunting, or the state of being hunted.

entry.ety: L. venatorius
entry.def: Or or pertaining to hunting; venatic.

entry.note: ☞ Vend differs from barter. We vend for money; we barter for commodities. Vend is used chiefly of wares, merchandise, or other small articles, not of lands and tenements.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vended; p. pr. & vb. n. Vending
entry.ety: F. vendre, L. vendere, from venum dare; venus sale + dare to give. See 2d Venal Date, time
entry.def: To transfer to another person for a pecuniary equivalent; to make an object of trade; to dispose of by sale; to sell; as, to vend goods; to vend vegetables.

sn.def: The act of vending or selling; a sale.
The total sales of coal from a colliery.

entry.def: A European lake whitefish (Coregonus Willughbii, or Coregonus Vandesius) native of certain lakes in Scotland and England. It is regarded as a delicate food fish. Called also vendis.
The person to whom a thing is vended, or sold; -- the correlative of vendor.

entry.note: ☞ This calendar was substituted for the ordinary calendar, dating from the Christian era, by a decree of the National Convention in 1793. The 22d of September, 1792, which had been fixed upon as the day of the foundation of the republic, was also the date of the new calendar. In this calendar, the year, which began at midnight of the day of the autumnal equinox, was divided into twelve months of thirty days, with five additional days for festivals, and every fourth year six. Each month was divided into three decades of ten days each, the week being abolished. The names of the months in their order were, Vendémiaire Brumaire Frimaire Nivose Pluviose Ventose Germinal Floréal Prairial Messidor Thermidorsometimes called Fervidor), and Fructidor. This calendar was abolished December 31, 1805, and the ordinary one restored January 1, 1806.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. vindemia vintage
entry.def: The first month of the French republican calendar, dating from September 22, 1792.

entry.ety: From Vend: cf. F. vendeur, OF. vendeor. Cf. Vendor
entry.def: One who vends; one who transfers the exclusive right of possessing a thing, either his own, or that of another as his agent, for a price or pecuniary equivalent; a seller; a vendor.

entry.ety: It

sn.def: A blood feud; private revenge for the murder of a kinsman.

Any feud or contention that is bitter and prolonged; however, the deep enmity may be held by only one party to the dispute; as, the former Mayor nurtured a lifelong vendetta against the candidate who defeated him.

entry.def: The quality or state of being vendible, or salable.

entry.note: ☞ Vendible differs from marketable; the latter signifies proper or fit for market, according to the laws or customs of a place. Vendible has no reference to such legal fitness.
entry.ety: L. vendibilis: cf. OF. vendible, F. vendable
entry.def: Capable of being vended, or sold; that may be sold; salable.
entry.q: The regulating of prices of things vendible.

entry.def: Something to be sold, or offered for sale.

entry.ety: See Venditation
entry.def: To cry up. as if for sale; to blazon.

entry.ety: L. venditatio, fr. venditare venditatum, to offer again and again for sale, v. freq. of vendere. See Vend
entry.def: The act of setting forth ostentatiously; a boastful display.

entry.ety: L. venditio: cf. F. vendition
entry.def: The act of vending, or selling; sale.

entry.ety: See Vender
entry.def: A vender; a seller; the correlative of vendee.

entries.entry: Vend"or's lien. Law An implied lien (that is, one not created by mortgage or other express agreement) given in equity to a vendor of lands for the unpaid purchase money.

entry.def: See Wends.

cs.cd: one who is authorized to sell any property by vendue; an auctioneer.

entry.ety: OF. vendue, from F. vendre, p. p. vendu vendue, to sell
entry.def: A public sale of anything, by outcry, to the highest bidder; an auction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Veneered; p. pr. & vb. n. Veneering
entry.ety: G. furnieren fourniren, fr. F. fournir to furnish. See Furnish
entry.def: To overlay or plate with a thin layer of wood or other material for outer finish or decoration; as, to veneer a piece of furniture with mahogany. Used also figuratively.
entry.q: As a rogue in grainVeneered with sanctimonious theory.

cs.cd: any moth of the genus Chilo; -- so called because the mottled colors resemble those of veneering.

entry.ety: Cf. G. furnier or fournier. See Veneer v. t.
entry.def: A thin leaf or layer of a more valuable or beautiful material for overlaying an inferior one, especially such a thin leaf of wood to be glued to a cheaper wood; hence, external show; gloss; false pretense.

sn.def: The act or art of one who veneers.
Thin wood or other material used as a veneer.

entry.ety: L. veneficus
entry.def: Veneficial.
entry.q: Veneficalinstruments.

entry.ety: L. veneficium, fr. veneficus poisoning; venenum poison + facere to make: cf. F. vénéfice
entry.def: The act or practice of poisoning.
Acting by poison; used in poisoning or in sorcery.
entry.q: An oldveneficiouspractice.

entry.def: Venomous.

entry.ety: L. venenatus, p. p. venenare to poison, from venenum poison. Cf. Venom
entry.def: To poison; to infect with poison.
Poisoned.

sn.def: The act of poisoning.
Poison; venom.

entry.def: Poisonous; venomous.

entry.ety: L. venenosus, fr. venenum poison. Cf. Venomous
entry.def: Poisonous.
The quality or state of being venerable; venerableness.

entry.note: ☞ This word is employed in the Church of England as a title for an archdeacon. In the Roman Catholic Church, venerable is applied to those who have attained to the lowest of the three recognized degrees of sanctity, but are not among the beatified, nor the canonized.
entry.ety: L. venerabilis: cf. F. vénérable

sn.def: Capable of being venerated; worthy of veneration or reverence; deserving of honor and respect; -- generally implying an advanced age; as, a venerable magistrate; a venerable parent.
sn.q: He was a man of eternal self-sacrifice, and that is always venerable.
Venerable men! you have come down to us from a former generation.

sn.def: Rendered sacred by religious or other associations; that should be regarded with awe and treated with reverence; as, the venerable walls of a temple or a church.

entry.ety: NL. See Venus
entry.def: An extensive tribe of bivalve mollusks of which the genus Venus is the type. The shells are usually oval, or somewhat heartshaped, with a conspicuous lunule. See Venus.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Venerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Venerating
entry.ety: L. veneratus, p. p. of venerari to venerate; akin to Venus Venus, Skr. van to like, to wish, and E. winsome. See Winsome
entry.def: To regard with reverential respect; to honor with mingled respect and awe; to reverence; to revere; as, we venerate parents and elders.
entry.q: And seemed to venerate the sacred shade.
I do not know a man more to be venerated for uprightness of heart and loftiness of genius.

entry.ety: L. veneratio: cf. F. vénération
entry.def: The act of venerating, or the state of being venerated; the highest degree of respect and reverence; respect mingled with awe; a feeling or sentiment excited by the dignity, wisdom, or superiority of a person, by sacredness of character, by consecration to sacred services, or by hallowed associations.
entry.q: We find a secret awe and veneration for one who moves about us in a regular and illustrious course of virtue.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who venerates.

entry.ety: L. venereus venerius, fr. Venus Veneris, Venus, the goddess of love. See Venerate

sn.def: Of or pertaining to venery, or sexual love; relating to sexual intercourse.
sn.q: Into the snare I fell Of fair, fallacious looks, venereal trains, Softened with pleasure and voluptuous life.

sd.def: Arising from sexual intercourse; as, a venereal disease; venereal virus or poison.
Adapted to the cure of venereal diseases; as, venereal medicines.

sn.def: Adapted to excite venereal desire; aphrodisiac.
Consisting of, or pertaining to, copper, formerly called by chemists Venus.

entry.def: The venereal disease; syphilis.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vénérien
entry.def: Devoted to the offices of Venus, or love; venereal.
entry.q: I am allvenereanin feeling.

entry.ety: L. venereus

sn.def: Venereal; exciting lust; aphrodisiac.
Lustful; lascivious; libidinous.

entry.def: Venereous.

entry.ety: L. Venus Veneris, the goddess of love
entry.def: Sexual love; sexual intercourse; coition.
entry.q: Contentment, without the pleasure of lawful venery, is continence; of unlawful, chastity.

entry.ety: OE. venerie, F. vénerie, fr. OF. vener to hunt, L. venari. See Venison
entry.def: The art, act, or practice of hunting; the sports of the chase.
entry.q: Beasts ofveneryand fishes.
I love hunting and venery.

entry.ety: NL. venaesectio; L. vena vein + sectio section
entry.def: The act or operation of opening a vein for letting blood; bloodletting; phlebotomy.

entry.cs: Venetian blind a blind for windows, doors, etc., made of thin slats, either fixed at a certain angle in the shutter, or movable, and in the latter case so disposed as to overlap each other when closed, and to show a series of open spaces for the admission of air and light when in other positions. Venetian carpet an inexpensive carpet, used for passages and stairs, having a woolen warp which conceals the weft; the pattern is therefore commonly made up of simple stripes. Venetian chalk a white compact talc or steatite, used for marking on cloth, etc. Venetian door Arch a door having long, narrow windows or panes of glass on the sides. Venetian glass a kind of glass made by the Venetians, for decorative purposes, by the combination of pieces of glass of different colors fused together and wrought into various ornamental patterns. Venetian red a brownish red color, prepared from sulphate of iron; -- called also scarlet ocher. Venetian soap. See Castile soap, under Soap. Venetian sumac Bot a South European tree (Rhus Cotinus) which yields the yellow dyewood called fustet; -- also called smoke tree. Venetian window Arch a window consisting of a main window with an arched head, having on each side a long and narrow window with a square head.
entry.ety: Cf. It. Veneziano, L. Venetianus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Venice in Italy.

sn.def: A native or inhabitant of Venice.
Galligaskins.
A Venetian blind.

entry.ety: F. venue, lit., an arrival, from venir, p. p. venu venue, to come. See Venue
entry.def: A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.

entry.ety: Cf. Venew or Visne
entry.def: A bout; a thrust; a venew.
entry.q: Three veneys for a dish of stewed prunes.

entries.entry:
Venge v. t. F. venger. See Vengeance
To avenge; to punish; to revenge. Obs See Avenge, and Revenge. Chaucer.Tovengeme, as I may.

entry.def: Revengeful; deserving revenge.

entry.cs:
What a vengeanceorWhat the vengeance
what! -- emphatically. Obs “But what a vengeance makes thee fly!” Hudibras. “What the vengeance! Could he not speak 'em fair?” Shak. With a vengeance with great violence; as, to strike with a vengeance . Colloq with even greater intensity; as, to return one's insult with a vengeance .
entry.ety: F. vengeance, fr. venger to avenge, L. vindicare to lay claim to, defend, avenge, fr. vindex a claimant, defender, avenger, the first part of which is of uncertain origin, and the last part akin to dicere to say. See Diction, and cf. Avenge Revenge Vindicate

sn.def: Punishment inflicted in return for an injury or an offense; retribution; -- often, in a bad sense, passionate or unrestrained revenge.
sn.q: To me belongeth vengeance and recompense.
To execute fierce vengeance on his foes.

sn.def: Harm; mischief.

entry.def: Extremely; excessively.
entry.q: He loves thatvengeancely.

entry.def: Vindictive; retributive; revengeful.
entry.q: Vengefulire.

entry.ety: OF. vengement
entry.def: Avengement; penal retribution; vengeance.
An avenger.

entry.ety: L. veniabilis, fr. venia forgiveness, pardon
entry.def: Venial; pardonable.

cs.cd: a sin which weakens, but does not wholly destroy, sanctifying grace, as do mortal, or deadly, sins.

entry.ety: OF. venial, F. véniel, L. venialis, from venia forgiveness, pardon, grace, favor, kindness; akin to venerari to venerate. See Venerate

sn.def: Capable of being forgiven; not heinous; excusable; pardonable; as, a venial fault or transgression.
sn.q: So they do nothing, 't is a venial slip.

sn.def: Allowed; permitted.
sn.q: Permitting him the whilevenialdiscourse unblamed.

entry.def: The quality or state of being venial; venialness.

entry.ety: L. venenum poison
entry.def: A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes; also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by the cleavage of an albumose.

entries.entry: Ve*ni"re fa"ci*as Ve*ni"re fa"ci*as. L., make, or cause, to come Law A judicial writ or precept directed to the sheriff, requiring him to cause a certain number of qualified persons to appear in court at a specified time, to serve as jurors in said court. A writ in the nature of a summons to cause the party indicted on a penal statute to appear. Called also venire.

entry.ety: OE. veneison veneson venison, OF. veneison, F. venaison, L. venatio hunting, the chase, game, fr. venari, p. p. venatus, to hunt; perhaps akin to OHG. weidinōn weidenen, to pasture, to hunt, G. weide pasturage. Cf. Gain to acquire, Venation

sn.def: Beasts of the chase.
Formerly, the flesh of any of the edible beasts of the chase, also of game birds; now, the flesh of animals of the deer kind exclusively.

entry.ety: L., come, imperative 2d person pl. So called from its opening word in the Latin version
entry.def: The 95th Psalm, which is said or sung regularly in the public worship of many churches. Also, a musical composition adapted to this Psalm.

entry.ety: OE. venim, OF. venim venin, F. venin, L. venenum. Cf. Venenate

sn.def: Matter fatal or injurious to life; poison; particularly, the poisonous matter which certain animals, such as serpents, scorpions, bees, etc., secrete in a state of health, and communicate by biting or stinging.
sn.q: Or hurtful worm with cankered venom bites.

sn.def: Spite; malice; malignity; evil quality.
sn.q: Thevenomof such looks.
sn.syn: Venom; virus; bane. See Poison.

entry.ety: OE. venimen, OF. venimer, L. venenare. See Venom n.
entry.def: To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison.
entry.q: Venomedvengeance.

cs.cd: any serpent which has poison glands and fangs, whether dangerous to man or not. These serpents constitute two tribes, the viperine serpents, or Solenoglypha, and the cobralike serpents, or Proteroglypha. The former have perforated, erectile fangs situated in the front part of the upper jaw, and are without ordinary teeth behind the fangs; the latter have permanently erect and grooved fangs, with ordinary maxillary teeth behind them.

entry.ety: OE. venemous venimous, F. venimeux, L. venenosus, fr. venenum poison. See Venom, and cf. Venenose

sn.def: Full of venom; noxious to animal life; poisonous; as, the bite of a serpent may be venomous .
Having a poison gland or glands for the secretion of venom, as certain serpents and insects.
