Noxious; mischievous; malignant; spiteful; as, a venomous progeny; a venomous writer.

entry.ety: See Venous
entry.def: Having numerous or conspicuous veins; veiny; as, a venose frond.

sn.def: The quality or state of being venous.
A condition in which the circulation is retarded, and the entire mass of blood is less oxygenated than it normally is.

cs.cd: a leaf having vessels branching, or variously divided, over its surface.
a humming sound, or bruit, heard during auscultation of the veins of the neck in anæmia.

the pulse, or rhythmic contraction, sometimes seen in a vein, as in the neck, when there is an obstruction to the passage of blood from the auricles to the ventricles, or when there is an abnormal rigidity in the walls of the greater vessels. There is normally no pulse in a vein.

entry.ety: L. venosus, from vena a vein. See Vein

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a vein or veins; as, the venous circulation of the blood.

Contained in the veins, or having the same qualities as if contained in the veins, that is, having a dark bluish color and containing an insufficient amount of oxygen so as no longer to be fit for oxygenating the tissues; -- said of the blood, and opposed to arterial.
Marked with veins; veined; as, a venous leaf.

entry.ety: F. vente, fr. L. vendere -itum, to sell; perh. confused with E. vent an opening. See Vend
entry.def: Sale; opportunity to sell; market.
entry.q: There is no vent for any commodity but of wool.

entry.def: To sell; to vend.
entry.q: Therefore did those nations vent such spice.

entry.ety: Sp. venta a poor inn, sale, market. See Vent sale
entry.def: A baiting place; an inn.

entry.ety: Cf. F. venter to blow, vent wind (see Ventilate); but prob influenced by E. vent an opening
entry.def: To snuff; to breathe or puff out; to snort.

entry.cs: To give vent to to suffer to escape; to let out; to pour forth; as, to give vent to anger. To take vent to escape; to be made public. R Vent feather Zoöl one of the anal, or crissal, feathers of a bird. Vent field Gun a flat raised surface around a vent. Vent piece. Gun A bush. See 4th Bush n., 2. A breech block.
entry.ety: OE. fent fente, a slit, F. fente a slit, cleft, fissure, from fendre to split, L. findere; but probably confused with F. vent wind, L. ventus. See Fissure, and cf. Vent to snuff

sn.def: A small aperture; a hole or passage for air or any fluid to escape; as, the vent of a cask; the vent of a mold; a volcanic vent.
sn.q: Look, how thy wounds do bleed at many vents.
Long 't was doubtful, both so closely pent, Which first should issue from the narrow vent.

entry.sn:
Specifically: Zoöl The anal opening of certain invertebrates and fishes; also, the external cloacal opening of reptiles, birds, amphibians, and many fishes.
Gun The opening at the breech of a firearm, through which fire is communicated to the powder of the charge; touchhole.
Steam Boilers Sectional area of the passage for gases divided by the length of the same passage in feet.

sn.def: Fig.: Opportunity of escape or passage from confinement or privacy; outlet.
Emission; escape; passage to notice or expression; publication; utterance.
sn.q: Without the vent of words.
Thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vented; p. pr. & vb. n. Venting

sn.def: To let out at a vent, or small aperture; to give passage or outlet to.
To suffer to escape from confinement; to let out; to utter; to pour forth; as, to vent passion or complaint.
sn.q: The queen of heaven did thus her fury vent.

sn.def: To utter; to report; to publish.
sn.q: By mixing somewhat true to vent more lies.
Thou hast framed and vented very curious orations.

sn.def: To scent, as a hound.
To furnish with a vent; to make a vent in; as, to vent . a mold.

entry.def: A small hole, as the stop in a flute; a vent.

entry.ety: OF. ventaille, F. ventail. See Ventilate, and cf. Aventail
entry.def: That part of a helmet which is intended for the admission of air, -- sometimes in the visor.
entry.q: Her ventail up so high that he descried Her goodly visage and her beauty's pride.

entry.def: One who vents; one who utters, reports, or publishes.

entry.ety: L

sd.def: The belly; the abdomen; -- sometimes applied to any large cavity containing viscera.
The uterus, or womb.
A belly, or protuberant part; a broad surface; as, the venter of a muscle; the venter, or anterior surface, of the scapula.

sn.def: The lower part of the abdomen in insects.
A pregnant woman; a mother; as, A has a son B by one venter, and a daughter C by another venter; children by different venters.

entry.def: A touchhole; a vent.

entry.ety: L. ventus wind + ductus a leading, conduit, fr. ducere ductum, to lead
entry.def: A passage for wind or air; a passage or pipe for ventilating apartments.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ventilated; p. pr. & vb. n. Ventilating
entry.ety: L. ventilatus, p. p. of ventilare to toss, brandish in the air, to fan, to winnow, from ventus wind; akin to E. wind. See Wind rushing air

sn.def: To open and expose to the free passage of air; to supply with fresh air, and remove impure air from; to air; as, to ventilate a room; to ventilate a cellar; to ventilate a mine.
To provide with a vent, or escape, for air, gas, etc.; as, to ventilate a mold, or a water-wheel bucket.
To change or renew, as the air of a room.
To winnow; to fan; as, to ventilate wheat.
To sift and examine; to bring out, and subject to penetrating scrutiny; to expose to examination and discussion; as, to ventilate questions of policy.
To give vent to; to utter; to make public.
sn.q: Macaulay took occasion to ventilate one of those startling, but not very profound, paradoxes.

entry.ety: L. ventilatio: cf. F. ventilation

sn.def: The act of ventilating, or the state of being ventilated; the art or process of replacing foul air by that which is pure, in any inclosed place, as a house, a church, a mine, etc.; free exposure to air.
sn.q: Insuring, for the laboring man, better ventilation.

sn.def: The act of refrigerating, or cooling; refrigeration; as, ventilation of the blood.
The act of fanning, or winnowing, for the purpose of separating chaff and dust from the grain.
The act of sifting, and bringing out to view or examination; free discussion; public exposure.
sn.q: The ventilation of these points diffused them to the knowledge of the world.

sn.def: The act of giving vent or expression.
sn.q: Ventilationof his thoughts.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to ventilation; adapted to secure ventilation; ventilating; as, ventilative apparatus.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ventilateur, L. ventilator a winnower
entry.def: A contrivance for effecting ventilation; especially, a contrivance or machine for drawing off or expelling foul or stagnant air from any place or apartment, or for introducing that which is fresh and pure.
A ventouse.

entry.ety: L. ventosus windy. See Ventilate
entry.def: Windy; flatulent.

entry.ety: F. ventôse. See Ventose a.
entry.def: The sixth month of the calendar adopted by the first French republic. It began February 19, and ended March 20. See Vendémiaire.

entry.ety: L. ventositas: cf. F. ventosité. See Ventose n.
entry.def: Quality or state of being ventose; windiness; hence, vainglory; pride.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A cupping glass.
To cup; to use a cupping glass.

entry.ety: L. venter belly + ad to
entry.def: Toward the ventral side; on the ventral side; ventrally; -- opposed to dorsad.

entry.cs: Ventral fins Zoöl the posterior pair of fins of a fish. They are often situated beneath the belly, but sometimes beneath the throat. Ventral segment. Acoustics See Loop n., 5.
entry.ety: L. ventralis, fr. venter the belly; perhaps akin to G. wanst: cf. F. ventral

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or situated near, the belly, or ventral side, of an animal or of one of its parts; hemal; abdominal; as, the ventral fin of a fish; the ventral root of a spinal nerve; -- opposed to dorsal.

sd.def: Of or pertaining to that surface of a carpel, petal, etc., which faces toward the center of a flower.
Of or pertaining to the lower side or surface of a creeping moss or other low flowerless plant. Opposed to dorsal.

entry.note: ☞ The principal ventricles of the brain are the fourth in the medulla, the third in the midbrain, the first and second, or lateral, ventricles in the cerebral hemispheres, all of which are connected with each other, and the fifth, or pseudocœle, situated between the hemispheres, in front of, or above, the fornix, and entirely disconnected with the other cavities. See Brain, and Cœlia.
entry.ety: L. ventriculus the stomach, a ventricle, dim. of venter the belly: cf. F. ventricule. See Ventral

sn.def: A cavity, or one of the cavities, of an organ, as of the larynx or the brain; specifically, the posterior chamber, or one of the two posterior chambers, of the heart, which receives the blood from the auricle and forces it out from the heart. See Heart.
The stomach.
sn.q: Whether I will or not, while I live, my heart beats, and my ventricle digests what is in it.

sn.def: Fig.: Any cavity, or hollow place, in which any function may be conceived of as operating.
sn.q: These [ideas] are begot on the ventricle of memory.

entry.cs: Ventricose shell. Zoöl A spiral shell having the body whorls rounded or swollen in the middle. A bivalve shell in which the valves are strongly convex.
entry.ety: NL. ventricosus, fr. L. venter belly
entry.def: Swelling out on one side or unequally; bellied; ventricular; as, a ventricose corolla.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ventriculaire
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a ventricle; bellied.

entry.note: ☞ Many of them were shaped like vases, others like mushrooms. They belong to the hexactinellids, and are allied to the Venus's basket of modern seas.
entry.ety: See Ventriculus
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of siliceous fossil sponges belonging to Ventriculites and allied genera, characteristic of the Cretaceous period.

entry.ety: L. ventriculosus of the belly
entry.def: Somewhat distended in the middle; ventricular.

entries.entry: Ven*tric"u*lus Ven*tric"u*lus n.; pl.Ventriculi #. L., belly, dim. fr. venter belly Zoöl One of the stomachs of certain insects. The body cavity of a sponge.

entry.ety: See Ventriloquous
entry.def: Ventriloquism.
Ventriloquous.

entry.ety: See Ventriloquous
entry.def: The act, art, or practice of speaking in such a manner that the voice appears to come, not from the person speaking, but from some other source, as from a dummy held by the ventriloquist, from the opposite side of the room, from the cellar, etc.

cs.cd: the onappo; -- so called from the character of its cry.

entry.def: One who practices, or is skilled in, ventriloquism.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ventriloquized; p. pr. & vb. n. Ventriloquizing
entry.def: To practice ventriloquism; to speak like a ventriloquist.

entry.ety: L. ventriloquus a ventriloquist; venter the belly + loqui, p. p. locutus, to speak. See Ventral, and Loquacious
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a ventriloquist or ventriloquism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ventriloquie
entry.def: Same as Ventriloquism.

entry.ety: NL. See Venter, and Meson
entry.def: See Meson.

entries.entry: Ven"tro-. L. venter belly A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to the abdomen; also, connection with relation to, or direction toward the ventral side; as, ventrolateral; ventro-inguinal.

entry.def: Pertaining both to the abdomen and groin, or to the abdomen and inguinal canal; as, ventro-inguinal hernia.

cs.cd: at hazard; without seeing the end or mark; without foreseeing the issue; at random.

entry.note: ☞ The phrase at a venture was originally at aventure, that is, at adventure.
entry.ety: Aphetic form of OE. aventure. See Adventure

sn.def: An undertaking of chance or danger; the risking of something upon an event which can not be foreseen with certainty; a hazard; a risk; a speculation.
sn.q: I, in this venture, double gains pursue.

sn.def: An event that is not, or can not be, foreseen; an accident; chance; hap; contingency; luck.
The thing put to hazard; a stake; a risk; especially, something sent to sea in trade.
sn.q: My ventures are not in one bottom trusted.
A certain man drew a bow at a venture.
A bargain at a venture made.

entry.cs:
To venture atorTo venture onorTo venture upon
to dare to engage in; to attempt without any certainty of success; as, it is rash to venture upon such a project. “When I venture at the comic style.” Waller.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ventured; p. pr. & vb. n. Venturing

sn.def: To hazard one's self; to have the courage or presumption to do, undertake, or say something; to dare.
To make a venture; to run a hazard or risk; to take the chances.
sn.q: Who freights a ship to venture on the seas.

sn.def: To expose to hazard; to risk; to hazard; as, to venture one's person in a balloon.
sn.q: I am afraid; and yet I'll venture it.

sn.def: To put or send on a venture or chance; as, to venture a horse to the West Indies.
To confide in; to rely on; to trust.
sn.q: A man would be well enough pleased to buy silks of one whom he would not venture to feel his pulse.

sn.def: One who ventures, or puts to hazard; an adventurer.
A strumpet; a prostitute.

entry.def: Inclined to venture; not loth to run risk or danger; venturous; bold; daring; adventurous; as, a venturesome boy or act.

entry.ety: Cf. Aventurine
entry.def: Gold powder for covering varnished surfaces.

entry.ety: Aphetic form of OE. aventurous. See Adventurous Venture n.
entry.def: Daring; bold; hardy; fearless; venturesome; adventurous; as, a venturous soldier.
entry.q: This said, he paused not, but with venturous arm He plucked, he tasted.

entry.def: See Ventouse.

entry.note: ☞ In certain cases, the court has power to change the venue, which is to direct the trial to be had in a different county from that where the venue is laid.

cs.cd: to allege a place.

entry.ety: F. venue a coming, arrival, fr. venir to come, L. venire; hence, in English, the place whither the jury are summoned to come. See Come, and cf. Venew Veney

sn.def: A neighborhood or near place; the place or county in which anything is alleged to have happened; also, the place where an action is laid.
sn.q: The twelve men who are to try the cause must be of the same venue where the demand is made.

sn.def: A bout; a hit; a turn. See Venew.

entry.ety: L. venula, dim. from vena vein
entry.def: A small vein; a veinlet; specifically Zoöl, one of the small branches of the veins of the wings in insects.
Full of venules, or small veins.

entry.cs: Venus's basin Bot the wild teasel; -- so called because the connate leaf bases form a kind of receptacle for water, which was formerly gathered for use in the toilet. Also called Venus's bath. Venus's basket Zoöl an elegant, cornucopia-shaped, hexactinellid sponge (Euplectella speciosa) native of the East Indies. It consists of glassy, transparent, siliceous fibers interwoven and soldered together so as to form a firm network, and has long, slender, divergent anchoring fibers at the base by means of which it stands erect in the soft mud at the bottom of the sea. Called also Venus's flower basket, and Venus's purse. Venus's comb. Bot Same as Lady's comb. Zoöl A species of Murex Murex tenuispinus). It has a long, tubular canal, with a row of long, slender spines along both of its borders, and rows of similar spines covering the body of the shell. Called also Venus's shell. Venus's fan Zoöl a common reticulated, fanshaped gorgonia (Gorgonia flabellum) native of Florida and the West Indies. When fresh the color is purple or yellow, or a mixture of the two. Venus's flytrap. Bot See Flytrap, 2. Venus's girdle Zoöl a long, flat, ribbonlike, very delicate, transparent and iridescent ctenophore (Cestum Veneris) which swims in the open sea. Its form is due to the enormous development of two spheromeres. See Illust. in Appendix. Venus's hair Bot a delicate and graceful fern (Adiantum Capillus-Veneris) having a slender, black and shining stem and branches. Venus's hair stone Min quartz penetrated by acicular crystals of rutile. Venus's looking-glass Bot an annual plant of the genus Specularia allied to the bellflower; -- also called lady's looking-glass. Venus's navelwort Bot any one of several species of Omphalodes, low boraginaceous herbs with small blue or white flowers. Venus's pride Bot an old name for Quaker ladies. See under Quaker. Venus's purse. Zoöl Same as Venus's basket, above. Venus's shell. Zoöl Any species of Cypræa; a cowrie. Same as Venus's comb, above. Same as Venus, 4. Venus's slipper. Bot Any plant of the genus Cypripedium. See Lady's slipper. Zoöl Any heteropod shell of the genus Carinaria. See Carinaria.
entry.ety: L. Venus -eris, the goddess of love, the planet Venus

sn.def: The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or love deified.

One of the planets, the second in order from the sun, its orbit lying between that of Mercury and that of the Earth, at a mean distance from the sun of about 67,000,000 miles. Its diameter is 7,700 miles, and its sidereal period 224.7 days. As the morning star, it was called by the ancients Lucifer; as the evening star, Hesperus.
The metal copper; -- probably so designated from the ancient use of the metal in making mirrors, a mirror being still the astronomical symbol of the planet Venus.

Any one of numerous species of marine bivalve shells of the genus Venus or family Veneridæ. Many of these shells are large, and ornamented with beautiful frills; others are smooth, glossy, and handsomely colored. Some of the larger species, as the round clam, or quahog, are valued for food.

entry.ety: L. venustus, from Venus the goddess of love
entry.def: Beautiful.

entry.ety: L. verax -acis, fr. verus true. See Very

sn.def: Observant of truth; habitually speaking truth; truthful; as, veracious historian.
sn.q: The Spirit is most perfectly and absolutely veracious.

sn.def: Characterized by truth; true; not false; as, a veracious account or narrative.
sn.q: The young, ardent soul that enters on this world with heroic purpose, with veracious insight, will find it a mad one.

entry.def: In a veracious manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. véracité
entry.def: The quality or state of being veracious; habitual observance of truth; truthfulness; truth; as, a man of veracity .

entry.ety: A word brought by the English from India; of uncertain origin; cf. Skr. varaṇḍa, Pg. varanda, Sp. baranda, Malay baranda
entry.def: An open, roofed gallery or portico, adjoining a dwelling house, forming an out-of-door sitting room. See Loggia.
entry.q: The house was of adobe, low, with a wide veranda on the three sides of the inner court.

entry.def: A yellowish amorphous alkaloid extracted from the rootstock of Veratrum album.
A salt of veratric acid.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Veratrine.

cs.cd: an acid occurring, together with veratrine, in the root of white hellebore (Veratrum album), and in sabadilla seed; -- extracted as a white crystalline substance which is related to protocatechuic acid.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, plants of the genus Veratrum.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Veratrine.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vératrine. See Veratrum
entry.def: A poisonous alkaloid obtained from the root of hellebore (Veratrum) and from sabadilla seeds as a white crystalline powder, having an acrid, burning taste. It is sometimes used externally, as in ointments, in the local treatment of neuralgia and rheumatism. Called also veratria, and veratrina.

entry.ety: Veratric + ol
entry.def: A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the decomposition of veratric acid, and constituting the dimethyl ether of pyrocatechin.

entry.note: ☞ Veratrum album of Europe, and Veratrum viride of America, are both called hellebore. They grow in wet land, have large, elliptical, plicate leaves in three vertical ranks, and bear panicles of greenish flowers.
entry.ety: L. veratrum hellebore
entry.def: A genus of coarse liliaceous herbs having very poisonous qualities.

entry.note: ☞ A verb is a word whereby the chief action of the mind [the assertion or the denial of a proposition] finds expression. Earle.

cs.cd: etc. See Active Auxiliary Neuter, etc.

entry.ety: F. verbe, L. verbum a word, verb. See Word

sn.def: A word; a vocable.
A word which affirms or predicates something of some person or thing; a part of speech expressing being, action, or the suffering of action.

entry.cs: Verbal inspiration. See under Inspiration. Verbal noun Gram a noun derived directly from a verb or verb stem; a verbal. The term is specifically applied to infinitives, and nouns ending in -ing, esp. to the latter. See Gerund, and -ing, 2. See also, Infinitive mood, under Infinitive.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. verbalis. See Verb

sn.def: Expressed in words, whether spoken or written, but commonly in spoken words; hence, spoken; oral; not written; as, a verbal contract; verbal testimony.
sn.q: Made she no verbal question?
We subjoin an engraving . . . which will give the reader a far better notion of the structure than any verbal description could convey to the mind.

sn.def: Consisting in, or having to do with, words only; dealing with words rather than with the ideas intended to be conveyed; as, a verbal critic; a verbal change.
sn.q: And loses, though but verbal, his reward.
Mere verbal refinements, instead of substantial knowledge.

sn.def: Having word answering to word; word for word; literal; as, a verbal translation.
Abounding with words; verbose.
Of or pertaining to a verb; as, a verbal group; derived directly from a verb; as, a verbal noun; used in forming verbs; as, a verbal prefix.

entry.def: A noun derived from a verb.
Something expressed verbally; a verbal remark or expression.
A literal adherent to, or a minute critic of, words; a literalist.
The quality or state of being verbal; mere words; bare literal expression.
entry.q: Moreverbalitythan matter.

entry.def: The act of verbalizing, or the state of being verbalized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Verbalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Verbalizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. verbaliser

sn.def: To convert into a verb; to verbify.
To express in words.

entry.def: To be verbose.

sn.def: In a verbal manner; orally.
Word for word; verbatim.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to words; verbal.
One who coins words; a neologist.
entry.q: Southey gives himself free scope as a verbarian.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. verbum word
entry.def: A game in word making. See Logomachy, 2.

cs.cd: word for word, and letter for letter.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. verbum word
entry.def: Word for word; in the same words; verbally; as, to tell a story verbatim as another has related it.

entry.note: ☞ Verbena, or vervain, was used by the Greeks, the Romans, and the Druids, in their sacred rites. Brewer.

cs.cd: a perfume prepared from the lemon verbena; also, a similar perfume properly called grass oil. See Grass oil, under Grass.
a shrubby verbenaceous plant (Lippia citriodora), with narrow leaves which exhale a pleasant, lemonlike fragrance when crushed.

entry.ety: L. See Vervain
entry.def: A genus of herbaceous plants of which several species are extensively cultivated for the great beauty of their flowers; vervain.

Of or pertaining to a natural order (Verbenaceæ) of gamopetalous plants of which Verbena is the type. The order includes also the black and white mangroves, and many plants noted for medicinal use or for beauty of bloom.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Verbenated; p. pr. & vb. n. Verbenating
entry.ety: L. verbenatus crowned with a wreath of sacred boughs. See Verbena
entry.def: To strew with verbena, or vervain, as in ancient sacrifices and rites.

entry.ety: L. verberatus, p. p. of verberare to beat, from verber a lash, a whip
entry.def: To beat; to strike.
entry.q: The sound . . . rebounds again andverberatesthe skies.

entry.ety: L. verberatio: cf. F. verbération

sn.def: The act of verberating; a beating or striking.
The impulse of a body, which causes sound.

entry.ety: F. verbiage, from OF. verbe a word. See Verb
entry.def: The use of many words without necessity, or with little sense; a superabundance of words; verbosity; wordiness.
entry.q: Verbiage may indicate observation, but not thinking.
This barren verbiage current among men.

entry.ety: Verb + -fy
entry.def: To make into a verb; to use as a verb; to verbalize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. verbigerated; p. pr. & vb. n. verbigerating
entry.ety: L. verbigerate -atum, to talk

sn.def: To talk; chat.
To repeat a word or sentence, in speaking or writing, without wishing to do so or in spite of efforts to cease.

entry.ety: L. verbosus, from verbum a word. See Verb
entry.def: Abounding in words; using or containing more words than are necessary; tedious by a multiplicity of words; prolix; wordy; as, a verbose speaker; a verbose argument.
entry.q: Too verbose in their way of speaking.

entries.entry:
Ver*bos"i*ty n.; pl.Verbosities #. L. verbositas: cf. F. verbosité
The quality or state of being verbose; the use of more words than are necessary; prolixity; wordiness; verbiage. The worst fault, by far, is the extreme diffuseness and verbosity of his style.

entry.ety: See Vert Verdant

sd.def: The privilege of cutting green wood within a forest for fuel.
The right of pasturing animals in a forest.

sn.def: Greenness; freshness.

entry.def: The quality or state of being verdant.

entry.ety: F. verdoyant, p. pr. of verdoyer to be verdant, to grow green, OF. verdoier verdeier, fr. verd vert, green, fr. L. viridis green, fr. virere to be green: cf. OF. verdant verdant, L. viridans, p. pr. of viridare to make green. Cf. Farthingale Verjuice Vert

sn.def: Covered with growing plants or grass; green; fresh; flourishing; as, verdant fields; a verdant lawn.
sn.q: Let the earth Put forth the verdant grass.

sn.def: Unripe in knowledge or judgment; unsophisticated; raw; green; as, a verdant youth.

entries.entry:
Verd` an*tique". F. vert antique a kind of marble; verd vert, green + antique ancient: cf. It. verde antico
Min A mottled-green serpentine marble. A green porphyry called oriental verd antique.

entry.def: In a verdant manner.

entry.ety: F. verdier, LL. viridarius, fr. L. viridis green
entry.def: An officer who has the charge of the king's forest, to preserve the vert and venison, keep the assizes, view, receive, and enroll attachments and presentments of all manner of trespasses.

entry.note: ☞ The decision of a judge or referee, upon an issue of fact, is not called a verdict, but a finding, or a finding of fact. Abbott.
entry.ety: OE. verdit, OF. verdit veirdit, LL. verdictum veredictum; L. vere truly (fr. verus true) + dictum a saying, a word, fr. dicere, dictum, to say. See Very, and Dictum

sn.def: The answer of a jury given to the court concerning any matter of fact in any cause, civil or criminal, committed to their examination and determination; the finding or decision of a jury on the matter legally submitted to them in the course of the trial of a cause.
Decision; judgment; opinion pronounced; as, to be condemned by the verdict of the public.
sn.q: These were enormities condemned by the most natural verdict of common humanity.
Two generations have since confirmed the verdict which was pronounced on that night.

entry.note: ☞ This rust is a carbonate of copper, and should not be confounded with true verdigris.

cs.cd: a verdigris having a blue color, used as a pigment, etc.
an acid copper acetate; -- so called because the acetic acid used in making it was obtained from distilled vinegar.
clear bluish green, the color of verdigris.

entry.ety: F. vert-de-gris, apparently from verd vert, green + de of + gris gray, but really a corruption of LL. viride aerisequivalent to L. aerugo), from L. viridis green + aes aeris, brass. See Verdant, and 2d Ore

sn.def: A green poisonous substance used as a pigment and drug, obtained by the action of acetic acid on copper, and consisting essentially of a complex mixture of several basic copper acetates.
The green rust formed on copper.

entry.def: To cover, or coat, with verdigris.
entry.q: An oldverdigrisedbrass bugle.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. verdino bright green, F. verdin the yellow-hammer
entry.def: A small yellow-headed bird (Auriparus flaviceps) of Lower California, allied to the titmice; -- called also goldtit.

entry.ety: F. verd vert, green
entry.def: A commercial name for a green aniline dye.
See Farthingale.
Verdict.

cs.cd: a pale greenish blue color, like that of the pigment verditer.

entry.ety: F. vert-de-terre, literally, green of earth
entry.def: Verdigris.

Either one of two pigments (called blue verditer, and green verditer) which are made by treating copper nitrate with calcium carbonate (in the form of lime, whiting, chalk, etc.) They consist of hydrated copper carbonates analogous to the minerals azurite and malachite.

entry.ety: Cf. Verditer
entry.def: The faintest and palest green.

entry.ety: F. verdoyer to become green. See Verdant
entry.def: Charged with leaves, fruits, flowers, etc.; -- said of a border.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. viridis green. See Verdant
entry.def: Green; greenness; freshness of vegetation; as, the verdure of the meadows in June.
entry.q: A wide expanse of living verdure, cultivated gardens, shady groves, fertile cornfields, flowed round it like a sea.

entry.def: Covered with verdure.
Destitute of verdure.
Covered with verdure; clothed with the fresh green of vegetation; verdured; verdant; as, verdurous pastures.

entry.ety: L. verecundus, fr. vereri to feel awe
entry.def: Bashful; modest.
Verecund.
entry.q: Verecundiousgenerosity.

entry.def: The quality or state of being verecund; modesty.

entry.ety: G
entry.def: A union, association, or society; -- used in names of German organizations.

entry.ety: L., dim. of veretrum the private parts
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of club-shaped, compound Alcyonaria belonging to Veretillum and allied genera, of the tribe Pennatulacea. The whole colony can move about as if it were a simple animal.

entry.ety: Cf. Virgouleuse
entry.def: See Virgalieu.

entry.ety: F. verge, L. virga; perhaps akin to E. wisp

sn.def: A rod or staff, carried as an emblem of authority; as, the verge, carried before a dean.
The stick or wand with which persons were formerly admitted tenants, they holding it in the hand, and swearing fealty to the lord. Such tenants were called tenants by the verge.

The compass of the court of Marshalsea and the Palace court, within which the lord steward and the marshal of the king's household had special jurisdiction; -- so called from the verge, or staff, which the marshal bore.
A virgate; a yardland.
A border, limit, or boundary of a space; an edge, margin, or brink of something definite in extent.
sn.q: Even though we go to the extreme verge of possibility to invent a supposition favorable to it, the theory . . . implies an absurdity.
But on the horizon's verge descried, Hangs, touched with light, one snowy sail.

sn.def: A circumference; a circle; a ring.
sn.q: The inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow.

sd.def: The shaft of a column, or a small ornamental shaft.
The edge of the tiling projecting over the gable of a roof.

sn.def: The spindle of a watch balance, especially one with pallets, as in the old vertical escapement. See under Escapement.

sd.def: The edge or outside of a bed or border.
A slip of grass adjoining gravel walks, and dividing them from the borders in a parterre.

sn.def: The penis.
The external male organ of certain mollusks, worms, etc. See Illustration in Appendix.
sn.syn: Border; edge; rim; brim; margin; brink.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Verged vẽrjd; p. pr. & vb. n. Verging vẽr"jĭng
entry.ety: L. vergere to bend, turn, incline; cf. Skr. vṛj to turn

sn.def: To border upon; to tend; to incline; to come near; to approach.
To tend downward; to bend; to slope; as, a hill verges to the north.
sn.q: Our soul, from original instinct, vergeth towards him as its center.
I find myself verging to that period of life which is to be labor and sorrow.

entry.ety: Verge + board. Cf. Bargeboard
entry.def: The ornament of woodwork upon the gable of a house, used extensively in the 15th century. It was generally suspended from the edge of the projecting roof (see Verge n., 4), and in a position parallel to the gable wall. Called also bargeboard.

sn.def: The act of verging or approaching; tendency; approach.
The reciprocal of the focal distance of a lens, used as measure of the divergence or convergence of a pencil of rays.

entries.entry:
Ver"ger n. F. verger, from verge a rod. See 1st Verge
One who carries a verge, or emblem of office. Specifically:An attendant upon a dignitary, as on a bishop, a dean, a justice, etc. Eng The official who takes care of the interior of a church building.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A garden or orchard.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vergeté
entry.def: Divided by pallets, or pales; paly.
A small pale.

entry.ety: L. veridicus; verus true + dicere to say, tell
entry.def: Truth-telling; truthful; veracious.
Capable of being verified; confirmable.

cs.cd: the operation of testing the equation of a problem, to see whether it expresses truly the conditions of the problem.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vérification

sn.def: The act of verifying, or the state of being verified; confirmation; authentication.

sd.def: Confirmation by evidence.
A formal phrase used in concluding a plea.

entry.def: Serving to verify; verifying; authenticating; confirming.
One who, or that which, verifies.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Verified; p. pr. & vb. n. Verifying
entry.ety: F. vérifier, LL. verificare, from L. verus true + -ficare to make. See Very, and -fy

sn.def: To prove to be true or correct; to establish the truth of; to confirm; to substantiate.
sn.q: This is verified by a number of examples.
So shalt thou best fulfill, best verify. The prophets old, who sung thy endless reign.

sn.def: To confirm or establish the authenticity of by examination or competent evidence; to authenticate; as, to verify a written statement; to verify an account, a pleading, or the like.
sn.q: To verify our title with their lives.

sn.def: To maintain; to affirm; to support.

entry.ety: L. verus true + loquens speaking
entry.def: Speaking truth; truthful.

entry.ety: From Very
entry.def: In very truth; beyond doubt or question; in fact; certainly.
entry.q: Trust in the Lord and do good; so shalt thou dwell in the land, and verily thou shalt be fed.

entry.ety: Contr. from veratrine
entry.def: An alkaloid obtained as a yellow amorphous substance by the decomposition of veratrine.

entry.ety: L. verisimilis; verus true + similis like, similar. See Very, and Similar
entry.def: Having the appearance of truth; probable; likely.
entry.q: Howverisimilarit looks.

entry.ety: L. verisimilitudo: cf. OF. verisimilitude. See Verisimilar
entry.def: The quality or state of being verisimilar; the appearance of truth; probability; likelihood.
entry.q: Verisimilitude and opinion are an easy purchase; but true knowledge is dear and difficult.
All that gives verisimilitude to a narrative.

entry.def: Verisimilitude.
entry.q: The verisimility or probable truth.

entry.def: Verisimilar.

entry.ety: F. véritable. See Verity
entry.def: Agreeable to truth or to fact; actual; real; true; genuine.
entry.q: TheveritableDeity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. véritas. See Verity
entry.def: The Bureau Veritas. See under Bureau.

entries.entry:
Ver"i*ty n.; pl.Verities #. F. vérité, L. veritas, fr. verus true. See Very
The quality or state of being true, or real; consonance of a statement, proposition, or other thing, with fact; truth; reality. Theverityof certain words. It is a proposition of eternal verity, that none can govern while he is despised.
That which is true; a true assertion or tenet; a truth; a reality. Mark what I say, which you shall find By every syllable a faithful verity.

entry.ety: OE. vergeous, F. verjus, that is, the juice of green fruits; verd vert, green + jus juice. See Verdant, and Juice

sn.def: The sour juice of crab apples, of green or unripe grapes, apples, etc.; also, an acid liquor made from such juice.
Tartness; sourness, as of disposition.

entry.ety: F., vermilion, fr. LL. vermiculus, fr. L. vermiculus a little worm, the coccus Indicus, from vermis a worm. See Worm, and cf. Vermicule

sn.def: Vermilion; also, the color of vermilion, a bright, beautiful red.
sn.q: In her cheeks the vermeill red did show Like roses in a bed of lilies shed.

sn.def: Silver gilt or gilt bronze.
A liquid composition applied to a gilded surface to give luster to the gold.

entry.def: One who treats of vermes, or worms; a helminthologist.

entry.ety: L. vermes worms + -logy
entry.def: A discourse or treatise on worms; that part of zoölogy which treats of worms; helminthology.

entry.ety: L. vermes, pl. of vermis a worm
entry.def: An extensive artificial division of the animal kingdom, including the parasitic worms, or helminths, together with the nemerteans, annelids, and allied groups. By some writers the branchiopods, the bryzoans, and the tunicates are also included. The name was used in a still wider sense by Linnæus and his followers.
A more restricted group, comprising only the helminths and closely allied orders.
Any species of vermetus.

entry.ety: NL., from L. vermis worm
entry.def: Any one of many species of marine gastropods belonging to Vermetus and allied genera, of the family Vermetidæ. Their shells are regularly spiral when young, but later in life the whorls become separate, and the shell is often irregularly bent and contorted like a worm tube.

entry.ety: It., pl. of vermicello, literally, a little worm, dim. of verme a worm, L. vermis. See Worm, and cf. Vermicule Vermeil
entry.def: The flour of a hard and small-grained wheat made into dough, and forced through small cylinders or pipes till it takes a slender, wormlike form, whence the Italian name. When the paste is made in larger tubes, it is called macaroni.

entry.ety: L. vermis a worm + caedere to kill
entry.def: A medicine which destroys intestinal worms; a worm killer.

entry.ety: L. vermis a worm
entry.def: Of or pertaining to worms; wormy.

entry.cs: Vermicular work. See under Vermiculated.
entry.ety: L. vermiculus a little worm, dim. of vermis a worm: cf. F. vermiculaire. See Vermicelli
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a worm or worms; resembling a worm; shaped like a worm; especially, resembling the motion or track of a worm; as, the vermicular, or peristaltic, motion of the intestines. See Peristaltic.
entry.q: A twisted formvermicular.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vermiculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Vermiculating
entry.ety: L. vermiculatus inlaid so as to resemble the tracks of worms, p. p. of vermiculari to be full of worms, vermiculus a little worm. See Vermicular
entry.def: To form or work, as by inlaying, with irregular lines or impressions resembling the tracks of worms, or appearing as if formed by the motion of worms.

sn.def: Wormlike in shape; covered with wormlike elevations; marked with irregular fine lines of color, or with irregular wavy impressed lines like worm tracks; as, a vermiculate nut.
Crawling or creeping like a worm; hence, insinuating; sophistical.
sn.q: Vermiculatequestions.
Vermiculatelogic.

cs.cd: rustic work so wrought as to have the appearance of convoluted worms, or of having been eaten into by, or covered with tracks of, worms.

entry.def: Made or marked with irregular wavy lines or impressions; vermiculate.

entry.ety: L. vermiculatio a being worm-eaten

sn.def: The act or operation of moving in the manner of a worm; continuation of motion from one part to another; as, the vermiculation, or peristaltic motion, of the intestines.
The act of vermiculating, or forming or inlaying so as to resemble the motion, track, or work of a worm.
Penetration by worms; the state of being wormeaten.
A very fine wavy crosswise color marking, or a patch of such markings, as on the feathers of birds.

entry.ety: L. vermiculus, dim. of vermis a worm. See Vermicular
entry.def: A small worm or insect larva; also, a wormlike body.

entry.ety: L. vermiculus, dim. of vermis worm
entry.def: A group of minerals having, a micaceous structure. They are hydrous silicates, derived generally from the alteration of some kind of mica. So called because the scales, when heated, open out into wormlike forms.

entry.ety: L. vermiculosus. See Vermicule
entry.def: Containing, or full of, worms; resembling worms.

cs.cd: a slender blind process of the cæcum in man and some other animals; -- called also vermiform appendage, and vermiform process. Small solid bodies, such as grape seeds or cherry stones, sometimes lodge in it, causing serious, or even fatal, inflammation. See Illust. under Digestion.

entry.ety: L. vermis a worm + -form
entry.def: Resembling a worm in form or motions; vermicular; as, the vermiform process of the cerebellum.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A tribe of worms including Phoronis. See Phoronis.

entry.ety: L. vermis a worm + fugare to drive away, fr. fugere to flee. See Worm, and Fugitive
entry.def: Tending to prevent, destroy, or expel, worms or vermin; anthelmintic.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vermifuge. See Vermifugal
entry.def: A medicine or substance that expels worms from animal bodies; an anthelmintic.
See Vermeil.

entries.entry: Ver`mi*lin"gui*a Ver`mi*lin"gui*a n. pl. NL., fr. L. vermis worm + lingua tongueCalled also Vermilingues Zoöl A tribe of edentates comprising the South American ant-eaters. The tongue is long, slender, exsertile, and very flexible, whence the name. A tribe of Old World lizards which comprises the chameleon. They have long, flexible tongues.

entry.note: ☞ The kermes insect has long been used for dyeing red or scarlet. It was formerly known as the worm dye vermiculus, or vermiculum, and the cloth was called vermiculatia. Hence came the French vermeil for any red dye, and hence the modern name vermilion, although the substance it denotes is very different from the kermes, being a compound of mercury and sulphur.
entry.ety: F. vermillon. See Vermeil

sn.def: A bright red pigment consisting of mercuric sulphide, obtained either from the mineral cinnabar or artificially. It has a fine red color, and is much used in coloring sealing wax, in printing, etc.
Hence, a red color like the pigment; a lively and brilliant red; as, cheeks of vermilion .

entry.def: To color with vermilion, or as if with vermilion; to dye red; to cover with a delicate red.
Vermeil.

entries.entry:
Ver"min n. sing. & pl.; used chiefly as plural. OE. vermine, F. vermine, from L. vermis a worm; cf. LL. vermen a worm, L. verminosus full of worms. See Vermicular Worm
An animal, in general. Obs Wherein were all manner of fourfooted beasts of the earth, and vermin, and worms, and fowls. This crocodile is a mischievous fourfooted beast, a dangerous vermin, used to both elements.
A noxious or mischievous animal; especially, noxious little animals or insects, collectively, as squirrels, rats, mice, worms, flies, lice, bugs, etc. Cruel hounds or some foulvermin. Great injuries these vermin, mice and rats, do in the field. They disdain such vermin when the mighty boar of the forest . . . is before them.
Hence, in contempt, noxious human beings. You are my prisoners, base vermin.

entry.ety: L. verminare to have worms, fr. vermis a worm
entry.def: To breed vermin.

entry.ety: L. verminatio the worms, a disease of animals, a crawling, itching pain

sn.def: The generation or breeding of vermin.
A griping of the bowels.

entry.def: Resembling vermin; in the manner of vermin.

entry.ety: L. verminosus, fr. vermis a worm: cf. F. vermineux

sn.def: Tending to breed vermin; infested by vermin.
sn.q: Some . . . verminous disposition of the body.

sn.def: Caused by, or arising from the presence of, vermin; as, verminous disease.

entry.def: In a verminous manner.

entry.ety: L. vermis a worm + parere to bring forth
entry.def: Producing or breeding worms.
entry.q: Vermiparousanimals.

entry.ety: L. vermis a worm + vorare to devour: cf. F. vermivore
entry.def: Devouring worms; feeding on worms; as, vermivorous birds.

entry.ety: F. vermout
entry.def: A liqueur made of white wine, absinthe, and various aromatic drugs, used to excite the appetite.
See Veronica, 1.

entry.ety: L. vernaculus born in one's house, native, fr. verna a slave born in his master's house, a native, probably akin to Skr. vas to dwell, E. was
entry.def: Belonging to the country of one's birth; one's own by birth or nature; native; indigenous; -- now used chiefly of language; as, English is our vernacular language.
entry.q: Avernaculardisease.
His skill in the vernacular dialect of the Celtic tongue.
Which in our vernacular idiom may be thus interpreted.

entry.def: The vernacular language; one's mother tongue; often, the common forms of expression in a particular locality, opposed to literary or learned forms.
A vernacular idiom.
The act or process of making vernacular, or the state of being made vernacular.
In a vernacular manner; in the vernacular.

entry.ety: L. vernaculus. See Vernacular

sn.def: Vernacular.
Scoffing; scurrilous.
sn.q: Subject to the petulancy of everyvernaculousorator.

entry.ety: It. vernaccia
entry.def: A kind of sweet wine from Italy.

cs.cd: the point of time in each year when the sun crosses the equator when proceeding northward, about March 21, when day and night are of approximately equal duration. The beginning of the Spring season.

a low, soft grass (Anthoxanthum odoratum), producing in the spring narrow spikelike panicles, and noted for the delicious fragrance which it gives to new-mown hay; -- also called sweet vernal grass. See Illust. in Appendix.
the signs, Aries, Taurus, and Gemini, in which the sun appears between the vernal equinox and summer solstice.

entry.ety: L. vernalis, fr. vernus vernal, ver spring; akin to Gr. 'e`ar, Skr. vasanta, Icel. vār, and E. Easter east

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the spring; appearing in the spring; as, vernal bloom.
sn.q: And purple all the ground with vernal flowers.

sn.def: Fig.: Belonging to youth, the spring of life.
sn.q: When after the long vernal day of life.
And seems it hard thy vernal years Few vernal joys can show?

entry.ety: L. vernans, p. pr. vernare to flourish, from ver spring
entry.def: Flourishing, as in spring; vernal.
entry.q: Vernantflowers.

entry.ety: See Vernant
entry.def: To become young again.

entry.ety: F. vernation: cf. L. vernatio the sloughing of the skin of snakes
entry.def: The arrangement of the leaves within the leaf bud, as regards their folding, coiling, rolling, etc.; prefoliation.

entries.entry: Ver"ner's law. Philol A statement, propounded by the Danish philologist Karl Verner in 1875, which explains certain apparent exceptions to Grimm's law by the original position of the accent. Primitive Indo-European k t p, became first in Teutonic h th f, and appear without further change in old Teutonic, if the accent rested on the preceding syllable; but these sounds became voiced and produced g d b, if the accent was originally on a different syllable. Similarly s either remained unchanged, or it became z and later r. Example: Skt. saptā (accent on ultima), Gr. 'e`pta, Gothic sibun (seven). Examples in English are dead by the side of death, to rise and to rear.

entry.def: A Veronica. See Veronica, 1.
entry.q: A vernicle had he sowed upon his cap.

entry.ety: See Varnish
entry.def: Having a brilliantly polished surface, as some leaves.

cs.cd: a gauge with a graduated bar and a sliding jaw bearing a vernier, used for accurate measurements.
a surveyor's compass with a vernier for the accurate adjustment of the zero point in accordance with magnetic variation.
a surveyor's transit instrument with a vernier compass.

entry.ety: So named after the inventor, Pierre Vernier
entry.def: A short scale made to slide along the divisions of a graduated instrument, as the limb of a sextant, or the scale of a barometer, for indicating parts of divisions. It is so graduated that a certain convenient number of its divisions are just equal to a certain number, either one less or one more, of the divisions of the instrument, so that parts of a division are determined by observing what line on the vernier coincides with a line on the instrument.

entry.ety: L. vernilis servile. See Vernacular
entry.def: Suiting a slave; servile; obsequious.
entry.q: The example . . . of vernile scurrility.

entry.ety: L. vernilitas
entry.def: Fawning or obsequious behavior; servility.

entry.ety: Vernal + -ine
entry.def: An alkaloid extracted from the shoots of the vetch, red clover, etc., as a white crystalline substance.
Varnish.
A glucoside extracted from the root of a South African plant of the genus Vernonia, as a deliquescent powder, and used as a mild heart tonic.

entry.ety: It. Veronese
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Verona, in Italy.

def2.def: A native of Verona; collectively, the people of Verona.

entry.note: ☞ Several herbaceous species are common in both Europe and America, most of which have small blue flowers. A few shrubby species from New Zealand are sometimes found in cultivation.
entry.ety: [LL.; -- so called from Veronica, a woman who, according to an old legend, as Christ was carrying the cross, wiped his face with a cloth, which received an impression of his countenance; Veronica is fr. MGr. Beroni`kh, fr. Macedonian Bereni`kh, for Gr. Fereni`kh, literally, carrying off victory, victorious

sn.def: A portrait or representation of the face of our Savior on the alleged handkerchief of Saint Veronica, preserved at Rome; hence, a representation of this portrait, or any similar representation of the face of the Savior. Formerly called also Vernacle, and Vernicle.
A genus of scrophulariaceous plants; the speedwell. See Speedwell.

entry.def: Very; true.

entry.ety: OF. veraiement. See Very
entry.def: Verily; truly.
See Ferrule.

entry.ety: L. verriculum a net, seine
entry.def: Having thickset tufts of parallel hairs, bristles, or branches.

entries.entry:
Ver*ru"ca Ver*ru"ca n.; pl. Verrucæ # . L. Cf. Verrugas
Med A wart.
Zoöl A wartlike elevation or roughness.

entry.ety: L. verruca wart + -form
entry.def: Shaped like a wart or warts.

entry.ety: L. verrucosus, fr. verruca a wart
entry.def: Covered with wartlike elevations; tuberculate; warty; verrucous; as, a verrucose capsule.
Verrucose.

entry.ety: L. verrucula, dim. of verruca a wart
entry.def: Minutely verrucose; as, a verruculose leaf or stalk.

entry.ety: Sp., warts. Cf. Verruca
entry.def: An endemic disease occurring in the Andes in Peru, characterized by warty tumors which ulcerate and bleed. It is probably due to a special bacillus, and is often fatal.
A verse or verses. See Verse n.
entry.q: Tenversor twelve.

entry.def: The quality or state of being versable.

entry.ety: L. versabilis: cf. F. versable. See Versatile
entry.def: Capable of being turned.
Versability.
Universal.

entry.ety: L. versans, p. pr. of versare to turn about frequently, to turn over in the mind, to meditate. See Versatile
entry.def: Familiar; conversant.
entry.q: Men not versant with courts of justice.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The slope of a side of a mountain chain; hence, the general slope of a country; aspect.

entry.ety: L. versatilis, fr. versare to turn around, v. freq. of vertere: cf. F. versatile. See Verse

sn.def: Capable of being turned round.
Liable to be turned in opinion; changeable; variable; unsteady; inconstant; as, a versatile disposition.
Turning with ease from one thing to another; readily applied to a new task, or to various subjects; many-sided; as, versatile genius; a versatile politician.
sn.q: Conspicuous among the youths of high promise . . . was the quick and versatileCharles] Montagu.

sn.def: Capable of turning; freely movable; as, a versatile anther, which is fixed at one point to the filament, and hence is very easily turned around; a versatile toe of a bird.

entry.ety: Cf. F. versatilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being versatile; versatileness.

entries.entry: Vers` de so`cié`té" Vers` de so`cié`té". F See Society verses, under Society.

entry.note: ☞ Verses are of various kinds, as hexameter pentameter tetrameter, etc., according to the number of feet in each. A verse of twelve syllables is called an Alexandrine. Two or more verses form a stanza or strophe.
☞ Although this use of verse is common, it is objectionable, because not always distinguishable from the stricter use in the sense of a line.

☞ The author of the division of the Old Testament into verses is not ascertained. The New Testament was divided into verses by Robert Stephens [or Estienne], a French printer. This arrangement appeared for the first time in an edition printed at Geneva, in 1551.
entry.cs: Blank verse poetry in which the lines do not end in rhymes. Heroic verse. See under Heroic.
entry.ety: OE. vers, AS. fers, L. versus a line in writing, and, in poetry, a verse, from vertere versum, to turn, to turn round; akin to E. worth to become: cf. F. vers. See Worth to become, and cf. Advertise Averse Controversy Convert Divers Invert Obverse Prose Suzerain Vortex

sn.def: A line consisting of a certain number of metrical feet (see Foot n., 9) disposed according to metrical rules.
Metrical arrangement and language; that which is composed in metrical form; versification; poetry.
sn.q: Such prompt eloquence Flowed from their lips in prose or numerous verse.
Virtue was taught in verse.
Verse embalms virtue.

entry.sn:
A short division of any composition. Specifically: A stanza; a stave; as, a hymn of four verses .
Script One of the short divisions of the chapters in the Old and New Testaments.
Mus A portion of an anthem to be performed by a single voice to each part.

sn.def: A piece of poetry.
sn.q: Thisversebe thine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Versed vẽrst; p. pr. & vb. n. Versing
entry.def: To tell in verse, or poetry.
entry.q: Playing on pipes of corn and versing love.

entry.def: To make verses; to versify.
entry.q: It is not rhyming and versing that maketh a poet.

entry.ety: Cf. F. versé, L. versatus, p. p. of versari to turn about frequently, to turn over, to be engaged in a thing, passive of versare. See Versant a.
entry.def: Acquainted or familiar, as the result of experience, study, practice, etc.; skilled; practiced; knowledgeable; expert.
entry.q: Deep versed in books and shallow in himself.
Opinions . . . derived from studying the Scriptures, wherein he was versed beyond any person of his age.
These men were versed in the details of business.

entry.cs: Versed sine. See under Sine, and Illust. of Functions.
entry.ety: L. versus turned, p. p. vertere. See 1st Versed
entry.def: Turned.
Same as Versemonger.
A writer of verses; especially, a writer of commonplace poetry; a poetaster; a rhymer; -- used humorously or in contempt.
A versifier.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A verse.

entry.ety: L. versiculus, dim. of versus. See Verse
entry.def: A little verse; especially, a short verse or text said or sung in public worship by the priest or minister, and followed by a response from the people.
entry.q: The psalms were in number fifteen, . . . being digested into versicles.

entry.ety: L. versicolor; versare to change + color color
entry.def: Having various colors; changeable in color.
entry.q: Versicolor, sweet-smelling flowers.

entry.ety: See Versicle
entry.def: Of or pertaining to verses; designating distinct divisions of a writing.

entry.ety: L. versificatio: cf. F. versification
entry.def: The act, art, or practice, of versifying, or making verses; the construction of poetry; metrical composition.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A versifier.
entry.q: The bestversificatornext Virgil.

sn.def: One who versifies, or makes verses; as, not every versifier is a poet.
One who converts into verse; one who expresses in verse the ideas of another written in prose; as, Dr. Watts was a versifier of the Psalms.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Versified; p. pr. & vb. n. Versifying
entry.ety: OE. versifien, F. versifier, L. versificare; versus a verse + -ficare to make. See Verse, and -fy
entry.def: To make verses.
entry.q: I'll versify in spite, and do my best.

sn.def: To relate or describe in verse; to compose in verse.
sn.q: I'll versify the truth, not poetize.

sn.def: To turn into verse; to render into metrical form; as, to versify the Psalms.

entry.ety: F., from L. vertere versum, to turn, to change, to translate. See Verse

sn.def: A change of form, direction, or the like; transformation; conversion; turning.
sn.q: The version of air into water.

sn.def: A condition of the uterus in which its axis is deflected from its normal position without being bent upon itself. See Anteversion, and Retroversion.
The act of translating, or rendering, from one language into another language.
A translation; that which is rendered from another language; as, the Common, or Authorized, Version of the Scriptures (see under Authorized); the Septuagint Version of the Old Testament.
An account or description from a particular point of view, especially as contrasted with another account; as, he gave another version of the affair.

entry.def: One who makes or favors a version; a translator.

entry.ety: L. versus, p. p. of vertere to turn: cf. F. verso
entry.def: The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet of paper; -- opposed to recto.

entry.note: ☞ The change of one vector into another is considered in quaternions as made up of two operations; 1st, the rotation of the first vector so that it shall be parallel to the second; 2d, the change of length so that the first vector shall be equal to the second. That which expresses in amount and kind the first operation is a versor, and is denoted geometrically by a line at right angles to the plane in which the rotation takes place, the length of this line being proportioned to the amount of rotation. That which expresses the second operation is a tensor. The product of the versor and tensor expresses the total operation, and is called a quaternion. See Quaternion.
entry.cs: Quadrantal versor. See under Quadrantal.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. vertere versus, to turn. See Version
entry.def: The turning factor of a quaternion.

entry.ety: Russ. versta: cf. F. verste
entry.def: A Russian measure of length containing 3,500 English feet.
Of or pertaining to a verse.

entry.ety: L., toward, turned in the direction of, from vertere versum, to turn. See Verse
entry.def: Against; as, John Doe versus Richard Roe; -- chiefly used in legal language, and abbreviated to v. or vs.

entry.ety: L. versutus, fr. vertere versum, to turn
entry.def: Crafty; wily; cunning; artful.

entry.ety: F., green, from L. viridis. See Verdant, and cf. Verd

sd.def: Everything that grows, and bears a green leaf, within the forest; as, to preserve vert and venison is the duty of the verderer.
The right or privilege of cutting growing wood.

sn.def: The color green, represented in a drawing or engraving by parallel lines sloping downward toward the right.

entry.def: A vertebra.

entries.entry:
Ver"te*bra Ver"te*bra ☞ In many fishes the vertebræ are simple cartilaginous disks or short cylinders, but in the higher vertebrates they are composed of many parts, and the vertebræ in different portions of the same column vary very greatly. A well-developed vertebra usually consists of a more or less cylindrical and solid body, or centrum, which is surmounted dorsally by an arch, leaving an opening which forms a part of the canal containing the spinal cord. From this dorsal, or neural, arch spring various processes, or apophyses, which have received special names: a dorsal, or neural, spine, spinous process, or neurapophysis, on the middle of the arch; two anterior and two posterior articular processes, or zygapophyses; and one or two transverse processes on each side. In those vertebræ which bear well-developed ribs, a tubercle near the end of the rib articulates at a tubercular facet on the transverse process (diapophysis), while the end, or head, of the rib articulates at a more ventral capitular facet which is sometimes developed into a second, or ventral, transverse process (parapophysis). In vertebrates with well-developed hind limbs, the spinal column is divided into five regions in each of which the vertebræ are specially designated: those vertebræ in front of, or anterior to, the first vertebra which bears ribs connected with the sternum are cervical; all those which bear ribs and are back of the cervicals are dorsal; the one or more directly supporting the pelvis are sacral and form the sacrum; those between the sacral and dorsal are lumbar; and all those back of the sacral are caudal, or coccygeal. In man there are seven cervical vertebræ, twelve dorsal, five lumbar, five sacral, and usually four, but sometimes five and rarely three, coccygeal. vẽr"t�*brȧ n.; pl.Vertebræ #. L. vertebra, fr. vertere to turn, change. See Verse
Anat One of the serial segments of the spinal column.
Zoöl One of the central ossicles in each joint of the arms of an ophiuran.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vertébral

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a vertebra, vertebræ, or the vertebral column; spinal; rachidian.
Vertebrate.

entry.def: A vertebrate.
At or within a vertebra or vertebræ; -- distinguished from interverterbrally.
Of or pertaining to a vertebra or vertebræ and an artery; -- said of the foramina in the transverse processes of cervical vertebræ and of the canal which they form for the vertebral artery and vein.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, comprising all animals that have a backbone composed of bony or cartilaginous vertebræ, together with Amphioxus in which the backbone is represented by a simple undivided notochord. The Vertebrata always have a dorsal, or neural, cavity above the notochord or backbone, and a ventral, or visceral, cavity below it. The subdivisions or classes of Vertebrata are Mammalia, Aves, Reptilia, Amphibia, Pisces, Marsipobranchia, and Leptocardia.
One of the Vertebrata.

entry.ety: L. vertebratus

sn.def: Having a backbone, or vertebral column, containing the spinal marrow, as man, quadrupeds, birds, amphibia, and fishes.
Contracted at intervals, so as to resemble the spine in animals.
Having movable joints resembling vertebræ; -- said of the arms of ophiurans.
Of or pertaining to the Vertebrata; -- used only in the form vertebrate.

entry.def: A vertebra.

entries.entry: Ver"te*bro-. A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to a vertebra vertebræ, or the vertebral column; as in vertebrocostal.

entry.def: Iliolumbar.

entries.entry:
Ver"tex ☞ The principal vertex of a conic section is, in the parabola, the vertex of the axis of the curve: in the ellipse, either extremity of either axis, but usually the left-hand vertex of the transverse axis; in the hyperbola, either vertex, but usually the right-hand vertex of the transverse axis.
Vertex of a curve Math the point in which the axis of the curve intersects it. Vertex of an angle Math the point in which the sides of the angle meet.
Vertex of a solidorVertex of a surface of revolution
Math the point in which the axis pierces the surface.
n.; pl. E. Vertexes #, L. Vertices #. L. vertex -icis, a whirl, top of the head, top, summit, from vertere to turn. See Verse, and cf. Vortex
A turning point; the principal or highest point; top; summit; crown; apex. Specifically:Anat The top, or crown, of the head. Astron The zenith, or the point of the heavens directly overhead. Math The point in any figure opposite to, and farthest from, the base; the terminating point of some particular line or lines in a figure or a curve; the top, or the point opposite the base.

entry.cs: Vertical angle Astron. & Geod an angle measured on a vertical circle, called an angle of elevation, or altitude, when reckoned from the horizon upward, and of depression when downward below the horizon. Vertical anthers Bot such anthers as stand erect at the top of the filaments. Vertical circle Astron an azimuth circle. See under Azimuth. Vertical drill an upright drill. See under Upright. Vertical fire Mil the fire, as of mortars, at high angles of elevation. Vertical leaves Bot leaves which present their edges to the earth and the sky, and their faces to the horizon, as in the Australian species of Eucalyptus. Vertical limb a graduated arc attached to an instrument, as a theodolite, for measuring vertical angles. Vertical line. Dialing A line perpendicular to the horizon. Conic Sections A right line drawn on the vertical plane, and passing through the vertex of the cone. Surv The direction of a plumb line; a line normal to the surface of still water. Geom., Drawing, etc A line parallel to the sides of a page or sheet, in distinction from a horizontal line parallel to the top or bottom. Vertical plane. Conic Sections A plane passing through the vertex of a cone, and through its axis. Projections Any plane which passes through a vertical line. Persp The plane passing through the point of sight, and perpendicular to the ground plane, and also to the picture. Vertical sash a sash sliding up and down. Cf. French sash, under 3d Sash. Vertical steam engine a steam engine having the crank shaft vertically above or below a vertical cylinder.
entry.ety: Cf. F. vertical. See Vertex

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the vertex; situated at the vertex, or highest point; directly overhead, or in the zenith; perpendicularly above one.
sn.q: Charity . . . is the vertical top of all religion.

sn.def: Perpendicular to the plane of the horizon; upright; plumb; as, a vertical line.

entry.cs: Prime vertical Prime vertical dial . See under Prime a.

sn.def: Vertical position; zenith.
A vertical line, plane, or circle.

entry.def: The quality or state of being vertical; verticalness.
entry.q: The different points of the verticality.

entry.def: In a vertical manner, position, or direction; perpendicularly; as, to look down vertically; to raise a thing vertically .
Quality or state of being vertical.

entry.ety: L. verticillus, dim. of vertex a whirl: cf. F. verticille. See Vertex
entry.def: A circle either of leaves or flowers about a stem at the same node; a whorl.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. verticillus a whirl + aster a star
entry.def: A whorl of flowers apparently of one cluster, but composed of two opposite axillary cymes, as in mint. See Illust. of Whorl.

entry.ety: See Verticil
entry.def: Arranged in a transverse whorl or whorls like the rays of a wheel; as, verticillate leaves of a plant; a verticillate shell.

entry.ety: L., a whirl
entry.def: A whorl; a verticil.

entry.ety: Cf. F. verticité. See Vertex
entry.def: The quality or power of turning; revolution; rotation.
entry.q: I hardly believe he hath from elder times unknown the verticity of the loadstone.

entry.ety: L. verticula a joint
entry.def: An axis; a hinge; a turning point.
Turned round; giddy.

entry.ety: L. vertiginosus, fr. vertigo a whirling around, giddiness: cf. F. vertigineux. See Vertigo

sn.def: Turning round; whirling; rotary; revolving; as, a vertiginous motion.
sn.q: Some vertiginous whirl of fortune.

sn.def: Affected with vertigo; giddy; dizzy.
sn.q: They [the angels] grew vertiginous, and fell from the battlements of heaven.

entries.entry:
Ver"ti*go ?; 277 n.; pl. E. Vertigoes #, L. Vertigines #. L., fr. vertere to turn. See Verse
Med Dizziness or swimming of the head; an affection of the head in which objects, though stationary, appear to move in various directions, and the person affected finds it difficult to maintain an erect posture; giddiness.
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of small land snails belonging to the genus Vertigo, having an elongated or conical spiral shell and usually teeth in the aperture.

entry.ety: Vertical + linear
entry.def: Straight; rectilinear.

sn.def: Virtue; power. See Virtue.
See Virtu.

entry.def: Virtuous; powerful.

entry.note: ☞ This is sometimes written .
entry.ety: NL
entry.def: An elevation, or crest, in the wall of the urethra where the seminal ducts enter it.

cs.cd: a species of mallow (Malva Alcea) with rose-colored flowers.

entry.ety: OE. verveine, F. verveine, fr. L. verbena, pl. verbenae sacred boughs of laurel, olive, or myrtle, a class of plants; cf. verbenaca vervain. Cf. Verbena
entry.def: Any plant of the genus Verbena.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit; energy.
See Varvel.
A South African monkey (Cercopithecus pygerythrus syn. Cercopithecus Lelandii). The upper parts are grayish green, finely specked with black. The cheeks and belly are reddish white.

entry.note: ☞ Very is sometimes used to make the word with which it is connected emphatic, and may then be paraphrased by same self-same itself, and the like. “The very hand, the very words.” Shak. “The very rats instinctively have quit it.” Shak. “Yea, there where very desolation dwells.” Milton. Very is used occasionally in the comparative degree, and more frequently in the superlative. “Was not my lord the verier wag of the two?” Shak. “The veriest hermit in the nation.” Pope. “He had spoken the very truth, and transformed it into the veriest falsehood.” Hawthorne.
entry.cs: Very Reverend. See the Note under Reverend.
entry.ety: OE. verai verray, OF. verai vrai, F. vrai, (assumed) LL. veracus, for L. verax true, veracious, fr. verus true; akin to OHG. & OS. wār, G. wahr, D. waar; perhaps originally, that is or exists, and akin to E. was. Cf. Aver v. t. Veracious Verdict Verity
entry.def: True; real; actual; veritable.
entry.q: Whether thou be my very son Esau or not.
He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth very friends.
The very essence of truth is plainness and brightness.
I looked on the consideration of public service or public ornament to be real and very justice.

entry.def: In a high degree; to no small extent; exceedingly; excessively; extremely; as, a very great mountain; a very bright sun; a very cold day; the river flows very rapidly; he was very much hurt.

entries.entry: Ver"y's night signalsorVer"y night signals . After Lieut. Samuel W. Very , who invented the system in 1877 Naut A system of signaling in which balls of red and green fire are fired from a pistol, the arrangement in groups denoting numbers having a code significance. The pistol used to fire the signal flare is called a Very pistol.

entry.note: It is not a recognized element. Actual identity?
entry.ety: NL., from L. Vesuvius, contr. Vesbius, Vesuvius
entry.def: A rare metallic element of which little is known. It is said by Scacchi to have been extracted from a yellowish incrustation from the cracks of a Vesuvian lava erupted in 1631.

entry.ety: Cf. Feese n.
entry.def: Onset; rush; violent draught or wind.

entry.cs: Vesica piscis. L., fish bladder Eccl. Art A glory, or aureole, of oval shape, or composed of two arcs of circles usually represented as surrounding a divine personage. More rarely, an oval composed of two arcs not representing a glory; a solid oval, etc.
entry.ety: L
entry.def: A bladder.

entry.ety: L. vesica bladder
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the bladder.

entry.ety: L. vesica blister: cf. F. vésicant
entry.def: A vesicatory.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vesicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Vesicating
entry.ety: See Vesicant
entry.def: To raise little bladders or blisters upon; to inflame and separate the cuticle of; to blister.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vésication
entry.def: The process of vesicating, or of raising blisters.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vésicatoire
entry.def: Tending, or having power, to raise a blister.

def2.def: A blistering application or plaster; a vesicant; an epispastic.

entries.entry:
Ves"i*cle n. L. vesicula, dim. of vesica a bladder, blister; akin to Skr. vasti bladder: cf. F. vésicule
A bladderlike vessel; a membranous cavity; a cyst; a cell. Specifically:Bot A small bladderlike body in the substance of a vegetable, or upon the surface of a leaf. Med A small, and more or less circular, elevation of the cuticle, containing a clear watery fluid. Anat A cavity or sac, especially one filled with fluid; as, the umbilical vesicle . Zoöl A small convex hollow prominence on the surface of a shell or a coral. Geol A small cavity, nearly spherical in form, and usually of the size of a pea or smaller, such as are common in some volcanic rocks. They are produced by the liberation of watery vapor in the molten mass.
Ves"i*co-. A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to the bladder; as in vesicoprostatic, vesicovaginal.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the bladder and the prostate gland.
Of or pertaining to the bladder and the uterus.
Of or pertaining to the bladder and the vagina.

entries.entry:
Ve*sic"u*la Ve*sic"u*la n.; pl.Vesiculæ . L., dim. of vesica
Anat. & Med A vesicle.

cs.cd: a series of nerve cells forming one of the tracts distinguished in the spinal cord; -- also called the ganglionic column.
emphysema of the lungs, in which the air vesicles are distended and their walls ruptured.
the sound, audible on auscultation of the chest, made by the air entering and leaving the air vesicles of the lungs in respiration.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vésiculaire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to vesicles; esp., of or pertaining to the air vesicles, or air cells, of the lungs; as, vesicular breathing, or normal breathing, in which the air enters freely the air vesicles of the lungs.
Containing, or composed of, vesicles or vesiclelike structures; covered with vesicles or bladders; vesiculate; as, a vesicular coral; vesicular lava; a vesicular leaf.
Having the form or structure of a vesicle; as, a vesicular body.

entry.ety: NL. See Vesicle
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of marine Bryozoa belonging to Vesicularia and allied genera. They have delicate tubular cells attached in clusters to slender flexible stems.

entry.ety: NL. See Vesicle
entry.def: The campanularian medusæ.
Bladdery; full of, or covered with, bladders; vesicular.
To form vesicles in, as lava.
The state of containing vesicles, or the process by which vesicles are formed.

entry.ety: NL.; vesicula + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of a vesicle.

entry.ety: L. vesiculosus: cf. F. vésiculeux
entry.def: Bladdery; vesicular; vesiculate; composed of vesicles; covered with vesicles; as, a vesiculose shell.

entry.ety: L., wasp
entry.def: A genus of Hymenoptera including the common wasps and hornets.

entry.ety: L., the evening, the evening star, the west; akin to Gr. "e`speros "espe`ra, and perhaps to E. west. Cf. Hesperian Vespers
entry.def: The evening star; Hesper; Venus, when seen after sunset; hence, the evening.

cs.cd: the grass finch. See under Grass.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the evening, or to the service of vespers; as, a vesper hymn; vesper bells.
Vesper; evening.

entry.cs: Sicilian vespers. See under Sicilian a.
entry.ety: OF. vespres, F. vêpres, LL. vesperae, fr. L. vespera evening. See Vesper n.
entry.def: One of the little hours of the Breviary.
The evening song or service.

entry.ety: L., a bat
entry.def: A genus of bats including some of the common small insectivorous species of North America and Europe.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A tribe of bats including the common insectivorous bats of America and Europe, belonging to Vespertilio and allied genera. They lack a nose membrane.
Of or pertaining to the Vespertiliones.
Vespertine.

entry.ety: L. vespertinus. See Vesper

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the evening; happening or being in the evening.
Blossoming in the evening.

entry.ety: L. vespa a wasp
entry.def: A nest, or habitation, of insects of the wasp kind.

entries.entry: Ves*pil"lo n.; pl.Vespilloes #. L Rom. Antiq One who carried out the dead bodies of the poor at night for burial. Like vespilloes or grave makers.

entry.cs: Acoustic vessels. See under Acoustic. Weaker vessel a woman; -- now applied humorously. “Giving honor unto the wife, as unto the weaker vessel.” 1 Peter iii. 7. “You are the weaker vessel.” Shak.
entry.ety: OF. vessel veissel vaissel vaissiel, F. vaisseau, fr. L. vascellum, dim. of vasculum, dim. of vas a vessel. Cf. Vascular Vase

sn.def: A hollow or concave utensil for holding anything; a hollow receptacle of any kind, as a hogshead, a barrel, a firkin, a bottle, a kettle, a cup, a bowl, etc.
sn.q: They drank] out of these noble vessels.

sn.def: A general name for any hollow structure made to float upon the water for purposes of navigation; especially, one that is larger than a common rowboat; as, a war vessel; a passenger vessel.
sn.q: He] began to build a vessel of huge bulk.

sn.def: Fig.: A person regarded as receiving or containing something; esp. Script, one into whom something is conceived as poured, or in whom something is stored for use; as, vessels of wrath or mercy.
sn.q: He is a chosen vessel unto me.
The serpent] fit vessel, fittest imp of fraud, in whom To enter.

sn.def: Any tube or canal in which the blood or other fluids are contained, secreted, or circulated, as the arteries, veins, lymphatics, etc.

A continuous tube formed from superposed large cylindrical or prismatic cells (tracheæ), which have lost their intervening partitions, and are usually marked with dots, pits, rings, or spirals by internal deposition of secondary membranes; a duct.

entry.def: To put into a vessel.

entries.entry: Ves"sel*ful n.; pl.Vesselfuls. As much as a vessel will hold; enough to fill a vessel.

entry.def: A kind of worsted; also, a worsted cloth.

entry.ety: F. vessigon, fr. L. vesica a bladder, blister
entry.def: A soft swelling on a horse's leg; a windgall.

entry.usage: Vest Waistcoat. In England, the original word waistcoat is generally used for the body garment worn over the shirt and immediately under the coat. In the United States this garment is commonly called a vest, and the waistcoat is often improperly given to an under-garment.
entry.ety: L. vestis a garment, vesture; akin to Goth. wasti, and E. wear: cf. F. veste. See Wear to carry on the person, and cf. Divest Invest Travesty

sn.def: An article of clothing covering the person; an outer garment; a vestment; a dress; a vesture; a robe.
sn.q: In state attended by her maiden train, Who bore the vests that holy rites require.

sn.def: Any outer covering; array; garb.
sn.q: Not seldom clothed in radiant vest Deceitfully goes forth the morn.

sn.def: Specifically, a waistcoat, or sleeveless body garment, for men, worn under the coat.
sn.syn: Garment; vesture; dress; robe; vestment; waistcoat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vested; p. pr. & vb. n. Vesting
entry.ety: Cf. L. vestire vestitum, OF. vestir, F. vêtir. See Vest n.

sn.def: To clothe with, or as with, a vestment, or garment; to dress; to robe; to cover, surround, or encompass closely.
sn.q: Came vested all in white, pure as her mind.
With ether vested, and a purple sky.

sn.def: To clothe with authority, power, or the like; to put in possession; to invest; to furnish; to endow; -- followed by with before the thing conferred; as, to vest a court with power to try cases of life and death.
sn.q: Had I been vested with the monarch's power.

sn.def: To place or give into the possession or discretion of some person or authority; to commit to another; -- with in before the possessor; as, the power of life and death is vested in the king, or in the courts.
sn.q: Empire and dominion was [werevested in him.

sn.def: To invest; to put; as, to vest money in goods, land, or houses.
To clothe with possession; as, to vest a person with an estate; also, to give a person an immediate fixed right of present or future enjoyment of; as, an estate is vested in possession.
