entry.q: Of such matter made he many lays, Songs, complains, roundels, virelayes.
To which a lady sung a virelay.

entry.ety: L. virens, p. pr. of virere to be green
entry.def: Green; not withered.

entry.note: ☞ In the Eastern United States the most common species are the white-eyed vireo (Vireo Noveboracensis), the red-eyed vireo (Vireo olivaceus), the blue-headed, or solitary, vireo (Vireo solitarius), the warbling vireo (Vireo gilvus), and the yellow-throated vireo (Vireo flavifrons). All these are noted for the sweetness of their songs.
entry.ety: L., a species of bird
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of American singing birds belonging to Vireo and allied genera of the family Vireonidæ. In many of the species the back is greenish, or olive-colored. Called also greenlet.
The act or state of becoming green through the formation of chlorophyll.

entry.ety: L. virescens, p. pr. of virescere to grow green, verb incho. fr. virere to be green
entry.def: Beginning to be green; slightly green; greenish.

entry.ety: F. See Vire
entry.def: An arrow or bolt for a crossbow having feathers or brass placed at an angle with the shaft to make it spin in flying.

entry.ety: Cf. Virgouleuse
entry.def: A valuable kind of pear, of an obovate shape and with melting flesh of delicious flavor; -- more properly called White Doyenné.

entry.ety: L. virgatus made of twigs, fr. virga a twig, rod. See Verge a rod
entry.def: Having the form of a straight rod; wand-shaped; straight and slender.

entry.ety: LL. virgata virgata terrae, so much land as virga terrae, a land measure, contains, fr. L. virga a twig, rod
entry.def: A yardland, or measure of land varying from fifteen to forty acres.

entry.ety: L. virgatus striped. See Virgate a.
entry.def: Striped; streaked.
A wand. See Verge.
See Verger.

entry.ety: L. Virgilianus, better Vergilianus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Virgil, the Roman poet; resembling the style of Virgil.
entry.q: The rich Virgilian rustic measure Of Lari Maxume.

cs.cd: the Virgin Mary, the Mother of Jesus Christ.
a name given to several climbing plants of the genus Clematis, as Clematis Vitalba of Europe, and Clematis Virginiana of North America.

entry.ety: L. virgo -inis: cf. OF. virgine virgene virge vierge, F. vierge

sn.def: A woman who has had no carnal knowledge of man; a maid.
A person of the male sex who has not known sexual indulgence.
sn.q: These are they which were not defiled with women; for they are virgins.
He his flesh hath overcome; He was a virgin, as he said.

sn.def: See Virgo.
Any one of several species of gossamer-winged butterflies of the family Lycænidæ.
A female insect producing eggs from which young are hatched, though there has been no fecundation by a male; a parthenogenetic insect.
Being a virgin; chaste; of or pertaining to a virgin; becoming a virgin; maidenly; modest; indicating modesty; as, a virgin blush.
sn.q: Virginshame.
Innocence and virgin modesty . . . That would be wooed, and unsought be won.

sn.def: Pure; undefiled; unmixed; fresh; new; as, virgin soil; virgin gold.
sn.q: VirginDutch.
The white cold virgin snow upon my heart.
A few ounces of mutton, with a little virgin oil.

sn.def: Not yet pregnant; impregnant.

entry.def: To act the virgin; to be or keep chaste; -- followed by it. See It, 5.
entry.q: My true lip hathvirginedit e'er since [that kiss].

cs.cd: parthenogenesis.
the hymen.

entry.ety: L. virginalis: cf. F. virginal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a virgin; becoming a virgin; maidenly.
entry.q: Chastity and honorvirginal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. virginale; -- probably so called from being used by young girls, or virgins
entry.def: An instrument somewhat resembling the spinet, but having a rectangular form, like the small piano. It had strings and keys, but only one wire to a note. The instrument was used in the sixteenth century, but is now wholly obsolete. It was sometimes called a pair of virginals.
To play with the fingers, as if on a virginal; to tap or pat.
entry.q: Stillvirginalingupon his palm!

entry.def: Virginity; maidenhood.

entry.cs: Virginia cowslip Bot the American lungwort (Mertensia Virginica). Virginia creeper Bot a common ornamental North American woody vine (Ampelopsis quinquefolia), climbing extensively by means of tendrils; -- called also woodbine, and American ivy. U. S Virginia fence. See Worm fence, under Fence. Virginia nightingale Zoöl the cardinal bird. See under Cardinal. Virginia quail Zoöl the bobwhite. Virginia reel an old English contradance; -- so called in the United States. Bartlett. Virginia stock. Bot See Mahon stock.
entry.def: One of the States of the United States of America.

def2.def: Of or pertaining to the State of Virginia.

entry.ety: OE. virgintee, F. virginité, L. virginitas

sn.def: The quality or state of being a virgin; undefiled purity or chastity; maidenhood.
The unmarried life; celibacy.

entry.ety: L. virgo a virgin, the constellation Virgo in the zodiac. See Virgin
entry.def: A sign of the zodiac which the sun enters about the 21st of August, marked thus [♍] in almanacs.
A constellation of the zodiac, now occupying chiefly the sign Libra, and containing the bright star Spica.

entry.ety: F. virgouleuse, from the village of Virgoulée, near Limoges
entry.def: An old French variety of pear, of little value.

entry.ety: From. L. virgula a small rod
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of long, slender Alcyonaria belonging to Virgularia and allied genera of the family Virgularidæ. These corals are allied to the sea-pens, but have a long rodlike rhachis inclosing a slender, round or square, calcareous axis. The polyps are arranged in transverse rows or clusters along each side of the rhachis.
Shaped like a little twig or rod.

entry.ety: F. virgule, fr. L. virgula, dim. of virga. See Verge a rod
entry.def: A comma.
entry.q: In the MSS. of Chaucer, the line is always broken by a cæsura in the middle, which is pointed by a virgule.

entry.ety: L. vis viris, force
entry.def: A certain function relating to a system of forces and their points of application, -- first used by Clausius in the investigation of problems in molecular physics.

entry.ety: L. viridis green. See Verdant
entry.def: Green.
entry.q: The virid marjoram Her sparkling beauty did but see.

entry.def: Quality or state of being viridescent.

entry.ety: L. viridescens, p. pr. of viridescere to grow green
entry.def: Slightly green; greenish.

entry.ety: L. viridis green
entry.def: A greenish, oily, nitrogenous hydrocarbon, C12H19N7, obtained from coal tar, and probably consisting of a mixture of several metameric compounds which are higher derivatives of the base pyridine.

entry.ety: L. viridis green
entry.def: A greenish chloritic mineral common in certain igneous rocks, as diabase, as a result of alternation.

entry.ety: L. viriditas, fr. viridis green: cf. F. viridité. See Verdant

sn.def: Greenness; verdure; the color of grass and foliage.
Freshness; soundness.

entry.def: Viridity; greenness.

entry.ety: L. virilis, fr. vir a man; akin to AS. wer: cf. F. viril. See Werewolf World, and cf. Decemvir Virago Virtue
entry.def: Having the nature, properties, or qualities, of an adult man; characteristic of developed manhood; hence, masterful; forceful; specifically, capable of begetting; -- opposed to womanly feminine, and puerile; as, virile age, virile power, virile organs.

entry.ety: L. virilitas: cf. F. virilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being virile; developed manhood; manliness; specif., the power of procreation; as, exhaustion.
entry.q: Virilityof visage.

entry.ety: L. vir man + potens fit for
entry.def: Developed in manhood; hence, able to beget; marriageable.
entry.q: Being not of ripe years, not viripotent.

entry.def: See Vermilion.

entry.ety: F., a ferrule. See Ferrule
entry.def: A ring surrounding a bugle or hunting horn.
Furnished with a virole or viroles; -- said of a horn or a bugle when the rings are of different tincture from the rest of the horn.

entry.ety: L. virosus. See Virus
entry.def: Having a nauseous odor; fetid; poisonous.

cs.mcol: An article of virtuora piece of virtu
cs.cd: an object of art or antiquity; a curiosity, such as those found in museums or private collections.

entry.ety: It. virtù virtue, excellence, from L. virtus. See Virtue
entry.def: A love of the fine arts; a taste for curiosities.
entry.q: I had thoughts, in my chambers to place it in view, To be shown to my friends as a piece of virtù.

entry.cs: Principle of virtual velocities Mech the law that when several forces are in equilibrium, the algebraic sum of their virtual moments is equal to zero. Virtual focus Opt the point from which rays, having been rendered divergent by reflection of refraction, appear to issue; the point at which converging rays would meet if not reflected or refracted before they reach it. Virtual image. Optics See under Image. Virtual momentof a forceMech the product of the intensity of the force multiplied by the virtual velocity of its point of application; -- sometimes called virtual work. Virtual velocity Mech a minute hypothetical displacement, assumed in analysis to facilitate the investigation of statical problems. With respect to any given force of a number of forces holding a material system in equilibrium, it is the projection, upon the direction of the force, of a line joining its point of application with a new position of that point indefinitely near to the first, to which the point is conceived to have been moved, without disturbing the equilibrium of the system, or the connections of its parts with each other. Strictly speaking, it is not a velocity but a length. Virtual work. Mech See Virtual moment, above.
entry.ety: Cf. F. virtuel. See Virtue

sn.def: Having the power of acting or of invisible efficacy without the agency of the material or sensible part; potential; energizing.
sn.q: Heat and cold have a virtual transition, without communication of substance.
Every kind that lives, Fomented by his virtual power, and warmed.

sn.def: Being in essence or effect, not in fact; as, the virtual presence of a man in his agent or substitute.
sn.q: A thing has a virtual existence when it has all the conditions necessary to its actual existence.
To mask by slight differences in the manners a virtual identity in the substance.

entry.ety: Cf. F. virtualité

sn.def: The quality or state of being virtual.
Potentiality; efficacy; potential existence.
sn.q: In one grain of corn, there lieth dormant a virtuality of many other.

entry.def: In a virtual manner; in efficacy or effect only, and not actually; to all intents and purposes; practically.
To make efficacious; to give virtue of efficacy.

entry.cs:
Cardinal virtues. See under Cardinal a.
In virtue oforBy virtue of
through the force of; by authority of. “He used to travel through Greece by virtue of this fable, which procured him reception in all the towns.” Addison. “This they shall attain, partly in virtue of the promise made by God, and partly in virtue of piety.” Atterbury. Theological virtues the three virtues, faith, hope, and charity. See 1 Cor. xiii. 13.
entry.ety: OE. vertu, F. vertu, L. virtus strength, courage, excellence, virtue, fr. vir a man. See Virile, and cf. Virtu

sn.def: Manly strength or courage; bravery; daring; spirit; valor.
sn.q: Built too strong For force or virtue ever to expugn.

sn.def: Active quality or power; capacity or power adequate to the production of a given effect; energy; strength; potency; efficacy; as, the virtue of a medicine.
sn.q: Jesus, immediately knowing in himself that virtue had gone out of him, turned him about.
A man was driven to depend for his security against misunderstanding, upon the pure virtue of his syntax.
The virtue of his midnight agony.

sn.def: Energy or influence operating without contact of the material or sensible substance.
sn.q: She moves the body which she doth possess, Yet no part toucheth, but by virtue's touch.

sn.def: Excellence; value; merit; meritoriousness; worth.
sn.q: I made virtue of necessity.
In the Greek poets, . . . the economy of poems is better observed than in Terence, who thought the sole grace and virtue of their fable the sticking in of sentences.

sn.def: Specifically, moral excellence; integrity of character; purity of soul; performance of duty.
sn.q: Virtue only makes our bliss below.
If there's Power above us, And that there is all nature cries aloud Through all her works, he must delight in virtue.

sn.def: A particular moral excellence; as, the virtue of temperance, of charity, etc.
sn.q: The veryvirtueof compassion.
Remember all hisvirtues.

sn.def: Specifically: Chastity; purity; especially, the chastity of women; virginity.
sn.q: H. I believe the girl has virtue.M. And if she has, I should be the last man in the world to attempt to corrupt it.

sn.def: One of the orders of the celestial hierarchy.
sn.q: Thrones, dominations, princedoms, virtues, powers.

entry.def: Destitute of virtue; without efficacy or operating qualities; powerless.
entry.q: Virtueless she wished all herbs and charms.

sn.def: The quality or state of being a virtuoso; in a bad sense, the character of one in whom mere artistic feeling or æsthetic cultivation takes the place of religious character; sentimentalism.
sn.q: This famous passage . . . over which the virtuosity of modern times, rejoicing in evil, has hung so fondly.

sn.def: Virtuosos, collectively.
An art or study affected by virtuosos.

entries.entry:
Vir`tu*o"so n.; pl.Virtuosos #; It. Virtuosi #. It. See Virtuous
One devoted to virtu; one skilled in the fine arts, in antiquities, and the like; a collector or ardent admirer of curiosities, etc.
Virtuoso the Italians call a man who loves the noble arts, and is a critic in them.
Mus A performer on some instrument, as the violin or the piano, who excels in the technical part of his art; a brilliant concert player.

entry.def: The condition, pursuits, or occupation of a virtuoso.

entry.ety: OE. vertuous, OF. vertuos vertuous, F. vertueux, fr. L. Virtuous. See Virtue, and cf. Virtuoso
entry.sn:
Possessing or exhibiting virtue. Specifically: Exhibiting manly courage and strength; valorous; valiant; brave. Obs Old Priam's son, amongst them all, was chiefly virtuous.
Having power or efficacy; powerfully operative; efficacious; potent. Obs Lifting up his virtuous staff on high, He smote the sea, which calméd was with speed. Every virtuous plant and healing herb.
Having moral excellence; characterized by morality; upright; righteous; pure; as, a virtuous action. The virtuous mind that ever walks attended By a strong siding champion, conscience.

sn.def: Chaste; pure; -- applied especially to women.
sn.q: Mistress Ford . . . the virtuous creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband.

entry.ety: Cf. F. virulence, L. virulentia an offensive odor, a stench

sn.def: The quality or state of being virulent or venomous; poisonousness; malignancy.
Extreme bitterness or malignity of disposition.
sn.q: Refuted without satiricalvirulency.
The virulence of one declaimer, or the profundities and sublimities of the other.

entry.ety: L. virulentus, fr. virus poison: cf. F. virulent. See Virus

sn.def: Extremely poisonous or venomous; very active in doing injury.
sn.q: A contagious disorder rendered more virulent by uncleanness.

sn.def: Very bitter in enmity; actuated by a desire to injure; malignant; as, a virulent invective.

entry.def: Made virulent; poisoned.
In a virulent manner.

entry.ety: L., a slimy liquid, a poisonous liquid, poison, stench; akin to Gr. � poison, Skr. visha. Cf. Wizen v. i.

sn.def: Contagious or poisonous matter, as of specific ulcers, the bite of snakes, etc.; -- applied to organic poisons.
the causative agent of a disease, .

any of numerous submicroscopic complex organic objects which have genetic material and may be considered as living organisms but have no proper cell membrane, and thus cannot by themselves perform metabolic processes, requiring entry into a host cell in order to multiply. The simplest viruses have no lipid envelope and may be considered as complex aggregates of molecules, sometimes only a nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) and a coat protein. They are sometimes viewed as being on the borderline between living and nonliving objects. They are smaller than living cells in size, usually between 20 and 300 nm; thus they pass through standard filters, and were previously referred to as filterable virus. The manifestations of disease caused by multiplication of viruses in cells may be due to destruction of the cells caused by subversion of the cellular metabolic processes by the virus, or by synthesis of a virus-specific toxin. Viruses may infect animals, plants, or microorganisms; those infecting bacteria are also called bacteriophages. Certain bacteriophages may be non-destructive and benign in the host; -- see bacteriophage.
Fig.: Any morbid corrupting quality in intellectual or moral conditions; something that poisons the mind or the soul; as, the virus of obscene books.

a program or segment of program code that may make copies of itself (replicate), attach itself to other programs, and perform unwanted actions within a computer; also called computer virus or virus program. Such programs are almost always introduced into a computer without the knowledge or assent of its owner, and are often malicious, causing destructive actions such as erasing data on disk, but sometime only annoying, causing peculiar objects to appear on the display. The form of sociopathic mental disease that causes a programmer to write such a program has not yet been given a name. Compare trojan horse{3.

entry.cs:
Principle of vis viva Mech the principle that the difference between the aggregate work of the accelerating forces of a system and that of the retarding forces is equal to one half the vis viva accumulated or lost in the system while the work is being done. Vis impressa L Mech force exerted, as in moving a body, or changing the direction of its motion; impressed force. Vis inertiæ. L The resistance of matter, as when a body at rest is set in motion, or a body in motion is brought to rest, or has its motion changed, either in direction or in velocity. Inertness; inactivity.
Vis intertiæ and inertia are not strictly synonymous. The former implies the resistance itself which is given, while the latter implies merely the property by which it is given. Vis mortua L Mech dead force; force doing no active work, but only producing pressure.
Vis vitæorVis vitalis
L Physiol vital force. Vis viva L Mech living force; the force of a body moving against resistance, or doing work, in distinction from vis mortua, or dead force; the kinetic energy of a moving body; the capacity of a moving body to do work by reason of its being in motion. See Kinetic energy, in the Note under Energy. The term vis viva is not usually understood to include that part of the kinetic energy of the body which is due to the vibrations of its molecules.

sn.def: Force; power.

sd.def: Physical force.
Moral power.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Vis�.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Visaed; p. pr. & vb. n. Visaing
entry.def: To indorse, after examination, with the word visé, as a passport; to visé.

entry.ety: F. visage, from L. visus a seeing, a look, fr. videre visum, to see. See Vision
entry.def: The face, countenance, or look of a person or an animal; -- chiefly applied to the human face.
entry.q: Avisageof demand.
His visage was so marred more than any man.
Love and beauty still that visage grace.

entry.def: To face.
Having a visage.
A mask. See Visor.
To mask.

entry.ety: F., opposite, face to face

sn.def: One who, or that which, is face to face with another; esp., one who faces another in dancing.
A carriage in which two persons sit face to face. Also, a form of sofa with seats for two persons, so arranged that the occupants are face to face while sitting on opposite sides.

entry.def: Face to face.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. Bisayo a Visayan
entry.def: A member of the most numerous of the native races of the Philippines, occupying the Visayan Islands and the northern coast Mindanao; also, their language. The Visayans possessed a native culture and alphabet.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: A large burrowing South American rodent (Lagostomus trichodactylus) allied to the chinchillas, but much larger. Its fur is soft and rather long, mottled gray above, white or yellowish white beneath. There is a white band across the muzzle, and a dark band on each cheek. It inhabits grassy plains, and is noted for its extensive burrows and for heaping up miscellaneous articles at the mouth of its burrows. Called also biscacha bizcacha vischacha vishatscha.
pl. of Viscus.

cs.cd: the bars or ridges between the visceral clefts.
the ventral cavity of a vertebrate, which contains the alimentary canal, as distinguished from the dorsal, or cerebro-spinal, canal.
transverse clefts on the sides just back of the mouth in the vertebrate embryo, which open into the pharyngeal portion of the alimentary canal, and correspond to the branchial clefts in adult fishes.

entry.ety: Cf. F. viscéral, LL. visceralis

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or affecting the viscera; splanchnic.
Fig.: Having deep sensibility.
proceeding from emotion or instinct rather than from intellect; deeply emotional;as, a visceral reaction.
dealing with coarse or base emotions;as, a visceral literary style.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Viscerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Viscerating
entry.def: To deprive of the viscera, or entrails; to eviscerate; to disembowel.
Of or pertaining to the framework, or skeleton, or skeleton, of the viscera; as, the visceroskeletal system of muscles.

entry.ety: L. viscidus, fr. viscum the mistletoe, birdlime made from the berries of the mistletoe; akin to Gr. �: cf. F. viscide
entry.def: Sticking or adhering, and having a ropy or glutinous consistency; viscous; glutinous; sticky; tenacious; clammy; as, turpentine, tar, gums, etc., are more or less viscid.

entry.ety: Cf. F. viscidité
entry.def: The quality or state of being viscid; also, that which is viscid; glutinous concretion; stickiness.
A clear, viscous, tasteless substance extracted from the mucilaginous sap of the mistletoe (Viscum album), holly, etc., and constituting an essential ingredient of birdlime.
Somewhat viscous. Cf. Mobile a., 2.

entry.ety: Viscosity + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the degree of viscosity of liquids, as solutions of gum.

entry.ety: Cf. F. viscosité, LL. viscositas

sn.def: The quality or state of being viscous.

A property possessed by a viscous fluid, being a resistance to the forces causing a fluid to flow, caused by interactions between the molecules of the fluid and between the fluid and the walls of the conduit through which it moves; also, a measure of such a property.

entry.ety: OE. vicounte, OF. visconte vescunte, F. vicomte, LL. vicecomes; L. vicesee Vice a.) + comes a companion, LL., a count. See Count

sn.def: An officer who formerly supplied the place of the count, or earl; the sheriff of the county.
A nobleman of the fourth rank, next in order below an earl and next above a baron; also, his degree or title of nobility. See Peer n., 3.

entry.def: The dignity or jurisdiction of a viscount.

entry.ety: F. vicomtesse, LL. vicecomitissa
entry.def: The wife of a viscount.

entry.ety: F. vicomté
entry.def: The quality, rank, or office of a viscount.

entry.note: ☞ There is no well-defined distinction in meaning between viscous and viscid.
entry.ety: L. viscosus. See Viscid
entry.def: Adhesive or sticky, and having a ropy or glutinous consistency; viscid; glutinous; clammy; tenacious; as, a viscous juice.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: A genus of parasitic shrubs, including the mistletoe of Europe.
Birdlime, which is often made from the berries of the European mistletoe.

entries.entry:
Vis"cus Vis"cus n.; pl.Viscera #. L., perhaps akin to E. viscid
Anat One of the organs, as the brain, heart, or stomach, in the great cavities of the body of an animal; -- especially used in the plural, and applied to the organs contained in the abdomen.

entry.ety: F. vis a screw, winding stairs, OF. vis viz, fr. L. vitis a vine; probably akin to E. withy
entry.def: An instrument consisting of two jaws, closing by a screw, lever, cam, or the like, for holding work, as in filing.

entry.ety: F. visé, p. p. of viser to put a visa to, fr. L. visus seen, p. p. of videre to see
entry.def: An indorsement made on a passport by the proper authorities of certain countries on the continent of Europe, denoting that it has been examined, and that the person who bears it is permitted to proceed on his journey; a visa.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Viséed; p. pr. & vb. n. Viséing
entry.def: To examine and indorse, as a passport; to visa.

entry.ety: Skr. Vishṇu, from vish to pervade., to extend through nature
entry.def: A divinity of the modern Hindu trimurti, or trinity. He is regarded as the preserver, while Brahma is the creator, and Siva the destroyer of the creation.

entry.ety: L. visibilitas: cf. F. visibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being visible.

entry.cs: Visible church Theol the apparent church of Christ on earth; the whole body of professed believers in Christ, as contradistinguished from the invisible, or real, church, consisting of sanctified persons. Visible horizon. Same as Apparent horizon, under Apparent.
entry.ety: L. visibilis, fr. videre visum, to see: cf. F. visible. See Vision

sn.def: Perceivable by the eye; capable of being seen; perceptible; in view; as, a visible star; the least spot is visible on white paper.
sn.q: Maker of heaven and earth, and of all things visible and invisible.
Virtue made visible in outward grace.

sn.def: Noticeable; apparent; open; conspicuous.
sn.q: The factions at court were greater, or more visible, than before.

entries.entry: Vis"i*ble speech". Phon A system of characters invented by Prof. Alexander Melville Bell to represent all sounds that may be uttered by the speech organs, and intended to be suggestive of the position of the organs of speech in uttering them.

entry.ety: L. Visegothae, pl. Cf. West, and Goth
entry.def: One of the West Goths. See the Note under Goth.

entry.cs:
Arc of vision Astron the arc which measures the least distance from the sun at which, when the sun is below the horizon, a star or planet emerging from his rays becomes visible. Beatific vision Theol the immediate sight of God in heaven. Direct vision Opt vision when the image of the object falls directly on the yellow spot (see under Yellow); also, vision by means of rays which are not deviated from their original direction. Field of vision field of view. See under Field. Indirect vision Opt vision when the rays of light from an object fall upon the peripheral parts of the retina.
Reflected visionorRefracted vision
vision by rays reflected from mirrors, or refracted by lenses or prisms, respectively. Vision purple. Physiol See Visual purple, under Visual.
entry.ety: OE. visioun, F. vision, fr. L. visio, from videre visum, to see: akin to Gr. � to see, � I know, and E. wit. See Wit v., and cf. Advice Clairvoyant Envy Evident Provide Revise Survey View Visage Visit

sn.def: The act of seeing external objects; actual sight.
sn.q: Faith here is turned into vision there.

sn.def: The faculty of seeing; sight; one of the five senses, by which colors and the physical qualities of external objects are appreciated as a result of the stimulating action of light on the sensitive retina, an expansion of the optic nerve.
That which is seen; an object of sight.

Especially, that which is seen otherwise than by the ordinary sight, or the rational eye; a supernatural, prophetic, or imaginary sight; an apparition; a phantom; a specter; as, the visions of Isaiah.
sn.q: The baseless fabric of this vision.
No dreams, but visions strange.

sn.def: Hence, something unreal or imaginary; a creation of fancy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Visioned; p. pr. & vb. n. Visioning
entry.def: To see in a vision; to dream.
entry.q: For them no visioned terrors daunt, Their nights no fancied specters haunt.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a vision.
The quality or state of being visionary.

entry.ety: Cf. F. visionnaire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a visions or visions; characterized by, appropriate to, or favorable for, visions.
sn.q: The visionary hour When musing midnight reigns.

sn.def: Affected by phantoms; disposed to receive impressions on the imagination; given to reverie; apt to receive, and act upon, fancies as if they were realities.
sn.q: Or lull to rest the visionary maid.

sn.def: Existing in imagination only; not real; fanciful; imaginary; having no solid foundation; as, visionary prospect; a visionary scheme or project.
sn.syn: Fanciful; fantastic; unreal. See Fanciful.

entries.entry:
Vi"sion*a*ry n.; pl.Visionaries.
One whose imagination is disturbed; one who sees visions or phantoms.
One whose imagination overpowers his reason and controls his judgment; an unpractical schemer; one who builds castles in the air; a daydreamer.

entry.def: Having the power of seeing visions; inspired; also, seen in visions.
A visionary.
Destitute of vision; sightless.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Visited; p. pr. & vb. n. Visiting
entry.ety: F. visiter, L. visitare, fr. visere to go to see, to visit, fr. videre visum to see. See Vision.

sn.def: To go or come to see, as for the purpose of friendship, business, curiosity, etc.; to attend; to call upon; as, the physician visits his patient.

entry.sn: Specifically: To go or come to see for inspection, examination, correction of abuses, etc.; to examine, to inspect; as, a bishop visits his diocese; a superintendent visits persons or works under his charge.

sn.def: To come to for the purpose of chastising, rewarding, comforting; to come upon with reward or retribution; to appear before or judge; as, to visit in mercy; to visit one in wrath.
sn.q: God] hath visited and redeemed his people.

entry.def: To make a visit or visits; to maintain visiting relations; to practice calling on others.

cs.cd: the right of visitation. See Visitation, 4.

entry.ety: Cf. F. visite. See Visit v. t., and cf. Visite

sn.def: The act of visiting, or going to see a person or thing; a brief stay of business, friendship, ceremony, curiosity, or the like, usually longer than a call; as, a visit of civility or respect; a visit to Saratoga; the visit of a physician.
The act of going to view or inspect; an official or formal inspection; examination; visitation; as, the visit of a trustee or inspector.

entry.def: Liable or subject to be visited or inspected.
entry.q: All hospitals built since the Reformation arevisitableby the king or lord chancellor.

entry.ety: L. visitans -antis; p. pr.: cf. F. visitant
entry.def: One who visits; a guest; a visitor.
entry.q: When the visitant comes again, he is no more a stranger.

entry.def: Visiting.

cs.col: The Order of the Visitation of Our Lady
cs.cd: a religious community of nuns, founded at Annecy, in Savoy, in 1610, and in 1808 established in the United States. In America these nuns are devoted to the education of girls.

entry.ety: L. visitatio: cf. F. visitation

sn.def: The act of visiting, or the state of being visited; access for inspection or examination.
sn.q: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

sn.def: Specifically: The act of a superior or superintending officer who, in the discharge of his office, visits a corporation, college, etc., to examine into the manner in which it is conducted, and see that its laws and regulations are duly observed and executed; as, the visitation of a diocese by a bishop.
The object of a visit.
sn.q: O flowers, . . . my earlyvisitationand my last.

sn.def: The act of a naval commander who visits, or enters on board, a vessel belonging to another nation, for the purpose of ascertaining her character and object, but without claiming or exercising a right of searching the vessel. It is, however, usually coupled with the right of searchsee under Search), visitation being used for the purpose of search.
Special dispensation; communication of divine favor and goodness, or, more usually, of divine wrath and vengeance; retributive calamity; retribution; judgment.
sn.q: What will ye do in the day of visitation?

sn.def: A festival in honor of the visit of the Virgin Mary to Elisabeth, mother of John the Baptist, celebrated on the second of July.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. visitator a bishop temporarily put in place of another
entry.def: Of or pertaining to visitation, or a judicial visitor or superintendent; visitorial.
entry.q: An archdeacon has visitatorial power.
The queen, however, still had over the church a visitatorial power of vast and undefined extent.

entry.ety: F. See Visit n.
entry.def: A light cape or short cloak of silk or lace worn by women in summer.
A visitor.

entry.cs: Visiting ant. Zoöl See Driver ant, under Driver. Visiting book a book in which a record of visits received, made, and to be made, is kept. Thackeray. Visiting card. See under Card.
entry.def: a. & vb. n. from Visit.

entries.entry:
Vis"it*or. Cf. F. visiteur
visiter
One who visits; one who comes or goes to see another, as in civility or friendship. This great flood ofvisitors.
A superior, or a person lawfully appointed for the purpose, who makes formal visits of inspection to a corporation or an institution. See Visit v. t., 2, and Visitation n., 2. The king is the visitor of all lay corporations.

entry.def: Same as Visitatorial.

entry.ety: Cf. F. visif, LL. visivus. See Vision
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the sight; visual.
entry.q: I can not satisfy myself how men should be so little surprised about this visive faculty.

entries.entry: Vis ma"jor Vis ma"jor. L. major greater Law A superior force which under certain circumstances is held to exempt from contract obligations; inevitable accident; -- a civil-law term used as nearly equivalent to, but broader than, the common-law term act of Godwhich see).

entry.ety: OF. visné veisiné visnet, neighborhood, LL. vicinatus, fr. L. vicunus neighboring, a neighbor. See Vicinity
entry.def: Neighborhood; vicinity; venue. See Venue.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. physiognomy
entry.def: Face; countenance.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The mink.

entry.ety: OE. visere, F. visière, fr. OF. vis. See Visage Vision

sn.def: A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.
A mask used to disfigure or disguise.
sn.q: My veryvisorbegan to assume life.
My weaker government since, makes you pull off the visor.

sn.def: The fore piece of a cap, projecting over, and protecting the eyes.

entry.def: Wearing a visor; masked.
entry.q: Visored falsehood and base forgery.

entries.entry:
Vis"ta n.; pl.Vistas #. It., sight, view, fr. vedere, p. p. visto veduto, to see, fr. L. videre visum. See View Vision
A view; especially, a view through or between intervening objects, as trees; a view or prospect through an avenue, or the like; hence, the trees or other objects that form the avenue. The finished garden to the view Its vistas opens, and its alleys green. In the groves of their academy, at the end of every vista, you see nothing but the gallows. The shattered tower which now forms a vista from his window.

entry.def: A vista; a prospect.
entry.q: Through the long visto of a thousand years.

entry.cs: Visual angle. Opt See under Angle. Visual cone Persp a cone whose vertex is at the point of sight, or the eye. Visual plane any plane passing through the point of sight. Visual point the point at which the visual rays unite; the position of the eye. Visual purple Physiol a photochemical substance, of a purplish red color, contained in the retina of human eyes and in the eyes of most animals. It is quickly bleached by light, passing through the colors, red, orange, and yellow, and then disappearing. Also called rhodopsin, and vision purple. See Optography. Visual ray a line from the eye, or point of sight. Visual white Physiol the final product in the action of light on visual purple. It is reconverted into visual purple by the regenerating action of the choroidal epithelium. Visual yellow Physiol a product intermediate between visual purple and visual white, formed in the photochemical action of light on visual purple.
entry.ety: L. visualis, from visus a seeing, sight: cf. F. visuel. See Vision

sn.def: Of or pertaining to sight; used in sight; serving as the instrument of seeing; as, the visual nerve.
sn.q: The air, Nowhere so clear, sharpened his visual ray.

sn.def: That can be seen; visible.
To make visual, or visible.
to see in the imagination; to form a mental image of.
sn.q: No one who has not seen them [glaciers] can possibly visualize them.

entry.def: To form a mental image of something not present before the eye at the time.
One who visualizes or is proficient in visualization;
one whose mental imagery is prevailingly visualization.

entry.ety: See Victuals
entry.def: Food; victuals.

entry.cs: Vital air oxygen gas; -- so called because essential to animal life. Obs Vital capacity Physiol the breathing capacity of the lungs; -- expressed by the number of cubic inches of air which can be forcibly exhaled after a full inspiration. Vital force. Biol See under Force. The vital forces, according to Cope, are nerve force (neurism), growth force (bathmism), and thought force (phrenism), all under the direction and control of the vital principle. Apart from the phenomena of consciousness, vital actions no longer need to be considered as of a mysterious and unfathomable character, nor vital force as anything other than a form of physical energy derived from, and convertible into, other well-known forces of nature. Vital functions Physiol those functions or actions of the body on which life is directly dependent, as the circulation of the blood, digestion, etc. Vital principle an immaterial force, to which the functions peculiar to living beings are ascribed. Vital statistics statistics respecting the duration of life, and the circumstances affecting its duration. Vital tripod. Physiol See under Tripod. Vital vessels Bot a name for latex tubes, now disused. See Latex.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. vitalis, fr. vita life; akin to vivere to live. See Vivid

sn.def: Belonging or relating to life, either animal or vegetable; as, vital energies; vital functions; vital actions.
Contributing to life; necessary to, or supporting, life; as, vital blood.
sn.q: Do the heavens afford him vital food?
And vital virtue infused, and vital warmth.

sn.def: Containing life; living.
sn.q: Spirits that live throughout,vitalin every part.

sn.def: Being the seat of life; being that on which life depends; mortal.
sn.q: The dart flew on, and pierced a vital part.

sn.def: Very necessary; highly important; essential.
sn.q: A competence is vital to content.

sn.def: Capable of living; in a state to live; viable.
sn.q: Pythagoras and Hippocrates . . . affirm the birth of the seventh month to be vital.

entry.def: A vital part; one of the vitals.
Pertaining to life; vital.
The doctrine that all the functions of a living organism are due to an unknown vital principle distinct from all chemical and physical forces.
A believer in the theory of vitalism; -- opposed to physicist.
Pertaining to, or involving, vitalism, or the theory of a special vital principle.

entry.ety: L. vitalitas: cf. F. vitalité
entry.def: The quality or state of being vital; the principle of life; vital force; animation; as, the vitality of eggs or vegetable seeds; the vitality of an enterprise.
The act or process of vitalizing, or infusing the vital principle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vitalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Vitalizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. vitaliser
entry.def: To endow with life, or vitality; to give life to; to make alive; as, vitalized blood.
In a vital manner.

sn.def: Organs that are necessary for life; more especially, the heart, lungs, and brain.
Fig.: The part essential to the life or health of anything; as, the vitals of a state.
sn.q: Thevitalsof the public body.

entry.note: Most vitamins act as coenzymes or precursors to coenzymes, and are not consumed for energy production or incorporated into structural units of the cell.
entry.def: any of several organic chemical substances not synthesized by an animal and required in small quantities for normal metabolism, present in and obtained from the natural foods eaten by the animal. Human vitamins are also produced synthetically, and taken in pure form or in mixtures, as dietary supplements. Deficiencies of specific vitamins lead to certain specific disorders, such as scurvy, caused by an insufficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
any of several related fat-soluble vitamins (such as retinol) essential for normal vision; it also prevents night blindness or inflammation or dryness of the eyes.

retinol (C20H30O), one of the substances also called vitamin A. It is also called more specifically vitamin A alcohol. It is a required factor for human nutrition. The USP unit of activity is equal to 0.30 micrograms of retinol.
dehydroretinol (C20H28O), one of the substances also called vitamin A. It has about 40% of the bioactivity of vitamin A1.
a group of water-soluble vitamins originally thought to be a single vitamin but now separated into several B vitamins.
entry.syn: B-complex vitamin, B complex, vitamin B complex, B vitamin.

entry.def: a B vitamin C12H17N4OS)Cl that prevents beriberi and maintains appetite and growth. Same as thiamine.
a B vitamin that is used to treat pernicious anemia.
a B vitamin that prevents skin lesions and weight loss.
entry.syn: vitamin G, riboflavin, lactoflavin, ovoflavin, hepatoflavin.

entry.def: See nicotinamide.
See nicotinic acid.
a B vitamin that is essential for metabolism of amino acids and starch.
a B vitamin that is essential for cell growth and reproduction. Also called folic acid
entry.syn: vitamin M, folic acid, folacin, pteroylglutamic acid, pteroylmonoglutamic acid.

entry.def: a vitamin that prevents scurvy. Also called ascorbic acid.

any of several chemically related fat-soluble vitamins that prevent rickets. It is found in fish-liver oils, egg yolks and milk. Component vitamin D2 is also called calciferol, and vitamin D3 is called cholecalciferol.
a fat-soluble vitamin that is essential for normal reproduction. It is found in vegetable oils, butter, and eggs.
same as vitamin B2.
entry.syn: vitamin B2, riboflavin, lactoflavin, ovoflavin, hepatoflavin.

entry.def: a B vitamin that aids in body growth.

entry.ety: from G. Koagulationsvitamin
entry.def: either of two fat-soluble vitamins (vitamin K1 or vitamin K2) that help clot blood by participating in the fromation of prothrombin.

entries.entry: vitamin K1 n. one of the two K vitamins, (C31H46O2). It is fat-soluble and occurs naturally as the trans isomer. Chemically it is 2-methyl-3-phytyl-1,4,-naphthoquinone. phylloquinone, phytonadione, antihemorrhagic vitamin..

vitamin K2 vitamins K2
n. one of the two K vitamins, actually a mixture of homologous fat-soluble substituted naphthoquinones (called menaquinones), (C11H7O2[C5H8]nH), where n may be 1 to 13 but is mostly 7 to 9. The term is also used for synthetic compounds resembling vitamin K2 and having the same physiological action. The individual components of vitamin K2 are also referred to by the number of isoprenyl units in the side chain (the number n in the formula), as for menadione, having no units at that position of the naphthaquinone ring, and also called vitamin K2(0) (and also called vitamin K3). MI11 menaquinones, antihemorrhagic vitamin..

entry.def: menadione, (C11H8O2) being chemically 2-methyl-1,4,-naphthoquinone. Having no side chain in the 3 position, it cannot exert all functions of a true K vitamin and the designation as vitamin K3 has been discouraged
same as vitamin Bc; folic acid.
a water-soluble vitamin that maintains the resistance of cell and capillary walls to permeation.

entry.ety: L. vita life + -scope
entry.def: A form of machine for exhibiting animated pictures.

entry.ety: L. vitellus a little calf, the yolk of an egg
entry.def: Vitelline.

Producing yolk, or vitelline substance; -- applied to certain cells (also called nutritive, or yolk cells) formed in the ovaries of many insects, and supposed to supply nutriment to the developing ova.

entry.ety: See Vitellus
entry.def: An albuminous body, belonging to the class of globulins, obtained from yolk of egg, of which it is the chief proteid constituent, and from the seeds of many plants. From the latter it can be separated in crystalline form.

entry.ety: L. vitellus the yolk of an egg
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the yolk of eggs; as, the vitelline membrane, a smooth, transparent membrane surrounding the vitellus.

entry.ety: See Vitellus, and -gen
entry.def: A gland secreting the yolk of the eggs in trematodes, turbellarians, and some other helminths.

entry.ety: L., the yolk of an egg

sn.def: The contents or substance of the ovum; egg yolk. See Illust. of Ovum.
Perisperm in an early condition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vitiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Vitiating
entry.ety: L. vitiatus, p. p. vitiare to vitiate, fr. vitium a fault, vice. See Vice a fault

sn.def: To make vicious, faulty, or imperfect; to render defective; to injure the substance or qualities of; to impair; to contaminate; to spoil; as, exaggeration vitiates a style of writing; sewer gas vitiates the air.
sn.q: A will vitiated and growth out of love with the truth disposes the understanding to error and delusion.
Without care it may be used to vitiate our minds.
This undistinguishing complaisance will vitiate the taste of readers.

sn.def: To cause to fail of effect, either wholly or in part; to make void; to destroy, as the validity or binding force of an instrument or transaction; to annul; as, any undue influence exerted on a jury vitiates their verdict; fraud vitiates a contract.

entry.ety: L. vitiatio
entry.def: The act of vitiating, or the state of being vitiated; depravation; corruption; invalidation; as, the vitiation of the blood; the vitiation of a contract.
entry.q: The vitiation that breeds evil acts.

entry.ety: L. viticula, dim. of vitis vine
entry.def: Having long and slender trailing stems.
Of or pertaining to viticulture.

entry.ety: L. vitis vine + E. culture
entry.def: The cultivation of the vine; grape growing.
One engaged in viticulture.

entry.ety: L., a kind of tetter, fr. vitium blemish, vice
entry.def: A rare skin disease consisting in the development of smooth, milk-white spots upon various parts of the body.

entry.ety: L. vitilitigare to quarrel disgracefully; vitium vice + litigare to quarrel
entry.def: To contend in law litigiously or cavilously.
Cavilous litigation; cavillation.

entry.ety: L. vitiositas. See Vicious
entry.def: Viciousness; depravity.
entry.q: The perverseness and vitiosity of man's will.

entry.def: See Vicious Viciously Viciousness.

entry.ety: L., a vine
entry.def: A genus of plants including all true grapevines.
See Durukuli.

entry.ety: F., prop., glazing, glass window
entry.def: A curtain of light and translucent material intended to be secured directly to the woodwork of a French casement window or a glazed door.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of L. vitrum glass
entry.def: One of the transparent lenslike cells in the ocelli of certain arthropods.

entry.ety: See Vitreous, and Electric
entry.def: Containing or exhibiting positive, or vitreous, electricity.

entry.cs: Vitreous body Anat the vitreous humor. See the Note under Eye. Vitreous electricity Elec the kind of electricity excited by rubbing glass with certain substances, as silk; positive electricity; -- opposed to resinous, or negative, electricity. Vitreous humor. Anat See the Note under Eye. Vitreous sponge Zoöl any one of numerous species of siliceous sponges having, often fibrous, glassy spicules which are normally six-rayed; a hexactinellid sponge. See Venus's basket, under Venus.
entry.ety: L. vitreous, from vitrum glass; perhaps akin to videre to see (see Vision). Cf. Varnish

sn.def: Consisting of, or resembling, glass; glassy; as, vitreous rocks.
Of or pertaining to glass; derived from glass; as, vitreous electricity.

entry.def: The quality or state of being vitreous.
The quality or state of being vitreous; glassiness, or the quality of being vitrescent; capability of conversion into glass; susceptibility of being formed into glass.

entry.ety: See Vitreous
entry.def: Capable of being formed into glass; tending to become glass.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vitrescible
entry.def: That may be vitrified; vitrifiable.

entry.ety: L. vitrum glass
entry.def: Having the nature and qualities of glass; glasslike; -- distinguished from ceramic.

entry.ety: See Vitric

sn.def: The art or study of the manufacture and decoration of glassware.
Articles of glassware, glassware in general.

entry.ety: Cf. Vitrification
entry.def: The act, art, or process of vitrifying; also, the state of being vitrified.

entry.ety: L. vitrum glass + facere factum, to make
entry.def: The manufacture of glass and glassware.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vitrifiable
entry.def: Capable of being vitrified, or converted into glass by heat and fusion; as, flint and alkalies are vitrifiable .
Vitrifiable.
To convert into glass; to vitrify.

entry.ety: See Vitrify
entry.def: Same as Vitrifaction.
Converted into glass.

entry.ety: L. vitrum glass + -form
entry.def: Having the form or appearance of glass; resembling glass; glasslike.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vitrified; p. pr. & vb. n. Vitrifying
entry.ety: F. vitrifier; L. vitrum glass + -ficare to make. See Vitreous -fy
entry.def: To convert into, or cause to resemble, glass or a glassy substance, by heat and fusion.
To become glass; to be converted into glass.
entry.q: Chymists make vessels of animal substances, calcined, which will not vitrify in the fire.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. vitrum glass
entry.def: A genus of terrestrial gastropods, having transparent, very thin, and delicate shells, -- whence the name.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A glass show case for displaying fine wares, specimens, etc.

entry.cs: Blue vitriol. See under Blue. Green vitriol ferrous sulphate; copperas. See under Green. Oil of vitriol sulphuric or vitriolic acid; -- popularly so called because it has the consistency of oil. Red vitriol a native sulphate of cobalt. Vitriol of Mars ferric sulphate, a white crystalline substance which dissolves in water, forming a red solution. White vitriol zinc sulphate, a white crystalline substance used in medicine and in dyeing. It is usually obtained by dissolving zinc in sulphuric acid, or by roasting and oxidizing certain zinc ores. Formerly called also vitriol of zinc.
entry.ety: F. vitriol; cf. Pr. vitriol vetriol, Sp. & Pg. vitriolo, It. vitriuolo; fr. L. vitreolus of glass, vitreus vitreous. See Vitreous
entry.def: A sulphate of any one of certain metals, as copper, iron, zinc, cobalt. So called on account of the glassy appearance or luster.
Sulphuric acid; -- called also oil of vitriol. So called because first made by the distillation of green vitriol. See Sulphuric acid, under Sulphuric.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. -oled or -olled; p. pr. & vb. n. -oling or -olling
entry.ety: From Vitriol n.

sn.def: To dip in dilute sulphuric acid; to pickle.
To vitriolize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vitriolated; p. pr. & vb. n. Vitriolating
entry.def: To convert into, or change to, a vitriol; to make into sulphuric acid or a sulphate.
To subject to the action of, or impregnate with, vitriol.
Vitriolated.
A sulphate.
Changed into a vitriol or a sulphate, or subjected to the action of sulphuric acid or of a sulphate; as, vitriolated potash, i. e., potassium sulphate.
The act, process, or result of vitriolating.

cs.cd: sulphuric acid. See Vitriol.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vitriolique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to vitriol; derived from, or resembling, vitriol; vitriolous; as, a vitriolic taste. Cf. Vitriol.
Biting, bitter or caustic; having or expressing strong and unpleasantly negative feelings; -- of speech or feelings; the vitriolic denunciations of opponents by partisan columnists.

entry.def: Capable of being converted into a vitriol.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vitriolisation
entry.def: The act of vitriolizing, or the state of being vitriolized; vitriolation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vitrioliser

sn.def: To convert into a vitriol; to vitriolate.
To injure (a person) with vitriol, or sulphuric acid, as by throwing it upon the face.

entry.def: See Vitriolic.

entry.ety: L. vitrum glass
entry.def: A kind of glass which is very hard and difficult to fuse, used as an insulator in electrical lamps and other apparatus.

entry.ety: It. vetro di trina glass of lace
entry.def: A kind of Venetian glass or glassware in which white threads are embedded in transparent glass with a lacelike or netlike effect.

cs.cd: a name given to a peculiar pattern of scrollwork, consisting of convolved undulations. It is used in classical architecture.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Vitruvius , an ancient Roman architect.

entries.entry:
Vit"ta Vit"ta n.; pl.Vittæ #. L. vitta ribbon, fillet
Bot One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
Zoöl A band, or stripe, of color.

entry.ety: L. vittatus bound with a fillet, fr. vitta fillet

sn.def: Bearing or containing vittæ.
Striped longitudinally.

entry.ety: L. vitulinus, fr. vitulus a calf. See Veal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a calf or veal.

entry.ety: L. vituperabilis: cf. F. vitupérable
entry.def: Liable to, or deserving, vituperation, or severe censure.

entry.ety: L. vituperatus, p. p. of vituperare to blame, vituperate; vitium a fault + parare to prepare. See Vice a fault, and Pare v. t.
entry.def: To find fault with; to scold; to overwhelm with wordy abuse; to censure severely or abusively; to rate.

entry.ety: L. vituperatio: cf. OF. vituperation. See Vituperate
entry.def: The act of vituperating; abuse; severe censure; blame.
entry.q: When a man becomes untractable and inaccessible by fierceness and pride, then vituperation comes upon him.

entry.def: Uttering or writing censure; containing, or characterized by, abuse; scolding; abusive.
entry.q: Vituperative appellations derived from their real or supposed ill qualities.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who vituperates, or censures abusively.
Worthy of vituperation; shameful; disgraceful.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Lit., (long) live; -- an exclamation expressing good will, well wishing, etc.

def2.def: The word viva, or a shout or sound made in uttering it.

entry.q: A wilder burst of “vivas”.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Brisk; vivacious; with spirit; -- a direction to perform a passage in a brisk and lively manner.

entry.ety: L. vívax -acis, fr. vivere to live. See Vivid

sn.def: Having vigorous powers of life; tenacious of life; long-lived.
sn.q: Hitherto the English bishops have been vivacious almost to wonder. . . . But five died for the first twenty years of her [Queen Elizabeth's] reign.
The faith of Christianity is far more vivacious than any mere ravishment of the imagination can ever be.

sn.def: Sprightly in temper or conduct; lively; merry; as, a vivacious poet.
sn.q: Vivaciousnonsense.

sn.def: Living through the winter, or from year to year; perennial.
sn.syn: Sprightly; active; animated; sportive; gay; merry; jocund; light-hearted.

entry.ety: L. vivicitas: cf. F. vivacité
entry.def: The quality or state of being vivacious.
Tenacity of life; vital force; natural vigor.
entry.q: The vivacity of some of these pensioners is little less than a miracle, they lived so long.
entry.def: Life; animation; spiritedness; liveliness; sprightliness; as, the vivacity of a discourse; a lady of great vivacity; vivacity of countenance.

entry.ety: OF. & F. vivandier, fr. LL. vivanda vivenda, provisions. Cf. Viand
entry.def: In Continental armies, esp. the French, a sutler.

entry.ety: F. See Viand
entry.def: In Continental armies, especially in the French army, a woman accompanying a regiment, who sells provisions and liquor to the soldiers; a female sutler.

entry.ety: F., p. pr., living
entry.def: In mort, bridge, and similar games, the partner of dummy.

entries.entry:
Vi*va"ri*um Vi*va"ri*um n.; pl. E. Vivariums #, L. Vivaria #. L., fr. vivarius belonging to living creatures, fr. vivus alive, living. See Vivid
A place artificially arranged for keeping or raising living animals, as a park, a pond, an aquarium, a warren, etc.
Vi"va*ry vī"vȧ*r� n.; pl.Vivaries -rĭz. A vivarium. That . . .vivaryof fowls and beasts.
Vi"va vo"ce Vi"va vo"ce vī"vȧ vō"s�. L By word of mouth; orally.

entry.def: See Vifda.

entries.entry:
Vive Vive vēv. F., imperative sing. pres. fr. vivre to live, L. vivere
Long live, that is, success to; as, vive le roi, long live the king; vive la bagatelle, success to trifles or sport.

entry.ety: L. vivus: cf. F. vif. See Vivid
entry.def: Lively; animated; forcible.
In a lively manner.
entry.q: If I see a thing vively represented on the stage.

entry.ety: L. vivens, p. pr. of vivere to live
entry.def: Manner of supporting or continuing life or vegetation.

entry.ety: L., a ferret
entry.def: A genus of carnivores which comprises the civets.
Of or pertaining to the Viverridæ, or Civet family.

entry.ety: F. vivres, pl. of vivre, orig., to live
entry.def: Provisions; victuals.
entry.q: I 'll join you at three, if the vivers can tarry so long.

entry.ety: OF. vives, F. avivescf. Sp. abivas adiva) fr. Ar. ad-dhība. Cf. Fives vives
entry.def: A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in the glands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends in suppuration.

entry.ety: So called by Werner after the English mineralogist F. G. Vivian
entry.def: A hydrous phosphate of iron of a blue to green color, growing darker on exposure. It occurs in monoclinic crystals, also fibrous, massive, and earthy.

entry.ety: L. vividus, from vivere to life; akin to vivus living. See Quick a., and cf. Revive Viand Victuals Vital

sn.def: True to the life; exhibiting the appearance of life or freshness; animated; spirited; bright; strong; intense; as, vivid colors.
sn.q: In dazzling streaks the vivid lightnings play.
Arts which present, with all the vivid charms of painting, the human face and human form divine.

sn.def: Forming brilliant images, or painting in lively colors; lively; sprightly; as, a vivid imagination.
sn.q: Body is a fit workhouse for sprightly, vivid faculties to exercise . . . themselves in.
sn.syn: Clear; lucid; bright; strong; striking; lively; quick; sprightly; active.

entry.def: The quality or state of being vivid; vividness.

entry.ety: L. vivificus: cf. F. vivifique. See Vivify
entry.def: Giving life; reviving; enlivening.

entry.ety: L. vivificatus, p. p. vivificare. See Vivify

sn.def: To give life to; to animate; to revive; to vivify.
sn.q: God vivificates and actuates the whole world.

sn.def: To bring back a metal to the metallic form, as from an oxide or solution; to reduce.

entry.ety: L. vivificatio: cf. vivification

sn.def: The act of vivifying, or the state of being vivified; restoration of life; revival.

One of the changes of assimilation, in which proteid matter which has been transformed, and made a part of the tissue or tissue cells, is endowed with life, and thus enabled to manifest the phenomena of irritability, contractility, etc.
The act or process of vivificating.

entry.def: Able or tending to vivify, animate, or give life; vivifying.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vivified; p. pr. & vb. n. Vivifying
entry.ety: F. vivifier, L. vivificare. See Vivid -fy; cf. Vivificate
entry.def: To endue with life; to make to be living; to quicken; to animate.
entry.q: Sitting on eggs doth vivify, not nourish.

entry.ety: NL. See Viviparous
entry.def: An artificial division of vertebrates including those that produce their young alive; -- opposed to Ovipara.
The quality or condition of being viviparous.

entry.cs: Viviparous fish. Zoöl See Embiotocoid. Viviparous shell Zoöl any one of numerous species of operculated fresh-water gastropods belonging to Viviparus Melantho, and allied genera. Their young, when born, have a well-developed spiral shell.
entry.ety: L. viviparus; vivus alive + parere to bear, bring forth. Cf. Viper
entry.def: Producing young in a living state, as most mammals, or as those plants the offspring of which are produced alive, either by bulbs instead of seeds, or by the seeds themselves germinating on the plant, instead of falling, as they usually do; -- opposed to oviparous.
In a viviparous manner.
The quality of being viviparous; viviparity.
To perform vivisection upon; to dissect alive.

entry.ety: L. vivus alive + E. section: cf. F. vivisection. See Vivid, and Section
entry.def: The dissection of an animal while alive, for the purpose of making physiological investigations.
Of or pertaining to vivisection.
One who practices or advocates vivisection; a vivisector.
A vivisectionist.

entry.ety: AS. fixen a she-fox, for fyxen, fem. of fox. See Fox

sn.def: A female fox.
A cross, ill-tempered person; -- formerly used of either sex, now only of a woman.
sn.q: She was a vixen when she went to school.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a vixen; resembling a vixen.
Like a vixen; vixenish.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. videlicet
entry.def: To wit; that is; namely.

entry.ety: See Visor
entry.def: A mask; a visor.
entry.q: A grotesquevizard.
To mislead and betray them under the vizard of law.

entry.def: Wearing a vizard.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: Same as Viscacha.

cs.cd: the chief minister of the Turkish empire; -- called also vizier-azem.

entry.ety: Ar. wezīr wazīr, properly, a bearer of burdens, a porter, from wazara to bear a burden: cf. F. vizir visir. Cf. Alguazil
entry.def: A councilor of state; a high executive officer in Turkey and other Oriental countries.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vizirat
entry.def: The office, dignity, or authority of a vizier.

entry.ety: Ar. azam great. See Vizier
entry.def: A grand vizier. See under Vizier.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vizirial
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or issued by, a vizier.
See Vizier.
See Visor.

entry.ety: From the native name
entry.def: The diadem indris. See Indris.

entries.entry: V" moth`. Zoöl A common gray European moth (Halia vauaria) having a V-shaped spot of dark brown on each of the fore wings.

entry.ety: L. vocabulum an appellation, designation, name, fr. vocare to call, fr. vox vocis, a voice, a word: cf. F. vocable. See Voice
entry.def: A word; a term; a name; specifically, a word considered as composed of certain sounds or letters, without regard to its meaning.
entry.q: Swamped near to drowning in a tide of ingenious vocables.

entries.entry:
Vo*cab"u*la*ry The “vocabulary” of this dictionary referred to within the definitions of certain collocations are those words serving as headwords for main entries, and distinguished from word combinations (“collocations”) which follow the main part of certain entries. In the XML-tagged version, these headwords are marked by the tags . . .. v�*kăb"�*l�*r� n.; pl.Vocabularies #. LL. vocabularium vocabularius: cf. F. vocabulaire. See Vocable
A list or collection of words arranged in alphabetical order and explained; a dictionary or lexicon, either of a whole language, a single work or author, a branch of science, or the like; a word-book.
A sum or stock of words employed. His vocabulary seems to have been no larger than was necessary for the transaction of business.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vocabuliste
entry.def: The writer or maker of a vocabulary; a lexicographer.

entry.cs: Vocal cordsorVocal chords . n. pl. Anat The two pairs of mucous membranes that project into the larynx, and which produce the sounds of speech by vibrating under the influence of air exhaled from the lungs. See Larynx, and the Note under Voice n., 1. Vocal fremitus L. fremitus a dull roaring or murmuring Med the perceptible vibration of the chest wall, produced by the transmission of the sonorous vibrations during the act of using the voice. Vocal music music made by the voice, in distinction from instrumental music; hence, music or tunes set to words, to be performed by the human voice. Vocal tube Anat the part of the air passages above the inferior ligaments of the larynx, including the passages through the nose and mouth.
entry.ety: L. vocalis, fr. vox vocis, voice: cf. F. vocal. See Voice, and cf. Vowel

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the voice or speech; having voice; endowed with utterance; full of voice, or voices.
sn.q: To hill or valley, fountain, or fresh shade, Made vocal by my song.

sn.def: Uttered or modulated by the voice; oral; as, vocal melody; vocal prayer.
sn.q: Vocalworship.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a vowel or voice sound; also, spoken with tone, intonation, and resonance; sonant; sonorous; -- said of certain articulate sounds.

sd.def: Consisting of, or characterized by, voice, or tone produced in the larynx, which may be modified, either by resonance, as in the case of the vowels, or by obstructive action, as in certain consonants, such as v l, etc., or by both, as in the nasals m n ng; sonant; intonated; voiced. See Voice, and Vowel, also Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 199-202.
Of or pertaining to a vowel; having the character of a vowel; vowel.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vocal, LL. vocalis

sn.def: A vocal sound; specifically, a purely vocal element of speech, unmodified except by resonance; a vowel or a diphthong; a tonic element; a tonic; -- distinguished from a subvocal, and a nonvocal.
A man who has a right to vote in certain elections.

entry.ety: L. vocalissc. littera) a vowel. See Vocal a.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to vowel sounds; consisting of the vowel sounds.
entry.q: The Gaelic language being uncommonly vocalic.

sn.def: The exercise of the vocal organs; vocalization.
A vocalic sound.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vocaliste
entry.def: A singer, or vocal musician, as opposed to an instrumentalist.

entry.ety: Cf. L. vocalitas euphony

sn.def: The quality or state of being vocal; utterableness; resonance; as, the vocality of the letters.
The quality of being a vowel; vocalic character.
The act of vocalizing, or the state of being vocalized.
The formation and utterance of vocal sounds.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vocalized vō"k�l*īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Vocalizing vō"k�l*ī*zĭng
entry.ety: Cf. F. vocaliser

sn.def: To form into voice; to make vocal or sonant; to give intonation or resonance to.
sn.q: It is one thing to give an impulse to breath alone, another thing to vocalize that breath.

sn.def: To practice singing on the vowel sounds.
In a vocal manner; with voice; orally; with audible sound.
In words; verbally; as, to express desires vocally .

entry.def: The quality of being vocal; vocality.

entry.ety: L. vocatio a bidding, invitation, fr. vocare to call, fr. vox vocis, voice: cf. F. vocation. See Vocal

sn.def: A call; a summons; a citation; especially, a designation or appointment to a particular state, business, or profession.
sn.q: What can be urged for them who not having the vocation of poverty to scribble, out of mere wantonness make themselves ridiculous?

sn.def: Destined or appropriate employment; calling; occupation; trade; business; profession.
sn.q: He would think his service greatly rewarded, if he might obtain by that means to live in the sight of his prince, and yet practice his own chosen vocation.

entry.sn:
Theol A calling by the will of God. Specifically: The bestowment of God's distinguishing grace upon a person or nation, by which that person or nation is put in the way of salvation; as, the vocation of the Jews under the old dispensation, and of the Gentiles under the gospel. The golden chain ofvocation, election, and justification.
A call to special religious work, as to the ministry. Every member of the same [the Church], in his vocation and ministry.

entry.ety: L. vocativus, fr. vocare to call
entry.def: Of or pertaining to calling; used in calling; specifically Gram, used in address; appellative; -- said of that case or form of the noun, pronoun, or adjective, in which a person or thing is addressed; as, Domine, O Lord.

entry.ety: L. vocativussc. casus): cf. F. vocatif
entry.def: The vocative case.
Vociferation; noise; clamor.

entry.ety: L. vociferans, p. pr
entry.def: Noisy; clamorous.

entry.ety: L. vociferatus, p. p. vociferari to vociferate; vox vocis, voice + ferre to bear. See Voice, and Bear to carry
entry.def: To cry out with vehemence; to exclaim; to bawl; to clamor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vociferated; p. pr. & vb. n. Vociferating
entry.def: To utter with a loud voice; to shout out.
entry.q: Though he may vociferate the word liberty.

entry.ety: L. vociferatio: cf. F. vocifération
entry.def: The act of vociferating; violent outcry; vehement utterance of the voice.
entry.q: Violent gesture and vociferation naturally shake the hearts of the ignorant.
Plaintive strains succeeding the vociferations of emotion or of pain.

entry.def: One who vociferates, or is clamorous.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vocifère
entry.def: Making a loud outcry; clamorous; noisy; as, vociferous heralds.

entry.ety: L. vocula, dim. of vox vocis, voice
entry.def: A short or weak utterance; a faint or feeble sound, as that heard on separating the lips in pronouncing p or b.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A supposed element, afterward found to be a mixture of several metals, as copper, iron, lead, nickel, etc.

entry.ety: Russ
entry.def: A Russian drink distilled from rye.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel ver sea, vöar a fenced-in landing place
entry.def: An inlet, bay, or creek; -- so called in the Orkney and Shetland Islands.
Same as Vugg.

entry.ety: F. vogue a rowing, vogue, fashion, It. voga, fr. vogare to row, to sail; probably fr. OHG. wag�n to move, akin to E. way. Cf. Way

sn.def: The way or fashion of people at any particular time; temporary mode, custom, or practice; popular reception for the time; -- used now generally in the phrase in vogue.
sn.q: One vogue, one vein, One air of thoughts usurps my brain.
Whatsoever its vogue may be, I still flatter myself that the parents of the growing generation will be satisfied with what �� to be taught to their children in Westminster, in Eton, or in Winchester.
Use may revive the obsoletest words, And banish those that now are most in vogue.

sn.def: Influence; power; sway.

entry.note: ☞ Voice, in this sense, is produced by vibration of the so-called vocal cords in the larynx (see Illust. of Larynx) which act upon the air, not in the manner of the strings of a stringed instrument, but as a pair of membranous tongues, or reeds, which, being continually forced apart by the outgoing current of breath, and continually brought together again by their own elasticity and muscular tension, break the breath current into a series of puffs, or pulses, sufficiently rapid to cause the sensation of tone. The power, or loudness, of such a tone depends on the force of the separate pulses, and this is determined by the pressure of the expired air, together with the resistance on the part of the vocal cords which is continually overcome. Its pitch depends on the number of aërial pulses within a given time, that is, on the rapidity of their succession. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 5, 146, 155.
entry.cs:
Active voice Gram that form of the verb by which its subject is represented as the agent or doer of the action expressed by it. Chest voice Phon a kind of voice of a medium or low pitch and of a sonorous quality ascribed to resonance in the chest, or thorax; voice of the thick register. It is produced by vibration of the vocal cords through their entire width and thickness, and with convex surfaces presented to each other. Head voice Phon a kind of voice of high pitch and of a thin quality ascribed to resonance in the head; voice of the thin register; falsetto. In producing it, the vibration of the cords is limited to their thin edges in the upper part, which are then presented to each other. Middle voice Gram that form of the verb by which its subject is represented as both the agent, or doer, and the object of the action, that is, as performing some act to or upon himself, or for his own advantage. Passive voice. Gram See under Passive a.
Voice glide Pron the brief and obscure neutral vowel sound that sometimes occurs between two consonants in an unaccented syllable (represented by the apostrophe), as in able a"b'l. See Glide n., 2. Voice stop. See Voiced stop, under Voiced a.
With one voice unanimously. “All with one voice . . . cried out, Great is Diana of the Ephesians.” Acts xix. 34.
entry.ety: OE. vois voys, OF. vois voiz, F. voix, L. vox vocis, akin to Gr. � a word, � a voice, Skr. vac to say, to speak, G. erwähnen to mention. Cf. Advocate Advowson Avouch Convoke Epic Vocal Vouch Vowel

sn.def: Sound uttered by the mouth, especially that uttered by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character; as, the human voice; a pleasant voice; a low voice .
sn.q: He with a manly voice saith his message.
Her voice was ever soft, Gentle, and low; an excellent thing in woman.
Thy voice is music.
Join thy voice unto the angel choir.

sn.def: Sound of the kind or quality heard in speech or song in the consonants b v d, etc., and in the vowels; sonant, or intonated, utterance; tone; -- distinguished from mere breath sound as heard in f s sh, etc., and also whisper.
The tone or sound emitted by anything.
sn.q: After the fire a still small voice.
Canst thou thunder with a voice like him?
The floods have lifted up their voice.
O Marcus, I am warm'd; my heart Leaps at the trumpet's voice.

sn.def: The faculty or power of utterance; as, to cultivate the voice .
Language; words; speech; expression; signification of feeling or opinion.
sn.q: I desire to be present with you now, and to change my voice; for I stand in doubt of you.
My voice is in my sword.
Let us call on God in the voice of his church.

sn.def: Opinion or choice expressed; judgment; a vote.
sn.q: Sic. How now, my masters! have you chose this man? 1 Cit. He has our voices, sir.
Some laws ordain, and some attend the choice Of holy senates, and elect by voice.

sn.def: Command; precept; -- now chiefly used in scriptural language.
sn.q: So shall ye perish; because ye would not be obedient unto the voice of the Lord your God.

sn.def: One who speaks; a speaker.
sn.q: A potentvoiceof Parliament.

sn.def: A particular mode of inflecting or conjugating verbs, or a particular form of a verb, by means of which is indicated the relation of the subject of the verb to the action which the verb expresses.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Voiced; p. pr. & vb. n. Voicing

sn.def: To give utterance or expression to; to utter; to publish; to announce; to divulge; as, to voice the sentiments of the nation.
sn.q: Rather assume thy right in silence and . . . thenvoiceit with claims and challenges.
It was voiced that the king purposed to put to death Edward Plantagenet.

sn.def: To utter with sonant or vocal tone; to pronounce with a narrowed glottis and rapid vibrations of the vocal cords; to speak above a whisper.
To fit for producing the proper sounds; to regulate the tone of; as, to voice the pipes of an organ.
To vote; to elect; to appoint.

entry.def: To clamor; to cry out.

cs.cd: a stopped consonant made with tone from the larynx while the mouth organs are closed at some point; a sonant mute, as b d g hard.

sn.def: Furnished with a voice; expressed by the voice.
Uttered with voice; pronounced with vibrations of the vocal cords; sonant; -- said of a sound uttered with the glottis narrowed.

entry.def: Having a voice or vocal quality; having a loud voice or many voices; vocal; sounding.
entry.q: Beheld the Iliad and the Odyssey Rise to the swelling of the voiceful sea.

cs.cd: a consonant made with no audible sound except in the transition to or from another sound; a surd mute, as p t k.

sn.def: Having no voice, utterance, or vote; silent; mute; dumb.
sn.q: I live and die unheard, With a most voiceless thought, sheathing it as a sword.

sn.def: Not sounded with voice; as, a voiceless consonant; surd.

cs.cd: a vacuum.

entry.ety: OE. voide, OF. voit voide vuit vuide, F. vide, fr. (assumed) LL. vocitus, fr. L. vocare, an old form of vacare to be empty, or a kindred word. Cf. Vacant Avoid

sn.def: Containing nothing; empty; vacant; not occupied; not filled.
sn.q: The earth was without form, and void.
I 'll get me to a place more void.
I 'll chain him in my study, that, at void hours, I may run over the story of his country.

sn.def: Having no incumbent; unoccupied; -- said of offices and the like.
sn.q: Divers great offices that had been long void.

sn.def: Being without; destitute; free; wanting; devoid; as, void of learning, or of common use.
sn.q: A conscience void of offense toward God.
He that is void of wisdom despiseth his neighbor.

sn.def: Not producing any effect; ineffectual; vain.
sn.q: My word] shall not return to me void, but it shall accomplish that which I please.
I will make void the counsel of Judah.

sn.def: Containing no immaterial quality; destitute of mind or soul.
sn.q: Idol,voidand vain.

sn.def: Of no legal force or effect, incapable of confirmation or ratification; null. Cf. Voidable, 2.
sn.syn: Empty; vacant; devoid; wanting; unfurnished; unsupplied; unoccupied.

entry.def: An empty space; a vacuum.
entry.q: Pride, where wit fails, steps in to our defense, And fills up all the mighty void of sense.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Voided; p. pr. & vb. n. Voiding
entry.ety: OF. voidier vuidier. See Void a.

sn.def: To remove the contents of; to make or leave vacant or empty; to quit; to leave; as, to void a table.
sn.q: Void anon her place.
If they will fight with us, bid them come down, Or void the field.

sn.def: To throw or send out; to evacuate; to emit; to discharge; as, to void excrements.
sn.q: A watchful application of mind in voiding prejudices.
With shovel, like a fury, voided out The earth and scattered bones.

sn.def: To render void; to make to be of no validity or effect; to vacate; to annul; to nullify.
sn.q: After they had voided the obligation of the oath he had taken.
It was become a practice . . . to void the security that was at any time given for money so borrowed.

entry.def: To be emitted or evacuated.

entry.note: ☞ A voidable contract may be ratified and confirmed; to render it null and of no effect, it must be avoided; a void contract can not be ratified.

sn.def: Capable of being voided, or evacuated.
Capable of being avoided, or of being adjudged void, invalid, and of no force; capable of being either avoided or confirmed.
sn.q: If the metropolitan . . . grants letters of administration, such administration is not, but voidable by sentence.

sn.def: The act of voiding, emptying, ejecting, or evacuating.
A ejection from a benefice.
The state of being void; vacancy, as of a benefice which is without an incumbent.
Evasion; subterfuge.
Emptied; evacuated.
Annulled; invalidated.
Having the inner part cut away, or left vacant, a narrow border being left at the sides, the tincture of the field being seen in the vacant space; -- said of a charge.
One who, or that which, voids, �mpties, vacates, or annuls.

A tray, or basket, formerly used to receive or convey that which is voided or cleared away from a given place; especially, one for carrying off the remains of a meal, as fragments of food; sometimes, a basket for containing household articles, as clothes, etc.
sn.q: Piers Plowman laid the cloth, and Simplicity brought in the voider.
The cloth whereon the earl dined was taken away, and the voider, wherein the plate was usually put, was set upon the cupboard's head.

sn.def: A servant whose business is to void, or clear away, a table after a meal.
