One of the ordinaries, much like the flanch, but less rounded and therefore smaller.

cs.cd: a knife used for gathering up fragments of food to put them into a voider.

sn.def: The act of one who, or that which, voids.
That which is voided; that which is ejected or evacuated; a remnant; a fragment.

entry.def: Receiving what is ejected or voided.
entry.q: How in ourvoidinglobby hast thou stood?

entry.def: The quality or state of being void; emptiness; vacuity; nullity; want of substantiality.

entries.entry: Voir dire Voir dire. OF., to say the truth, fr. L. verus true + dicere to say Law An oath administered to a witness, usually before being sworn in chief, requiring him to speak the truth, or make true answers in reference to matters inquired of, to ascertain his competency to give evidence.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. vectura a carrying, conveying. Cf. Vettura
entry.def: A carriage.
See Waywode.

entry.ety: L. volare to fly
entry.def: Apt or fit to fly.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: A flying fish of California (Exocœtus Californicus): -- called also volator.
The Atlantic flying gurnard. See under Flying.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Light; giddy.
entry.q: They wroughten all their lust volage.

cs.cd: an adjustable piece of armor, for guarding the throat, etc., in a joust.

entry.ety: L. volans -antis, p. pr. of volare to fly: cf. F. volant

sn.def: Passing through the air upon wings, or as if upon wings; flying; hence, passing from place to place; current.
sn.q: English silver now was current, and our gold volant in the pope's court.

sn.def: Nimble; light and quick; active; rapid.
sn.q: Hisvolanttouch.

sn.def: Represented as flying, or having the wings spread; as, an eagle volant .

entry.ety: Sp., prop., flying
entry.def: A two-wheeled carriage formerly much used in Cuba. The body is in front of the axle; the driver rides on the horse.
Literally, world's speech; the name of an artificial language invented by Johan Martin Schleyer, of Constance, Switzerland, about 1879.
One who is conversant with, or who favors adoption of, Volapük.

entry.ety: L. vola the palm of the hand, the sole of the foot
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of the foot.
See Volery.

entry.note: ☞ Substances which affect the smell with pungent or fragrant odors, as musk, hartshorn, and essential oils, are called volatile substances, because they waste away on exposure to the atmosphere. Alcohol and ether are called volatile liquids for a similar reason, and because they easily pass into the state of vapor on the application of heat. On the contrary, gold is a fixed substance, because it does not suffer waste, even when exposed to the heat of a furnace; and oils are called fixed when they do not evaporate on simple exposure to the atmosphere.
entry.cs: Volatile alkali. Old Chem See under Alkali. Volatile liniment a liniment composed of sweet oil and ammonia, so called from the readiness with which the latter evaporates. Volatile oils. Chem See Essential oils, under Essential.
entry.ety: F. volatil, L. volatilis, fr. volare to fly, perhaps akin to velox swift, E. velocity. Cf. Volley

sn.def: Passing through the air on wings, or by the buoyant force of the atmosphere; flying; having the power to fly.
Capable of wasting away, or of easily passing into the aëriform state; subject to evaporation.
Fig.: Light-hearted; easily affected by circumstances; airy; lively; hence, changeable; fickle; as, a volatile temper.
sn.q: You are as giddy and volatile as ever.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volatile
entry.def: A winged animal; wild fowl; game.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volatilité
entry.def: Quality or state of being volatile; disposition to evaporate; changeableness; fickleness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volatisable
entry.def: Capable of being volatilized.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volatilisation
entry.def: The act or process of volatilizing, or rendering volatile; the state of being volatilized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Volatilized; p. pr. & vb. n. Volatilizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. volatiliser
entry.def: To render volatile; to cause to exhale or evaporate; to cause to pass off in vapor.
entry.q: The water . . . dissolving the oil, and volatilizing it by the action.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Volador, 1.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A light puff paste, with a raised border, filled, after baking, usually with a ragout of fowl, game, or fish.

entry.ety: So named after Volborth, who first discovered it
entry.def: A mineral occurring in small six-sided tabular crystals of a green or yellow color. It is a hydrous vanadate of copper and lime.
Volcanic.

cs.cd: a mass ejected from a volcano, often of molten lava having a rounded form.
a hill, conical in form, built up of cinders, tufa, or lava, during volcanic eruptions.
the subterranean centers of volcanic action; the points beneath volcanoes where the causes producing volcanic phenomena are most active.
the vitreous form of lava, produced by sudden cooling; obsidian. See Obsidian.
fetid, sulphurous mud discharged by a volcano.
rocks which have been produced from the discharges of volcanic matter, as the various kinds of basalt, trachyte, scoria, obsidian, etc., whether compact, scoriaceous, or vitreous.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volcanique, It. vulcanico

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a volcano or volcanoes; as, volcanic heat.
Produced by a volcano, or, more generally, by igneous agencies; as, volcanic tufa.
Changed or affected by the heat of a volcano.

entry.def: Like a volcano.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volcanicité
entry.def: Quality or state of being volcanic; volcanic power.

entries.entry: Vol*can"ic neck. Geol A column of igneous rock formed by congelation of lava in the conduit of a volcano and later exposed by the removal of surrounding rocks.
Volcanic wind. Meteorol A wind associated with a volcanic outburst and due to the eruption or to convection currents over hot lava.

entry.def: Volcanic power or action; volcanicity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volcaniste vulcaniste

sn.def: One versed in the history and phenomena of volcanoes.
One who believes in the igneous, as opposed to the aqueous, origin of the rocks of the earth's crust; a vulcanist. Cf. Neptunist.

entry.ety: See Volcanic, and Volcanicity
entry.def: The quality or state of being volcanic, or volcanic origin; volcanicity.
The act of volcanizing, or the state of being volcanized; the process of undergoing volcanic heat, and being affected by it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Volcanized; p. pr. & vb. n. Volcanizing
entry.ety: Cf. Vulcanize
entry.def: To subject to, or cause to undergo, volcanic heat, and to be affected by its action.

entries.entry:
Vol*ca"no ☞ Volcanoes include many of the most conspicuous and lofty mountains of the earth, as Mt. Vesuvius in Italy (4,000 ft. high), Mt. Loa in Hawaii (14,000 ft.), Cotopaxi in South America (nearly 20,000 ft.), which are examples of active volcanoes. The crater of a volcano is usually a pit-shaped cavity, often of great size. The summit crater of Mt. Loa has a maximum length of 13,000 ft., and a depth of nearly 800 feet. Beside the chief crater, a volcano may have a number of subordinate craters. n.; pl.Volcanoes #. It. volcano vulcano, fr. L. Vulcanus Vulkan, the god of fire. See Vulkan
Geol A mountain or hill, usually more or less conical in form, from which lava, cinders, steam, sulphur gases, and the like, are ejected; -- often popularly called a burning mountain.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A deal at cards that draws all the tricks.
To win all the tricks by a vole.

entry.note: ☞ The water vole, or water rat, of Europe (Arvicola amphibius) is a common large aquatic species. The short-tailed field vole (Arvicola agrestis) of Northern and Central Europe, and Asia, the Southern field vole (Arvicola arvalis), and the Siberian root vole (Arvicola œconomus), are important European species. The common species of the Eastern United States (Arvicola riparius) (called also meadow mouse) and the prairie mouse (Arvicola austerus) are abundant, and often injurious to vegetation. Other species are found in Canada.
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of micelike rodents belonging to Arvicola and allied genera of the subfamily Arvicolinæ. They have a thick head, short ears, and a short hairy tail.

entry.ety: F. volerie a flying, volière a large bird cage, fr. voler to fly, L. volare. See Volatile

sn.def: A flight of birds.
A large bird cage; an aviary.

entry.ety: L. vulgus
entry.def: The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob.
Volatilizable.

entry.ety: L. volitare volitatum, to fly to and fro, v. freq. from volare to fly
entry.def: The act of flying; flight.

entry.ety: See Volition
entry.def: Exercising the will; acting from choice; willing, or having power to will.
entry.q: What I do, I dovolitient, not obedient.

entry.usage: Volition Choice. Choice is the familiar, and volition the scientific, term for the same state of the will; viz., an “elective preference.” When we have “made up our minds” (as we say) to a thing, i. e., have a settled state of choice respecting it, that state is called an immanent volition; when we put forth any particular act of choice, that act is called an emanent, or executive, or imperative, volition. When an immanent, or settled state of, choice, is one which controls or governs a series of actions, we call that state a predominant volition; while we give the name of subordinate volitions to those particular acts of choice which carry into effect the object sought for by the governing or “predominant volition.” See Will.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. volo I will, velle to will, be willing. See Voluntary

sn.def: The act of willing or choosing; the act of forming a purpose; the exercise of the will.
sn.q: Volition is the actual exercise of the power the mind has to order the consideration of any idea, or the forbearing to consider it.
Volition is an act of the mind, knowingly exerting that dominion it takes itself to have over any part of the man, by employing it in, or withholding it from, any particular action.

sn.def: The result of an act or exercise of choosing or willing; a state of choice.
The power of willing or determining; will.
sn.syn: Will; choice; preference; determination; purpose.

entry.def: Belonging or relating to volition.
entry.q: Thevolitionalimpulse.

entry.ety: See Volition

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the will; originating in the will; having the power to will.
sn.q: They not only perfect the intellectual faculty, but thevolitive.

sn.def: Used in expressing a wish or permission as, volitive proposition.

entries.entry: Volks"lied Volks"lied n.; pl.Volkslieder #. G Mus A popular song, or national air.

entry.ety: D
entry.def: A legislative assembly or parliament of any one of several countries colonized by the Dutch, esp. that of the South African Republic, or the Transvaal, and that of the Orange Free State.

entries.entry:
Vol"ley
Half volley. Tennis A return of the ball immediately after is has touched the ground. Cricket A sending of the ball so that after touching the ground it flies towards the top of the wicket. R. A. Proctor. On the volley at random. Obs “What we spake on the volley begins work.” Massinger. Volley gun a gun with several barrels for firing a number of shots simultaneously; a kind of mitrailleuse.
n.; pl.Volleys #. F. volée; flight, a volley, or discharge of several guns, fr. voler to fly, L. volare. See Volatile
A flight of missiles, as arrows, bullets, or the like; the simultaneous discharge of a number of small arms. Fiery darts in flaming volleys flew. Each volley tells that thousands cease to breathe.
A burst or emission of many things at once; as, a volley of words. Thisvolleyof oaths. Rattling nonsense in full volleys breaks.
Tennis A return of the ball before it touches the ground.
Cricket A sending of the ball full to the top of the wicket.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Volleyed; p. pr. & vb. n. Volleying
entry.def: To discharge with, or as with, a volley.

sn.def: To be thrown out, or discharged, at once; to be discharged in a volley, or as if in a volley; to make a volley or volleys.

sd.def: To return the ball before it touches the ground.
To send the ball full to the top of the wicket.

entries.entry: Vol"ley ball. A game played by volleying a large inflated ball with the hands over a net 7 ft. 6 in. high.

entry.def: Discharged with a sudden burst, or as if in a volley; as, volleyed thunder.

entry.ety: Russ. volost'
entry.def: In the greater part of Russia, a division for local government consisting of a group of mirs, or village communities; a canton.

entry.ety: From the answer, Volo I will, in the baptismal service. Richardson (Dict.).
entry.def: To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers.

entry.ety: F. vol plané act of volplaning; vol flight + plané, p.p.; cf. planer to hover
entry.def: To glide in a flying machine.

entry.ety: F. volte; cf. It. volta. See Vault

sn.def: A circular tread; a gait by which a horse going sideways round a center makes two concentric tracks.
A sudden movement to avoid a thrust.

entry.ety: After Alessandro Volta, the Italian electrician
entry.def: The unit of electro-motive force; -- defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893 and by United States Statute as, that electro-motive force which steadily applied to a conductor whose resistance is one ohm will produce a current of one ampère. It is practically equivalent to 1000/1434 the electro-motive force of a standard Clark's cell at a temperature of 15° C.

entries.entry: Vol"ta Vol"ta n.; pl.Volte #. It. volta a turn, turning, a time. See Volt a tread Mus A turning; a time; -- chiefly used in phrases signifying that the part is to be repeated one, two, or more times; as, una volta, once. Seconda volta, second time, points to certain modifications in the close of a repeated strain.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to voltaic electricity, or voltaism.
An instrument for the exact measurement of electric currents.
Electric potential or potential difference, expressed in volts.

entry.ety: Voltaic + -graphy
entry.def: In electrotypy, the act or art of copying, in metals deposited by electrolytic action, a form or pattern which is made the negative electrode.

entry.note: ☞ See the Note under Galvanism.
entry.cs:
Voltaic arc a luminous arc, of intense brilliancy, formed between carbon points as electrodes by the passage of a powerful voltaic current. Voltaic battery an apparatus variously constructed, consisting of a series of plates or pieces of dissimilar metals, as copper and zinc, arranged in pairs, and subjected to the action of a saline or acid solution, by which a current of electricity is generated whenever the two poles, or ends of the series, are connected by a conductor; a galvanic battery. See Battery, 4. , and Note. Voltaic circuit. See under Circuit.
Voltaic coupleorVoltaic element
a single pair of the connected plates of a battery. Voltaic electricity. See the Note under Electricity. Voltaic pile a kind of voltaic battery consisting of alternate disks of dissimilar metals, separated by moistened cloth or paper. See 5th Pile. Voltaic protection of metals the protection of a metal exposed to the corrosive action of sea water, saline or acid liquids, or the like, by associating it with a metal which is positive to it, as when iron is galvanized, or coated with zinc.
entry.ety: Cf. F. voltaïque, It. voltaico

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Alessandro Volta, who first devised apparatus for developing electric currents by chemical action, and established this branch of electric science; discovered by Volta; as, voltaic electricity.
Of or pertaining to voltaism, or voltaic electricity; as, voltaic induction; the voltaic arc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. voltairien
entry.def: Of or relating to Voltaire, the French author.
The theories or practice of Voltaire.

entry.ety: Cf. F. voltaïsme
entry.def: That form of electricity which is developed by the chemical action between metals and different liquids; voltaic electricity; also, the science which treats of this form of electricity; -- called also galvanism, from Galvani, on account of his experiments showing the remarkable influence of this agent on animals.

entry.ety: Voltaic + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the voltaic electricity passing through it, by its effect in decomposing water or some other chemical compound acting as an electrolyte.
A wattmeter.

entries.entry: Volt ampère. Elec A unit of electric measurement equal to the product of a volt and an ampere. For direct current it is a measure of power and is the same as a watt; for alternating current it is a measure of apparent power.

entry.ety: Voltaic + Gr. � molded
entry.def: A form of voltaic, or galvanic, battery suitable for use electrotyping.

entry.ety: Voltaic + type
entry.def: An electrotype.

cs.cd: turn over quickly.

entry.ety: It., fr. voltare to turn. See Volt a tread
entry.def: Turn, that is, turn over the leaf.

entry.ety: F., fr. voltiger to vault, It. volteggiare. See Volt a tread

sn.def: A tumbler; a leaper or vaulter.
One of a picked company of irregular riflemen in each regiment of the French infantry.

entry.ety: 2d volt + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring in volts the differences of potential between different points of an electrical circuit.

entry.ety: So named in honor of Voltz, a French engineer
entry.def: An oxysulphide of lead occurring in implanted spherical globules of a yellowish or brownish color; -- called also voltzine.

entry.ety: See Voluble
entry.def: Turning, or whirling; winding; twining; voluble.

entry.ety: L. volubilitas: cf. F. volubilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being voluble (in any of the senses of the adjective).

entry.note: ☞ Voluble was used formerly to indicate readiness of speech merely, without any derogatory suggestion. “A grave and voluble eloquence.”

cs.cd: a stem that climbs by winding, or twining, round another body.

entry.ety: L. volubilis, fr. volvere volutum, to roll, to turn round; akin to Gr. � to infold, to inwrap, � to roll, G. welle a wave: cf. F. voluble. Cf. F. Well of water, Convolvulus Devolve Involve Revolt Vault an arch, Volume Volute

sn.def: Easily rolling or turning; easily set in motion; apt to roll; rotating; as, voluble particles of matter.
Moving with ease and smoothness in uttering words; of rapid speech; nimble in speaking; glib; as, a flippant, voluble, tongue.
sn.q: Cassio,] a knave very voluble.

sn.def: Changeable; unstable; fickle.
Having the power or habit of turning or twining; as, the voluble stem of hop plants.

cs.cd: the ratio of the atomic and molecular weights divided respectively by the specific gravity of the substance in question.

the quotient obtained by dividing unity by the specific gravity; the reciprocal of the specific gravity. It is equal (when the specific gravity is referred to water at 4° C. as a standard) to the number of cubic centimeters occupied by one gram of the substance.

entry.ety: F., from L. volumen a roll of writing, a book, volume, from volvere volutum, to roll. See Voluble

sn.def: A roll; a scroll; a written document rolled up for keeping or for use, after the manner of the ancients.
sn.q: The papyrus, and afterward the parchment, was joined together [by the ancients] to form one sheet, and then rolled upon a staff into a volume volumen).

sn.def: Hence, a collection of printed sheets bound together, whether containing a single work, or a part of a work, or more than one work; a book; a tome; especially, that part of an extended work which is bound up together in one cover; as, a work in four volumes .
sn.q: An odd volume of a set of books bears not the value of its proportion to the set.

sn.def: Anything of a rounded or swelling form resembling a roll; a turn; a convolution; a coil.
sn.q: So glides some trodden serpent on the grass, And long behind wounded volume trails.
Undulating billows rolling their silver volumes.

sn.def: Dimensions; compass; space occupied, as measured by cubic units, that is, cubic inches, feet, yards, etc.; mass; bulk; as, the volume of an elephant's body; a volume of gas.
Amount, fullness, quantity, or caliber of voice or tone.
Having the form of a volume, or roil; as, volumed mist.
sn.q: The distant torrent's rushing sound Tells where the volumed cataract doth roll.

sn.def: Having volume, or bulk; massive; great.

entry.ety: L. volumen volume + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the volume of a body, especially a solid, by means of the difference in tension caused by its presence and absence in a confined portion of air.
The method or process of measuring volumes by means of the volumenometer.

entry.ety: Volume + -scope
entry.def: An instrument consisting essentially of a glass tube provided with a graduated scale, for exhibiting to the eye the changes of volume of a gas or gaseous mixture resulting from chemical action, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volumètre. See Volumetric
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the volumes of gases or liquids by introducing them into a vessel of known capacity.

cs.cd: that system of the quantitative analysis of solutions which employs definite volumes of standardized solutions of reagents, as measured by burettes, pipettes, etc.; also, the analysis of gases by volume, as by the eudiometer.

entry.ety: Volume + -metric
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the measurement of volume.
Volumetric.

entries.entry:
Vo*lu"mi*nous
Vo*lu"mi*nous*ly adv. Vo*lu"mi*nous*ness n.
Vo*lu"mi*nous*ly adv. Vo*lu"mi*nous*ness n.
a. L. voluminosus: cf. F. volumineux
Of or pertaining to volume or volumes. Specifically:Consisting of many folds, coils, or convolutions. But ended foul in many a scaly fold,Voluminous and vast. Over which dusky draperies are hanging, and voluminous curtains have long since fallen. Of great volume, or bulk; large. Consisting of many volumes or books; as, the collections of Muratori are voluminous.Having written much, or produced many volumes; copious; diffuse; as, a voluminous writer.

entry.def: One who writes a volume; an author.
In a voluntary manner; of one's own will; spontaneously.
The quality or state of being voluntary; spontaneousness; specifically, the quality or state of being free in the exercise of one's will.

sn.def: Any theory which conceives will to be the dominant factor in experience or in the constitution of the world; -- contrasted with intellectualism. Schopenhauer and Fichte are typical exponents of the two types of metaphysical voluntarism, Schopenhauer teaching that the evolution of the universe is the activity of a blind and irrational will, Fichte holding that the intelligent activity of the ego is the fundamental fact of reality.
the principle or practice of depending on volunteers to support institutions or perform some desired action.
a political philosophy opposed to dependence on governmental action or support for social services that might be performed by private groups.

entry.cs:
Voluntary affidavitorVoluntary oath
Law an affidavit or oath made in an extrajudicial matter. Voluntary conveyance Law a conveyance without valuable consideration. Voluntary escape Law the escape of a prisoner by the express consent of the sheriff. Voluntary jurisdiction. Eng. Eccl. Law See Contentious jurisdiction, under Contentious. Voluntary waste. Law See Waste n., 4.
entry.ety: L. voluntarius, fr. voluntas will, choice, from the root of velle to will, p. pr. volens; akin to E. will: cf. F. volontaire, Of. also voluntaire. See Will v. t., and cf. Benevolent Volition Volunteer

sn.def: Proceeding from the will; produced in or by an act of choice.
sn.q: That sin or guilt pertains exclusively to voluntary action is the true principle of orthodoxy.

sn.def: Unconstrained by the interference of another; unimpelled by the influence of another; not prompted or persuaded by another; done of his or its own accord; spontaneous; acting of one's self, or of itself; free.
sn.q: Our voluntary service he requires.
She fell to lust a voluntary prey.

sn.def: Done by design or intention; intentional; purposed; intended; not accidental; as, if a man kills another by lopping a tree, it is not voluntary manslaughter.

Of or pertaining to the will; subject to, or regulated by, the will; as, the voluntary motions of an animal, such as the movements of the leg or arm (in distinction from involuntary motions, such as the movements of the heart); the voluntary muscle fibers, which are the agents in voluntary motion.
Endowed with the power of willing; as, man is a voluntary agent.
sn.q: God did not work as a necessary, but a voluntary, agent, intending beforehand, and decreeing with himself, that which did outwardly proceed from him.

sn.def: Free; without compulsion; according to the will, consent, or agreement, of a party; without consideration; gratuitous; without valuable consideration.
Of or pertaining to voluntaryism; as, a voluntary church, in distinction from an established or state church.
sn.syn: See Spontaneous.

entries.entry:
Vol"un*ta*ry n.; pl.Voluntaries.
One who engages in any affair of his own free will; a volunteer. R
Mus A piece played by a musician, often extemporarily, according to his fancy; specifically, an organ solo played before, during, or after divine service.
Eccl One who advocates voluntaryism.

entry.def: The principle of supporting a religious system and its institutions by voluntary association and effort, rather than by the aid or patronage of the state.

entry.ety: F. volontaire. See Voluntary a.

sn.def: One who enters into, or offers for, any service of his own free will.

One who enters into service voluntarily, but who, when in service, is subject to discipline and regulations like other soldiers; -- opposed to conscript; specifically, a voluntary member of the organized militia of a country as distinguished from the standing army.

A grantee in a voluntary conveyance; one to whom a conveyance is made without valuable consideration; a party, other than a wife or child of the grantor, to whom, or for whose benefit, a voluntary conveyance is made.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a volunteer or volunteers; consisting of volunteers; voluntary; as, volunteer companies; volunteer advice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Volunteered; p. pr. & vb. n. Volunteering
entry.def: To offer or bestow voluntarily, or without solicitation or compulsion; as, to volunteer one's services.
To enter into, or offer for, any service of one's own free will, without solicitation or compulsion; as, he volunteered in that undertaking.

entries.entry: Vol`un*teer" na"vy. A navy of vessels fitted out and manned by volunteers who sail under the flag of the regular navy and subject to naval discipline. Prussia in 1870, in the Franco-German war, organized such a navy, which was commanded by merchant seamen with temporary commissions, with the claim (in which England acquiesced) that it did not come within the meaning of the term privateer.
Vol`un*teers" of America. A religious and philanthropic organization, similar to the Salvation Army, founded (1896) by Commander and Mrs. Ballington Booth.
Volunteer State. Tennessee; -- a nickname.

entry.ety: Cf. Envelop
entry.def: A woman's cap.

entries.entry: Vo*lup"tu*a*ry ?; 135 n.; pl.Voluptuaries #. L. voluptuarius or voluptarius, fr. voluptas pleasure A voluptuous person; one who makes his physical enjoyment his chief care; one addicted to luxury, and the gratification of sensual appetites. A good-humored, but hard-hearted, voluptuary. Sensualist; epicure.

entry.def: Voluptuous; luxurious.

entry.ety: F. voluptueux, L. voluptuosus, fr. voluptas pleasure, volup agreeably, delightfully; probably akin to Gr. � to hope, � hope, and to L. velle to wish. See Voluntary

sn.def: Full of delight or pleasure, especially that of the senses; ministering to sensuous or sensual gratification; exciting sensual desires; luxurious; sensual.
sn.q: Music arose with its voluptuous swell.
Sink back into your voluptuous repose.

sn.def: Given to the enjoyments of luxury and pleasure; indulging to excess in sensual gratifications.
sn.q: The jolly andvoluptuouslivers.
Softened with pleasure and voluptuous life.

entry.ety: Cf. F. volupté pleasure. See Voluptuous
entry.def: Voluptuousness.

entries.entry:
Vo*lu"ta n.; pl. E. Volutas #, L. Volutæ #. L., a spiral scroll. See Volute
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of large, handsome marine gastropods belonging to Voluta and allied genera.

entry.ety: L. volutatio, from volutare to roll, wallow, verb freq. volvere volutum, to roll
entry.def: A rolling of a body; a wallowing.

cs.cd: a spring formed of a spiral scroll of plate, rod, or wire, extended or extensible in the direction of the axis of the coil, in which direction its elastic force is exerted and employed.

entry.ety: F. volutecf. It. voluta), L. voluta, from volvere volutum, to roll. See Voluble

sn.def: A spiral scroll which forms the chief feature of the Ionic capital, and which, on a much smaller scale, is a feature in the Corinthian and Composite capitals. See Illust. of Capital, also Helix, and Stale.
A spiral turn, as in certain shells.
Any voluta.

entry.def: Having a volute, or spiral scroll.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. volutio an arch, vault

sn.def: A spiral turn or wreath.
A whorl of a spiral shell.

entry.ety: L. volva vulva, covering
entry.def: A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as the plant develops.

A genus of minute, pale-green, globular, organisms, about one fiftieth of an inch in diameter, found rolling through water, the motion being produced by minute colorless cilia. It has been considered as belonging to the flagellate Infusoria, but is now referred to the vegetable kingdom, and each globule is considered a colony of many individuals. The commonest species is Volvox globator, often called globe animalcule.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. volvere to turn about, to roll
entry.def: The spasmodic contraction of the intestines which causes colic.
Any twisting or displacement of the intestines causing obstruction; ileus. See Ileus.
A lurcher.

entry.ety: L., a plowshare
entry.def: A bone, or one of a pair of bones, beneath the ethmoid region of the skull, forming a part a part of the partition between the nostrils in man and other mammals.
The pygostyle.
Of or pertaining to the vomer.

entry.ety: L., fr. vomere to throw up, vomit
entry.def: An abscess cavity in the lungs.
An abscess in any other parenchymatous organ.

entry.ety: From nux vomica
entry.def: See Brucine.

entries.entry:
Vom"ic nut`. Cf. F. noix vomique
Same as Nux vomica.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vomited; p. pr. & vb. n. Vomiting
entry.ety: Cf. L. vomere vomitum, and v. freq. vomitare. See Vomit n.
entry.def: To eject the contents of the stomach by the mouth; to puke; to spew.

sn.def: To throw up; to eject from the stomach through the mouth; to disgorge; to puke; to spew out; -- often followed by up or out.
sn.q: The fish . . . vomited out Jonah upon the dry land.

sn.def: Hence, to eject from any hollow place; to belch forth; to emit; to throw forth; as, volcanoes vomit flame, stones, etc.
sn.q: Like the sons of Vulcan, vomit smoke.

entry.cs: Black vomit. Med See in the Vocabulary. Vomit nut nux vomica.
entry.ety: L. vomitus, from vomere vomitum, to vomit; akin to Gr. �, Skr. vam, Lith. vemiti. Cf. Emetic Vomito

sn.def: Matter that is vomited; esp., matter ejected from the stomach through the mouth.
sn.q: Like vomit from his yawning entrails poured.

sn.def: That which excites vomiting; an emetic.
sn.q: He gives your Hollander a vomit.

entry.def: The spasmodic ejection of matter from the stomach through the mouth.

entry.ety: L. vomitio
entry.def: The act or power of vomiting.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vomitif
entry.def: Causing the ejection of matter from the stomach; emetic.

entry.ety: Sp. vómito, fr. L. vomitus. See Vomit n.
entry.def: The yellow fever in its worst form, when it is usually attended with black vomit. See Black vomit.

entry.ety: L. vomitorious
entry.def: Causing vomiting; emetic; vomitive.

entries.entry:
Vom"i*to*ry n.; pl.Vomitories.
An emetic; a vomit.
L. vomitorium
Arch A principal door of a large ancient building, as of an amphitheater. Sixty-four vomitories . . . poured forth the immense multitude.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vomiturition
entry.def: An ineffectual attempt to vomit.
The vomiting of but little matter; also, that vomiting which is effected with little effort.
Same as Vansire.

sn.def: See Voodooism.
One who practices voodooism; a negro sorcerer.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to voodooism, or a voodoo; as, voodoo incantations.

an economic hypothesis, proposed by President Ronald Regan, that large cuts in tax rates would so stimulate the economy that the tax revenue on the increases in business and personal income would offset the anticipated tax revenue losses, so that such tax cuts would not increasing the federal budget deficit. Its believers do not consider the actual massive deficit increases subsequent to the 1982-83 tax cut as being caused by the tax cut itself, but by other governmental policies. This hypothesis was graphically illustrated by the Laffer curve.

entry.ety: Probably (through Creole French vaudoux a negro sorcerer) fr. F. Vaudois Waldensian, because the Waldenses were accused of sorcery
entry.def: A degraded form of superstition and sorcery, said to include human sacrifices and cannibalism in some of its rites. It is prevalent among the negroes of Haiti, and to some extent in the United States, and is regarded as a relic of African barbarism.

entry.ety: D. (in South Africa)
entry.def: One who treks before or first; a pioneer.

entry.ety: L. vorax -acis, fr. vorare to devour; akin to Gr. � meat, food, � to devour, Skr. gar. Cf. Devour
entry.def: Greedy in eating; very hungry; eager to devour or swallow; ravenous; gluttonous; edacious; rapacious; as, a voracious man or appetite; a voracious gulf or whirlpool.

entry.ety: L. voracitas: cf. F. voracité
entry.def: The quality of being voracious; voraciousness.

entry.ety: L. voraginosus, fr. vorago an abyss, fr. vorare to swallow up
entry.def: Pertaining to a gulf; full of gulfs; hence, devouring.

entries.entry:
Vor"tex
Vortex atom Chem a hypothetical ring-shaped mass of elementary matter in continuous vortical motion. It was conveniently regarded in certain early mathematical models as the typical form and structure of the chemical atom, but is no longer considered a useful model, having been superseded by quantum mechanics. Vortex wheel a kind of turbine.
n.; pl. E. Vortexes #, L. Vortices #. L. vortex vertex -icis, fr. vortere vertere, to turn. See Vertex
A mass of fluid, especially of a liquid, having a whirling or circular motion tending to form a cavity or vacuum in the center of the circle, and to draw in towards the center bodies subject to its action; the form assumed by a fluid in such motion; a whirlpool; an eddy.
Cartesian System A supposed collection of particles of very subtile matter, endowed with a rapid rotary motion around an axis which was also the axis of a sun or a planet. Descartes attempted to account for the formation of the universe, and the movements of the bodies composing it, by a theory of vortices.
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of small Turbellaria belonging to Vortex and allied genera. See Illustration in Appendix.
Vor"tex fil"a*ment. A vortex tube of infinitesimal cross section.
Vor"tex fringe. The region immediately surrounding a disk moving flatwise through air; -- so called because the air has a cyclic motion as in vortex ring.
Vortex line. A line, within a rotating fluid, whose tangent at every point is the instantaneous axis of rotation as that point of the fluid.

Vortex ring. Physics A ring-shaped mass of moving fluid which, by virtue of its motion of rotation around an axis disposed in circular form, attains a more or less distinct separation from the surrounding medium and has many of the properties of a solid.

Vortex theory. Chem. & Physics The theory, advanced by Thomson (Lord Kelvin) on the basis of investigation by Helmholtz, that the atoms are vortically moving ring-shaped masses (or masses of other forms having a similar internal motion) of a homogeneous, incompressible, frictionless fluid. Various properties of such atoms (vortex atoms) can be mathematically deduced. This theory is now (1998) obsolete, and has been superseded by quantum mechanics, which provides more accurate and detailed explanations of atomic behavior.
Vortex tube. Physics An imaginary tube within a rotating fluid, formed by drawing the vortex lines through all points of a closed curve.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a vortex or vortexes; resembling a vortex in form or motion; whirling; as, a vortical motion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vorticelle. See Vortex
entry.def: A vorticella.

entries.entry:
Vor`ti*cel"la n.; pl. E. Vorticellas, L. Vorticellæ. NL., dim. fr. L. vortex. See Vortex
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of ciliated Infusoria belonging to Vorticella and many other genera of the family Vorticellidæ. They have a more or less bell-shaped body with a circle of vibrating cilia around the oral disk. Most of the species have slender, contractile stems, either simple or branched.

entry.ety: L. vorticosus
entry.def: Vortical; whirling; as, a vorticose motion.

entry.ety: Cf. Vertiginous
entry.def: Moving rapidly round a center; vortical.

entry.ety: See Votary n.
entry.def: A woman who is a votary.

entry.ety: See Votary
entry.def: A votary.
entry.q: Like a sad votarist in palmer's weed.

entry.ety: From L. votus, p. p. vovere to vow, to devote. See Vote Vow
entry.def: Consecrated by a vow or promise; consequent on a vow; devoted; promised.
entry.q: Votary resolution is made equipollent to custom.

entries.entry: Vo"ta*ry n.; pl.Votaries. One devoted, consecrated, or engaged by a vow or promise; hence, especially, one devoted, given, or addicted, to some particular service, worship, study, or state of life. You are already love's firmvotary. 'T was coldness of the votary, not the prayer, that was in fault. But thou, my votary, weepest thou?

cs.cd: See under Casting Cumulative, etc.

entry.ety: L. votum a vow, wish, will, fr. vovere votum, to vow: cf. F. vote. See Vow

sn.def: An ardent wish or desire; a vow; a prayer.

A wish, choice, or opinion, of a person or a body of persons, expressed in some received and authorized way; the expression of a wish, desire, will, preference, or choice, in regard to any measure proposed, in which the person voting has an interest in common with others, either in electing a person to office, or in passing laws, rules, regulations, etc.; suffrage.
That by means of which will or preference is expressed in elections, or in deciding propositions; voice; a ballot; a ticket; as, a written vote .
sn.q: The freeman casting with unpurchased hand The vote that shakes the turrets of the land.

sn.def: Expression of judgment or will by a majority; legal decision by some expression of the minds of a number; as, the vote was unanimous; a vote of confidence.
Votes, collectively; as, the Tory vote; the labor vote .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Voted; p. pr. & vb. n. Voting
entry.ety: Cf. F. voter
entry.def: To express or signify the mind, will, or preference, either viva voce, or by ballot, or by other authorized means, as in electing persons to office, in passing laws, regulations, etc., or in deciding on any proposition in which one has an interest with others.
entry.q: The vote for a duelist is to assist in the prostration of justice, and, indirectly, to encourage the crime.
To vote on large principles, to vote honestly, requires a great amount of information.

sn.def: To choose by suffrage; to elec�; as, to vote a candidate into office.
To enact, establish, grant, determine, etc., by a formal vote; as, the legislature voted the resolution.
sn.q: Parliament voted them one hundred thousand pounds.

sn.def: To declare by general opinion or common consent, as if by a vote; as, he was voted a bore.
To condemn; to devote; to doom.

entry.def: One who votes; one who has a legal right to vote, or give his suffrage; an elector; a suffragist; as, an independent voter .

cs.cd: a form of ballot containing the names of more candidates than there are offices to be filled, the voter making a mark against the preferred names.

entry.def: a. & n. from Vote v.
One who makes a vow.

cs.cd: a medal struck in grateful commemoration of some auspicious event.
an offering in fulfillment of a religious vow, as of one's person or property.

entry.ety: L. votivus, fr. votum a vow: cf. F. votif. See Vow
entry.def: Given by vow, or in fulfillment of a vow; consecrated by a vow; devoted; as, votive offerings; a votive tablet.
entry.q: Votiveincense.
We reached a votive stone, that bears the name Of Aloys Reding.
Embellishments of flowers and votive garlands.

entry.def: A votaress.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vouched; p. pr. & vb. n. Vouching
entry.ety: OE. vouchen, OF. vochier to call, fr. L. vocare to call, fr. vox vocis, voice. See Voice, and cf. Avouch

sn.def: To call; to summon.
sn.q: Theyvouchas I might say) to their aid the authority of the writers.

sn.def: To call upon to witness; to obtest.
sn.q: Vouch the silent stars and conscious moon.

sn.def: To warrant; to maintain by affirmations; to attest; to affirm; to avouch.
sn.q: They made him ashamed to vouch the truth of the relation, and afterwards to credit it.

sn.def: To back; to support; to confirm; to establish.
sn.q: Me damp horror chilled At such bold words vouched with a deed so bold.

sn.def: To call into court to warrant and defend, or to make good a warranty of title.
sn.q: He vouches the tenant in tail, who vouches over the common vouchee.
sn.syn: To obtest; declare; affirm; attest; warrant; confirm; asseverate; aver; protest; assure.

sn.def: To bear witness; to give testimony or full attestation.
sn.q: He will not believe her until the elector of Hanover shall vouch for the truth of what she has . . . affirmed.

sn.def: To assert; to aver; to declare.

entry.def: Warrant; attestation.
entry.q: The vouch of very malice itself.

entry.def: The person who is vouched, or called into court to support or make good his warranty of title in the process of common recovery.

sn.def: One who vouches, or gives witness or full attestation, to anything.
sn.q: Will his vouchers vouch him no more?
The great writers of that age stand up together as vouchers for one another's reputation.

sn.def: A book, paper, or document which serves to vouch the truth of accounts, or to confirm and establish facts of any kind; also, any acquittance or receipt showing the payment of a debt; as, the merchant's books are his vouchers for the correctness of his accounts; notes, bonds, receipts, and other writings, are used as vouchers in proving facts.

sd.def: The act of calling in a person to make good his warranty of title in the old form of action for the recovery of lands.
The tenant in a writ of right; one who calls in another to establish his warranty of title. In common recoveries, there may be a single voucher or double vouchers.

sn.def: A document attesting to a credit against certain defined expenditures; a recipt for prepayment; -- often used in pre-arranged travel plans, to provide evidence of pre-payment of the cost of lodging, transportation, or meals.

entry.def: A solemn assertion.
Same as Voucher, 3 .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vouchsafed; p. pr. & vb. n. Vouchsafing
entry.ety: Vouch + safe, that is, to vouch or answer for safety

sn.def: To condescend to grant; to concede; to bestow.
sn.q: If ye vouchsafe that it be so.
Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?
It is not said by the apostle that God vouchsafed to the heathens the means of salvation.

sn.def: To receive or accept in condescension.

entry.def: To condescend; to deign; to yield; to descend or stoop.
entry.q: Vouchsafe, O Lord, to keep us this day without sin.
Vouchsafe, illustrious Ormond, to behold What power the charms of beauty had of old.

entry.def: The act of vouchsafing, or that which is vouchsafed; a gift or grant in condescension.

entry.ety: F., akin to voûte an arch, a vault
entry.def: One of the wedgelike stones of which an arch is composed.

entry.ety: OE. vou, OF. vou veu vo vu, F. v�u, from L. votum, from vovere, to vow. Cf. Avow Devout Vote

sn.def: A solemn promise made to God, or to some deity; an act by which one consecrates or devotes himself, absolutely or conditionally, wholly or in part, for a longer or shorter time, to some act, service, or condition; a devotion of one's possessions; as, a baptismal vow; a vow of poverty.
sn.q: Nothing . . . that may . . . stain myvowof Nazarite.
I pray thee, let me go and pay my vow.
I am combined by a sacred vow.

sn.def: Specifically, a promise of fidelity; a pledge of love or affection; as, the marriage vow .
sn.q: Knights of love, who never broke their vow; Firm to their plighted faith.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Vowing
entry.ety: OE. vouen, OF. vouer voer, F. vouer, LL. votare. See Vow n.

sn.def: To give, consecrate, or dedicate to God, or to some deity, by a solemn promise; to devote; to promise solemnly.
sn.q: When thouvowesta vow unto God, defer not to pay it.
Men] that vow a long and weary pilgrimage.

sn.def: To assert solemnly; to asseverate.

entry.def: To make a vow, or solemn promise.
entry.q: Better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldest vow and not pay.

entry.note: ☞ In the English language, the written vowels are aeiou, and sometimes w and y. The spoken vowels are much more numerous.
entry.cs:
Close vowel. See under Close a.
Vowel point. See under Point n.
entry.ety: F. voyelle, or an OF. form without y, L. vocalissc. littera), from vocalis sounding, from vox vocis, a voice, sound. See Vocal
entry.def: A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonance in the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving to each several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound of speech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whether made with or without vocality, derives its character in every case from some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, a letter or character which represents such a sound. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 5, 146-149.
Of or pertaining to a vowel; vocal.
Furnished with vowels.
Of the nature of a vowel.
entry.q: The power [ofw] is always vowelish.

entry.def: The use of vowels.
To give the quality, sound, or office of a vowel to.
One who makes a vow.
One bound by the same vow as another.

cs.cd: a reed stop in an organ, made to imitate the human voice.

entry.ety: L. See Voice
entry.def: A voice.

entries.entry: Vox` an*gel"i*ca Vox` an*gel"i*ca. L. angelica angelic Music An organ stop of delicate stringlike quality, having for each finger key a pair of pipes, of which one is tuned slightly sharp to give a wavy effect to their joint tone.

entry.ety: OE. veage viage, OF. veage viage veiage voiage, F. voyage, LL. viaticum, fr. L. viaticum traveling money, provision for a journey, from viaticus belonging to a road or journey, fr. via way, akin to E. way. See Way n., and cf. Convey Deviate Devious Envoy Trivial Viaduct Viaticum

sn.def: Formerly, a passage either by sea or land; a journey, in general; but not chiefly limited to a passing by sea or water from one place, port, or country, to another; especially, a passing or journey by water to a distant place or country.
sn.q: I love a sea voyage and a blustering tempest.
So steers the prudent crane Her annual voyage, borne on winds.
All the voyage of their life Is bound in shallows and in miseries.

sn.def: The act or practice of traveling.
sn.q: Nations have interknowledge of one another by voyage into foreign parts, or strangers that come to them.

sn.def: Course; way.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Voyaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Voyaging
entry.ety: Cf. F. voyager
entry.def: To take a voyage; especially, to sail or pass by water.
entry.q: A mind foreverVoyaging through strange seas of thought alone.

entry.def: To travel; to pass over; to traverse.
entry.q: With what painIvoyaged the unreal, vast, unbounded deep.

entry.ety: Cf. F. voyageable
entry.def: That may be sailed over, as water or air; navigable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. voyager traveling
entry.def: One who voyages; one who sails or passes by sea or water.

entry.ety: F., fr. voyager to travel. See Voyage
entry.def: A traveler; -- applied in Canada to a man employed by the fur companies in transporting goods by the rivers and across the land, to and from the remote stations in the Northwest.
See Viol, 2.
The block through which a messenger passes.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The appearance of truth; verisimilitude.
A cavity in a lode; -- called also vogle.

entry.ety: L. Vulcanus Volcanus: cf. Skr. ulkā a firebrand, meteor. Cf. Volcano
entry.def: The god of fire, who presided over the working of metals; -- answering to the Greek Hephæstus.

entry.ety: L. Vulcanius

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Vulcan; made by Vulcan; hence, of or pertaining to works in iron or other metals.
sn.q: Ingenious allusions to the Vulcanian panoply which Achilles lent to his feebler friend.

sn.def: Volcanic.
Of or pertaining to Vulcan; made by Vulcan; Vulcanian.
Of or pertaining to volcanoes; specifically, relating to the geological theory of the Vulcanists, or Plutonists.

entry.def: Volcanicity.
Volcanism.
A volcanist.
Hard rubber produced by vulcanizing with a large proportion of sulphur.

entry.ety: See Vulcan
entry.def: The act or process of imparting to caoutchouc, gutta-percha, or the like, greater elasticity, durability, or hardness by heating with sulphur under pressure.

cs.cd: paper, paper pulp, or other fiber, chemically treated, as with metallic chlorides, so as to form a substance resembling ebonite in texture, hardness, etc.
India rubber, vulcanized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vulcanized; p. pr. & vb. n. Vulcanizing
entry.def: To change the properties of, as caoutchouc, or India rubber, by the process of vulcanization.
One who, or that which, vulcanizes; esp., an apparatus for vulcanizing caoutchouc.
A volcano.

entry.ety: See Vulcan, and -logy
entry.def: The science which treats of phenomena due to plutonic action, as in volcanoes, hot springs, etc.

entries.entry: Vul"can pow"der. A dynamite composed of nitroglycerin (30 parts), sodium nitrate (52.5), charcoal (10.5), and sulphur (7), used in mining and blasting.

entry.cs: Vulgar fraction. Arith See under Fraction.
entry.ety: L. vulgaris, from vulgus the multitude, the common people; of uncertain origin: cf. F. vulgaire. Cf. Divulge

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the mass, or multitude, of people; common; general; ordinary; public; hence, in general use; vernacular.
sn.q: Things vulgar, and well-weighed, scarce worth the praise.
It might be more useful to the English reader . . . to write in our vulgar language.
The mechanical process of multiplying books had brought the New Testament in the vulgar tongue within the reach of every class.

sn.def: Belonging or relating to the common people, as distinguished from the cultivated or educated; pertaining to common life; plebeian; not select or distinguished; hence, sometimes, of little or no value.
sn.q: Like thevulgarsort of market men.
Men who have passed all their time in low and vulgar life.
In reading an account of a battle, we follow the hero with our whole attention, but seldom reflect on thevulgar heaps of slaughter.

sn.def: Hence, lacking cultivation or refinement; rustic; boorish; also, offensive to good taste or refined feelings; low; coarse; mean; base; as, vulgar men, minds, language, or manners.
sn.q: Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vulgaire

sn.def: One of the common people; a vulgar person.
sn.q: These vile vulgars are extremely proud.

sn.def: The vernacular, or common language.

entry.def: A vulgar person; one who has vulgar ideas. Used also adjectively.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vulgarisme

sn.def: Grossness; rudeness; vulgarity.
A vulgar phrase or expression.
sn.q: A fastidious taste will find offense in the occasional vulgarisms, or what we now call “slang,” which not a few of our writers seem to have affected.

entry.ety: Cf. F. vulgarité, L. vulgaritas the multitude

sn.def: The quality or state of being vulgar; mean condition of life; the state of the lower classes of society.
Grossness or clownishness of manners of language; absence of refinement; coarseness.
sn.q: The reprobate vulgarity of the frequenters of Bartholomew Fair.

entry.def: The act or process of making vulgar, or common.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Vulgarized; p. pr. & vb. n. Vulgarizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. vulgariser, LL. vulgarizare
entry.def: To make vulgar, or common.
entry.q: Exhortation vulgarized by low wit.

entry.def: In a vulgar manner.
The quality of being vulgar.

entry.note: ☞ The Vulgate was made by Jerome at the close of the 4th century. The Old Testament he translated mostly from the Hebrew and Chaldaic, and the New Testament he revised from an older Latin version. The Douay version, so called, is an English translation from the Vulgate. See Douay Bible.
entry.ety: NL. vulgata, from L. vulgatus usual, common, p. p. of vulgare to make general, or common, fr. vulgus the multitude: cf. F. vulgate. See Vulgar a.
entry.def: An ancient Latin version of the Scripture, and the only version which the Roman Church admits to be authentic; -- so called from its common use in the Latin Church.
Of or pertaining to the Vulgate, or the old Latin version of the Scriptures.
The quality or state of being vulnerable; vulnerableness.

entry.ety: L. vulnerabilis wounding, injurious, from vulnerare to wound, vulnus a wound; akin to Skr. vra�a: cf. F. vulnérable

sn.def: Capable of being wounded; susceptible of wounds or external injuries; as, a vulnerable body.
sn.q: Achilles was vulnerable in his heel; and there will be wanting a Paris to infix the dart.

sn.def: Liable to injury; subject to be affected injuriously; assailable; as, a vulnerable reputation.
sn.q: His skill in finding out the vulnerable parts of strong minds was consummate.

entry.def: The quality or state of being vulnerable; vulnerability.

entry.ety: L. vulnearius: cf. F. vulnéraire
entry.def: Useful in healing wounds; adapted to the cure of external injuries; as, vulnerary plants or potions.
entry.q: Suchvulneraryremedies.

entry.ety: L. vulneratus, p. p. of vulnerare to wound
entry.def: To wound; to hurt.

entry.ety: L. vulneratio
entry.def: The act of wounding, or the state of being wounded.
Full of wounds; wounded.

entry.ety: L. vulnificus; vulnus a wound + facere to make
entry.def: Causing wounds; inflicting wounds; wounding.
Having wounds; vulnerose.

entry.ety: L., a fox
entry.def: A genus of Carnivora including the foxes.
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtained from a lichen (Cetraria vulpina) as a yellow or red crystalline substance which on decomposition yields pulvinic acid.

entry.ety: L. vulpes a fox + caedere to kill
entry.def: One who kills a fox, except in hunting; also, the act of so killing a fox.

cs.cd: an Australian carnivorous marsupial (Phalangista vulpina syn. Trichosurus vulpina); -- called also vulpine phalanger, and vulpine opossum.

entry.ety: L. vulpinus, from vulpes a fox
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the fox; resembling the fox; foxy; cunning; crafty; artful.
Same as Vulpic.
The quality of being cunning like the fox; craft; artfulness.
entry.q: He was without guile, and had no vulpinism at all.

entry.ety: So called after Vulpino, in Italy
entry.def: A scaly granular variety of anhydrite of a grayish white color, used for ornamental purposes.
The brush turkey (Talegallus Lathami) of Australia. See Brush turkey.

entry.note: ☞ In most of the species the head and neck are naked or nearly so. They feed chiefly on carrion. The condor, king vulture, turkey buzzard, and black vulture (Catharista atrata) are well known American species. The griffin, lammergeir, and Pharaoh's chicken, or Egyptian vulture, are common Old World vultures.
entry.ety: OE. vultur, L. vultur: cf. OF. voltour, F. vautour
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of rapacious birds belonging to Vultur Cathartes Catharista, and various other genera of the family Vulturidæ.

entry.ety: L. vulturinus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a vulture; resembling a vulture in qualities or looks; as, the vulturine sea eagle (Gypohierax Angolensis); vulturine rapacity.
entry.q: The vulturine nose, which smells nothing but corruption, is no credit to its possessor.

entry.def: Vulturous.
The quality or state of being like a vulture; rapaciousness.
Like a vulture; rapacious.

entry.ety: L. vulva volva, from volvere to roll

sn.def: The external parts of the female genital organs; sometimes, the opening between the projecting parts of the external organs.
The orifice of the oviduct of an insect or other invertebrate.

entry.ety: L. vulva volva, a wrapper + -form
entry.def: Like a cleft with projecting edges.

entry.ety: NL. See Vulva, and -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of the vulva.
Pertaining both to the vulva and the uterus.
Pertaining both to the vulva and the vagina.

entry.ety: Cf. Vise
entry.def: A kind of clamp with gimlet points for holding a barrel head while the staves are being closed around it.
a. & n. from Vie.
